[17:32:00.0000] <Lachy>

[17:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lachy, I mean that if it's unlimited, you won't care how much you use, so you'll be much more likely to use an unreasonably large amount, which in aggregate degrades service for everyone.

[17:32:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But every individual bears too little of the cost to care.

[17:32:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[17:34:00.0000] <Lachy>

[17:40:01.0000] <Lachy>
AryehGregor, bandwidth is not a limited resource in the same sense as physical resources, and bandwidth caps attempt to solve the issue the wrong way.

[17:40:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lachy, it's limited every bit as much as things like electricity or water.  How would you solve it?

[17:41:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[17:41:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[17:41:02.0000] <Lachy>
Bandwidth is, for the sake of simplicity, effectively a measure of how much data can be transmitted at the same time. So offering plans based on the bandwidth, or rather speed, provided to the user makes sense.

[17:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Whee, still using MySQL 4.1.  At least one user is benefiting for our support for ancient MySQL versions!

[17:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
But imposing monthly usage limits tries to treat data as a finite resource, and implies that it will somehow run out if too much is used in a month.

[17:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, what they really care about is how much you're using at peak.  If there's excess capacity, it makes no difference to them, no.  So it's a crude metric, that's true.

[17:45:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's not quite true, actually.

[17:45:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
They do pay for every bit that goes over a backbone, AFAIK.

[17:45:03.0000] <Lachy>
but that's not the case at all. If a backbone can support 1Gbps, and 50 users are connected to that, each going flat out on their ADSL2+, 20Mbps connection, they could do that all indefinitely.

[17:46:02.0000] <Lachy>

[17:47:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[00:47:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: does aria-hidden actually work in Firefox for the use case you mentioned on the list?

[00:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: does aria-hidden in Firefox cause content to be hidden from visual rendering?

[00:48:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: no, AFAIK

[00:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I assume not, because that would violate the ARIA spec

[00:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so I assume it does work in Firefox

[00:48:03.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: but at least at some point, it didn't really prune anything from the accessible tree, either

[00:48:04.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: that would presumably be a bug in their ARIA support...

[00:48:05.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: it depended on the author specifying *[aria-hidden="true"] { display: none; }

[00:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I'm certainly not telling authors to include that, since it subverts the intent of the ARIA spec (as far as I can tell)

[00:49:01.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: I guess "the intent of the ARIA spec" is tricky thing

[00:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
my reading is that role="presentation" is supposed to skip an element (but still include its children) in the accessibility tree, and aria-hidden is supposed to hide the element *and* its children in the accessibility tree

[00:50:01.0000] <hsivonen>
what I've heard from the folks behind ARIA, *[aria-hidden="true"] { display: none; } in an author style sheet is very much something that is expected

[00:50:02.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: that's my understanding of the spec, too.

[00:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
having that in a UA stylesheet would definitely violate the ARIA spec

[00:51:01.0000] <othermaciej>
having it in an author stylesheet does not seem like a problem per se if you definitely want to visually hide all content that's also hidden from accessibility

[00:51:02.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: I said "author style sheet" intentionally. Putting it in the UA style sheet would be clearly wrong.

[00:51:03.0000] <othermaciej>
however, the author should not *have* to specify that, to hide content in the accessibility tree

[00:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if the UA doesn't prune it from the accessibility tree unless the author includes "*[aria-hidden="true"] { display: none; }", that too would violate the ARIA spec (as I read it)

[00:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or at least, if the UA+AT combination still present the content in that case, then there is clearly a bug in at least one of them

[00:52:02.0000] <hsivonen>
I agree. Dunno what Firefox does now and what's considered a bug and what's a feature here.

[00:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but like I said, I've been advising people to use it like a recursive version of role="presentation"

[00:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(the case this has particularly come up, the content does not actually need to work in other browsers, but that doesn't seem relevant to the actual issue of use cases)

[00:55:01.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: has this been for iTunes-embedded WebKit?

[00:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
can't really talk about the specific details, but feel free to speculate

[00:56:01.0000] <hsivonen>
I see

[00:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and I am sure we will need something similar in the future in content that works cross-browser

[00:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
at which point I guess we will have to test in all the target browsers we care about and possibly report bugs

[01:35:01.0000] <surkov>

[01:36:00.0000] <zcorpan>

Advisory: it is incorrect use of ARIA if an element with aria-hidden="true" is visible. The aria-hidden property is exposed only so that DOM-based assistive technologies can be informed of visibility changes. However, the layout will be able to provide the most complete set of all truly hidden

[01:36:01.0000] <zcorpan>
nodes."

[01:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but you'd still need a proper mechanism to hide parts of the XBL shadow tree from screen readers

[01:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:46:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(which is the only mode VoiceOver has, so you can work with or help a blind person by looking over their shoulder)

[02:19:01.0000] <Hixie>

[02:20:00.0000] <Hixie>

[02:20:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I have some potentially bad news, which is that I came up with a way to do the handshake that is both much more secure and likely much easier to use in existing server software

[02:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh?

[02:20:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: is it too late to consider changes to the handshake?

[02:20:04.0000] <Hixie>
depends how much of an improvement it is

[02:20:05.0000] <Hixie>
what is the improvement?

[02:21:00.0000] <othermaciej>
ok, so as I understand it, the security goal of the "exact binary match" requirement on the first part of the header is to reduce the risk of abusing unmodified vanilla HTTP servers,  or non-HTTP resources

[02:21:01.0000] <zcorpan>
othermaciej: thanks

[02:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: more or less, yeah

[02:21:03.0000] <othermaciej>
so there's two problems with the current setup:

[02:21:04.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, you can prevent sending a preflight by preventing making requests that result in one

[02:22:00.0000] <annevk>
(you can force a preflight if you want)

[02:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
1) Hardcoding not just the status line, but also a few of the initial headers, is apparently a pain in the ass to work into existing HTTP stacks in servers (I'm willing to take their word for it).

[02:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
i don't buy that at all, but i have heard it, yes

[02:22:03.0000] <othermaciej>
2) The handshake response consists exclusively of fixed contents, and literal character-for-character echoes of parts of the handshake request

[02:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
right

[02:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
this means that if you can trick any server into echoing back exact text of choice in response to a WebSocket request, you are hosed

[02:23:02.0000] <othermaciej>
a better method would be requiring something in the response that proves you saw the request, but is not predictable in advance

[02:23:03.0000] <Hixie>
yes, though i'm not aware of any case where it is possible, and i've looked

[02:23:04.0000] <othermaciej>
so here is my proposal:

[02:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
woah woah

[02:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
no

[02:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
we don't want to require that the server parse the request

[02:24:03.0000] <Hixie>
in fact in the common case the server won't parse the request at all

[02:24:04.0000] <othermaciej>
- Include a nonce in the request

[02:24:05.0000] <othermaciej>
- Server includes a hash of the nonce plus the request origin in the response status line

[02:25:00.0000] <othermaciej>
- Only the status line is strictly constrained, not response headers

[02:25:01.0000] <othermaciej>
This is clearly more robust against cross-protocol attacks

[02:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
unless you're aware of a web service that can be tricked into sending back the handshake, that seems unnecessarily complicated

[02:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
right now in the most common case a websocket server will send the handshake before the client does

[02:26:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's actually pretty trivial

[02:26:02.0000] <othermaciej>
cross-protocol attacks do happen and it's hard to predict them

[02:26:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's not as trivial as not doing anything :-)

[02:26:04.0000] <othermaciej>
witness recent firefox-based attack against IRC

[02:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
i agree that they happen, but as far as i've been able to tell, what we have currently is sufficient

[02:27:01.0000] <othermaciej>
what I described is far more robust against cross-protocol attacks, and likely easier to do in the context of integrating with an existing Web server

[02:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
actually i don't see why it's any more secure

[02:27:03.0000] <othermaciej>
again, anything where the necessary handshake response is predictable is much more robust

[02:27:04.0000] <Hixie>
why can't you just cause the server to echo back the right hash?

[02:27:05.0000] <othermaciej>
because you can't predict the correct handshake response

[02:27:06.0000] <Hixie>
why not?

[02:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
because you (the JS-level attacker) do not know the nonce

[02:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
oh the UA makes up the nonce, ok

[02:28:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it is generated by the UA

[02:28:03.0000] <Hixie>
that seems like a lot more complexity than what we have now

[02:28:04.0000] <Hixie>
i agree it's easy for experienced programmers

[02:28:05.0000] <othermaciej>
it doesn't even have to be a cryptographically secure hash, in fact, it might be an improvement even if you don't hash the nonce at all

[02:28:06.0000] <Hixie>
and even more non-experienced ones

[02:28:07.0000] <Hixie>
s/more/most/

[02:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
(or at least many0

[02:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
but it is still more work than nothing

[02:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not aware of any protocol where you can cause the server to echo back the handshake or even get close

[02:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
especially given how constrained the client's part of the handshake is

[02:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and putting the unpredictable part of the required handshake response in the status line makes it slightly more robust against header injection attacks on normal HTTP services

[02:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
right, the client can only control the URL part

[02:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
however, what I described is secure at a stronger level than "I'm not aware of any hackable services currently"

[02:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
agreed, but it's not enough of an improvement to throw away the half-dozen or so implementations

[02:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
(if you had suggested this six months ago, it'd be in without question)

[02:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
why don't we check if server and client implementors think it's enough of an improvement?

[02:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
go for it

[02:32:02.0000] <othermaciej>
afaik the only client implementation that has actually shipped is Chrome, and they specifically said they weren't looking to prematurely lock in the protocol

[02:32:03.0000] <Hixie>
i'm certainly happy to improve matters if people are willing to rewrite their code

[02:32:04.0000] <Hixie>
though i really don't like requiring that the server have to do work in the handshake

[02:32:05.0000] <Hixie>
isn't there some way we can get around that?

[02:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I posted a vague form of my suggestion on the hybi list

[02:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe I should pull it out of the thread and/or post it on whatwg

[02:33:02.0000] <annevk>
man, all this hybi crap in my inbox

[02:33:03.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe also get abarth's opinion

[02:33:04.0000] <annevk>
and now you guys are spamming this channel with it as well :p

[02:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
actually the more i think of this the less i like it... i don't like making the server have to read the client's data

[02:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
currently you can make a really simple server that completely ignores the server if you want to do something simple (similar to eventsource)

[02:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
er, ignores the client

[02:34:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: if a server accepts requests from multiple origins, doesn't it have to read the client's data anyway?

[02:34:04.0000] <Hixie>
yes, but that's likely to be much rarer

[02:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but the fact that it's needed in that case makes me think it is not such a huge burden

[02:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
i didn't say it was a huge burden, i said it was a burden

[02:36:02.0000] <Hixie>
right now you can literally never read a byte from the client

[02:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the part that the server has to read, check and echo-back isn't even in the fixed-order-and-capitalization part of the request, it's in the freeform part

[02:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
is it not required for servers to check correctness of the client part of the handshake?

[02:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
no

[02:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
they can totally ignore the client

[02:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
so a server could respond with WebSocket data even if you don't include Upgrade: WebSocket Connection: Upgrade?

[02:37:04.0000] <Hixie>
yes

[02:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
wouldn't such a service be at risk of being exploited via XHR?

[02:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
comnnechow?

[02:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
er

[02:38:03.0000] <Hixie>
how?

[02:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
try connecting to damowmow.com:11111

[02:38:05.0000] <Hixie>
how can XHR exploit that?

[02:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
If it does not check the handshake request, I bet I can send it a GET with some preformatted messages as the body

[02:39:01.0000] <othermaciej>
even if I can't get the results back, that's still an integrity violation

[02:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
?

[02:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if the service accepts commands of some kind via WebSocket that have side effects, rather than just reporting data, you could use XHR to abuse it if it does not check the handshake request

[02:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
if the server ignores the client, there's really not much to abuse

[02:40:02.0000] <surkov>
othermaciej: thanks for the link, I looked at the Firefox code and we do nothing with aria-hidden. And it sounds it goes with the spec :). However I'm agree it's not clear why ARIA hidden is at all.

[02:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
at least in a browser that supports CORS

[02:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
surkov: it doesn't sound to me like that is correct per the actual spec

[02:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
if the server ignores the client handshake but does listen to frames, then yes, you could send frames, just like you could if you just used zombies to send data there

[02:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
that doesn't seem like a particular problem

[02:41:03.0000] <annevk>
XHR cannot do GET with a body

[02:41:04.0000] <annevk>
unless the UA is broken

[02:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's a problem if the server uses Cookies from the request but does not otherwise check correctness

[02:42:01.0000] <surkov>
othermaciej: the spec sais aria-hidden="true" should be on hidden elements, aria-hidden="false" on visible elements so aria-hidden does affect on nothing

[02:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: good point - do any cross-site POSTs count as "simple requests"

[02:42:03.0000] <annevk>
yes

[02:42:04.0000] <annevk>
if the Content-Type header matches <form enctype> allowed values

[02:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: yes, if you read cookies you should make sure you're getting a websocket handshake. but then we're far past "ignoring the client", and checking the handshake is not a burden any more, since you're already parsing it and everything.

[02:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so if you're not checking correctness of the handshake request you presumably don't check the method either

[02:43:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: it seems to me that if you are completely ignoring the client, you don't really need a full duplex connection

[02:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: *shrug*

[02:44:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if you listen to the messages, then you'd better check the handshake

[02:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
i doubt most servers will

[02:44:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the spec should at least mention this in security considerations, even if it does not mandate rejecting a bad handshake

[02:45:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if most servers will not, then we effectively have an insecure protocol

[02:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
not much we can do about that as far as i can tell

[02:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it's always possible to make a buggy server, and indeed we can't prevent that

[02:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but:

[02:46:01.0000] <othermaciej>
a) the spec could require the server to check the handshake for correctness, even if we know some won't listen

[02:46:02.0000] <Hixie>
sure, i can add that, at least for the case where you read cookies

[02:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>
b) even if it does not require it, the spec could recommend checking the handshake for correctness in the case where you look at any credentials and/or perform any side effects in response to messages

[02:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
c) my nonce proposal would actually force servers to read the handshake and process it (though it can't force them to check it is really correct, I suppose)

[02:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if a server truly ignores all input, then it could work just as well over EventSource with less trouble, so I am not sure WebSocket has to make that use case extra easy

[02:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think requiring the non-sensitive cases to be harder just to secure the sensitive cases is making the wrong tradeoff, personally

[02:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
what i'd really like to do is throw out the HTTP compatibility altogether

[02:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
and go back to ports 81 and 815

[02:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the sensitive use cases are some of the most important

[02:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
and then just have people use port 443 as they will anyway

[02:50:02.0000] <othermaciej>
chat is clearly a case where you care about integrity, not just confidentiality

[02:50:03.0000] <othermaciej>
(i.e. you don't want random third parties to be able to forge chat messages as you)

[02:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think security is one area where I would be very hesitant to cut corners, even if it makes things easier for the use cases where you don't need any security

[02:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
well if we really want security to that level, we should design the handshake with that in mind and stop using HTTP

[02:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
trying to retrofit it into HTTP isn't ideal

[02:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
and will always leave us vulnerable to the fake-websocket-via-form-post attack

[02:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
retrofitting it into HTTP makes it easier to share a host:port with a web server

[02:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
i thought so too, but apparently not

[02:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
because it makes people think they should use their HTTP output code

[02:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
well it's really the input side of the handshake that matters

[02:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
i.e. the request from the client to the server

[02:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the server response could be anything, the fact that it takes the form of an HTTP 101 request is just following things to their logical conclusion

[02:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that being said, I think making the handshake response unpredictable would do more to improve security than making the handshake non-HTTP

[02:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
making the handshake non-HTTP could solve the entire attack scenario you described

[02:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
which is a real attack scenario

[02:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
unlike echoing the handshake, which is theoretical at this point

[02:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
so i'd say it's the other way around

[02:56:04.0000] <othermaciej>
actually, if a non-http handshake still allowed the server to ignore the client handshake request, it would do nothing to prevent my attack scenario

[02:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
nah, it'd be easy to design it in a way that it could... e.g. terminate the handshake with \n, so that the first frame would be corrupt

[02:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
then you would have to hard fail on a bad frame instead of ignoring it and moving on - does the protocol require that currently?

[02:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
if you're writing a server lazily, that's by far the easiest thing to do

[03:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
the spec does explain how you can go the extra mile and ignore unknown frames, but it's extra code, like checking the handshake

[03:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if the frame boundary is a fixed sentinel, then it's easiest to scan for the sentinel

[03:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
we could arrange for the failure to be with a length-delimited frame and for the length to be gigantic

[03:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
by flipping the meanings of the high bits in the frame typesa and the length marker

[03:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
if we do your nonce idea, we could put the nonce in a specific header that would only be included with websockets

[03:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
so that if you can't find it, you can't send it

[03:02:02.0000] <othermaciej>
request-wise you mean?

[03:02:03.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[03:02:04.0000] <Hixie>
that might make it more likely that the server implementors would fail if they can't find it

[03:02:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I agree that it should go in a request header that is only sent by WebSocet

[03:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
er *WebSocket

[03:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think I will ask abarth for his opinion on these issues

[03:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
both whether the attacks I described are worth worrying about, and whether a nonce mechanism would be an effective defense

[03:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
one of my concerns with requiring that authors read the handshake is that one of the advantages of them NOT reading the handshake is they won't just echo back the origin

[03:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm worried that authors will just do that instead of echoing back only their own origin

[03:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
servers that accept connections from multiple origins actually *do* have to do that, after checking the origin, but you are right that it may affect the likelihood of making a mistake in the single-origin case

[03:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
though of course you could write the server-side algorithms to say otherwise (i.e. have different ones for single-origin and multi-origin case, where the former only sends the fixed allowed origin after separately comparing it to the handshake origin)

[03:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's more or less what the spec does

[03:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
the parsing is in a separate (later) section

[03:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
people using stock tools for this (like mod_pywebsocket) might be less likely to make that mistake, if the framework asks you to declare allowed origins to it up front

[03:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
then the framework could make sure to both check against your list and echo back

[03:20:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess the main risk there would be if the framework has an "allow any origin" mode, authors might switch that on inadvertantly

[03:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
or indeed if they default to that :-)

[03:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
given how easy it is to write a websocket server, i don't know how much point there is to a websocket framework really

[03:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
(not having to parse the header is a big part of that)

[03:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
well, if you want something that operates on a large scale, you probably need some sort of framework, even if not for parsing the header

[03:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway - frameworks should probably either default to failing if you don't specify allowed origins, or default to allowing the same origin as the WEb sever they are running inside, if their purpose is to share a host:port with an existing web server

[03:26:00.0000] <hsivonen>
what's blocking bytes in JS?

[03:26:01.0000] <annevk>
TC39

[03:26:02.0000] <annevk>
doh

[03:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: btw, re having acks in the protocol, it's relatively easy to add them at the application level, but it turns out to be much harder to add them at the websocket level. Basically all you need is to number your messages, and tell the server what the last message was you got when you reconnect.

[03:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: but if you do that at the websocket level, you've no way to know if the script _actually_ received the message

[03:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: right - I'm wondering what the practical benefit (if any) would be of doing it at the websocket level

[03:33:02.0000] <othermaciej>
obviously, at the websocket level you could only generate transport-level acks, not guarantee actual end-to-end delivery to the app at either end

[03:33:03.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[03:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
one thing that would help is having a flag in the onclose event to say whether it was an orderly close or not

[03:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm wondering if a clean shutdown handshake is something that benefits from being at the protocol level

[03:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
TCP already does that for us, no?

[03:34:03.0000] <othermaciej>
it sounds like if you don't use one at the app level, you have to do the same kind of "lingering close" dance as HTTP servers, or you may lose mssages

[03:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
some of the content on the thread implies that the TCP close handshake is broken, and http servers have to work around it in crazy ways

[03:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I do not have enough expertise to check the accuracy of those claims

[03:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
obviously you can do a close handshake at the subprotocol level if you want, but if every subprotocol has to do it to be remotely correct, then maybe it should be in the base protocol

[03:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
i guess i'd have to understand the use case better

[03:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
to have an opinion

[03:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
apparently, if you just do a normal close of your socket when you are done sending, in some cases it can make the client drop data that it has already ACKd at the TCP level

[03:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
in other words, you might lose the last few messages even if there is no actual disruption of service

[03:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Web servers do something crazy that I don't understand to work around this

[03:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it would be nice if protocol reliability could just rely on TCP-level acks, but besides the close issue, there's the problem that OS TCP stacks apparently don't expose how much has been ACK'd

[03:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
which seems like a waste...

[03:39:01.0000] <othermaciej>
TCP is supposed to provide a reliable stream, but the next level up has to reinvent reliability

[03:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
wait, back up

[03:39:03.0000] <Hixie>
who's closing?

[03:39:04.0000] <Hixie>
client or server?

[03:39:05.0000] <othermaciej>
the server

[03:39:06.0000] <Hixie>
and why?

[03:39:07.0000] <Hixie>
ah

[03:39:08.0000] <othermaciej>
the server has sent the final message it intends to

[03:39:09.0000] <othermaciej>
closes the socket

[03:39:10.0000] <othermaciej>
that can make the client lose the last few messages

[03:39:11.0000] <Hixie>
so the server thinks it's done but it wants to make sure it gets all the client's messages?

[03:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(apparently)

[03:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
well there's no way to do that except at the application layer, since you don't know what the app wants to send but hasn't sent yet

[03:40:02.0000] <othermaciej>
not messages from the client

[03:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
what people claim is this:

[03:40:04.0000] <othermaciej>
- the server sends some messages to the client

[03:40:05.0000] <othermaciej>
- the server gets TCP-level ACKs

[03:40:06.0000] <othermaciej>
- the server closes the socket

[03:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
in this case, TCP requirements can cause the client to forcibly drop the last few messages

[03:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
oh i see

[03:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and you have to do some "lingering close" trick to avoid it

[03:41:03.0000] <Hixie>
wow, really?

[03:41:04.0000] <Hixie>
that's, ah, stupid

[03:41:05.0000] <Hixie>
how about we fix TCP

[03:41:06.0000] <othermaciej>
it sounds like a huge bug in TCP to me

[03:41:07.0000] <othermaciej>
but I think "fix TCP" is out of the range of the practical

[03:41:08.0000] <annevk>
someone asked about TCP5 from us

[03:42:00.0000] <foolip>
Hixie: cool, glad you enjoyed it

[03:42:01.0000] <annevk>

[03:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:49:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[03:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:50:01.0000] <foolip>

[03:50:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[03:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: btw, the two framing types is a result of targetting novice authors. SPDY is intended to be implemented by experts only.

[03:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: also, it's really easy to do multiplexing if your subprotocol supports it, just use a shared worker

[03:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: at this point I'm a little frightened of the thought of novice authors implementing the protocol by hand - I really hope people make good frameworks for Perl/Python/Ruby/Java/etc

[04:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
why?

[04:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
the protocol is trivial

[04:00:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems like there are many opportunities for subtle mistakes, when you dig into the details

[04:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
i've tried to minimise those

[04:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
obviously it's impossible to make a protocol idiot-proof, but it's a lot harder to screw up than most

[04:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's easier to make an API (more) idiot-proof than a protocol, so I hope people do so

[04:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
for multiplexing, yes, you could have clients coordinate via a SharedWorker or a shared iframe

[04:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it also seems to me that transparent multiplexing could be added down the line (between the UA and the server, invisible to the JS client code)

[04:04:01.0000] <othermaciej>
since the handshakes allow custom headers, and since you could introduce new frame types

[04:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
yes, indeed

[04:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
voluntary multiplexing also doesn't work if your clients might be running from different origins

[04:05:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but sharing a connection in such a case is scarier security-wise

[04:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>
bugs in doing framing become much more severe issues

[04:05:03.0000] <Hixie>
well, shared workers will be cross-origin capable in due course

[04:05:04.0000] <Hixie>
which would solve that issue

[04:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think transparent multiplexing would be cool, but it seems to me that it could be a 2.0 feature if deployment experience with WebSocket shows it is useful

[04:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
indeed

[04:06:02.0000] <othermaciej>
likewise for transparent compression

[04:06:03.0000] <othermaciej>
or whatever

[04:06:04.0000] <Hixie>
yup

[04:08:00.0000] <annevk>

[04:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: seems like the orderly close could be done easily just by having an echo feature of some kind

[04:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: either at the application level or in WS itself if we wanted to require all implementations to do it

[04:53:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: echo feature?

[04:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah where the side that wants to close the connection sends a packet saying "this is close attempt X" for some value of X, and the other side replies "close X", and if the first side receives a "close X" with the value of X that it sent, and it still thinks it wants to close, then it closes.

[04:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
without lingering.

[04:56:00.0000] <annevk>
but the side that sends close X does not know when it can close?

[04:56:01.0000] <annevk>
because wasn't the concern that if it closes to early "close X" would not arrive

[04:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
the side that sends close X will know it can close when the other side closes.

[05:00:00.0000] <annevk>
in that case one side could just do the closing attempt right?

[05:00:01.0000] <annevk>
no need for confirmation

[05:00:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Then there might be data lost in transmission

[05:02:00.0000] <annevk>
A says close, B closes on arrival of that message, A knows B closed

[05:02:01.0000] <annevk>
so A can close

[05:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Hixie's example said "and it still thinks it wants to close", though.

[05:05:01.0000] <Dashiva>
I guess that might not be a necessary step

[05:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i guess you could just do it that way

[05:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
actually no

[05:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
you need the two-way handshake

[05:06:02.0000] <zcorpan>
hmm looks like tests that i wrote 4 years ago have the same style as tests i write today

[05:06:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I believe that would be a fine orderly close mechanism, but I don't understand the TCP issue super well

[05:06:04.0000] <Hixie>
otherwise if A says to "close" to B, and B sends data to A then closes, B wouldn't see what A said

[05:06:05.0000] <Hixie>
er

[05:06:06.0000] <Hixie>
A wouldn't see what B siad

[05:06:07.0000] <zcorpan>

[05:07:00.0000] <annevk>
Hixie, good point

[05:07:01.0000] <annevk>
you win :)

[05:07:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: the reason I think it should be considered for the base protocol is that WebSocket is broken for any app-level protocol where you don't do this

[05:07:03.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: depends on the protocol

[05:07:04.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: not just "no acks" broken but "might gratuitously lose data even though everything seemed fine" broken

[05:08:00.0000] <annevk>
zcorpan, heh

[05:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: if the server is just sending a stream of updates "stock AAPL up $1" "stock MSFT up $5" etc, then you don't care about lost packets

[05:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: it very much depends on the subprotocol

[05:08:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: if the server initiated the close, then it seems wasteful for the server to order the client to discard the last few packets

[05:08:04.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: even if the client being a few messages out of date might not be a critical problem

[05:09:00.0000] <zcorpan>
6 out of 8 have been fixed from http://zcorpan.1go.dk/test/opera-bugs/

[05:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
agreed

[05:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
in that case the client would close

[05:09:03.0000] <Hixie>
not the server

[05:09:04.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: it seems like that is what's happening with this TCP issue - not just that you don't know for sure what got delivered, but that you are actually telling the client to discard data that it already received

[05:09:05.0000] <annevk>
you could put it in the base protocol and allow the server to close regardless if it doesn't care

[05:09:06.0000] <Hixie>
but the client wouldn't want an orderly close, especially if e.g. the websocket object is already GCed

[05:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
if we can come up with some thing simple enough that can be ignored if the server doesn't need it, it makes sense to add it to the base protocol

[05:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I actually don't know the bare minimum required for a proper orderly close handshake over TCP

[05:11:01.0000] <annevk>
it seems you could just use the highest byte as a special closing message

[05:11:02.0000] <annevk>
that needs to be returned

[05:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[07:00:00.0000] <zcorpan>
"Markup conformance requirements that need to be tested and give them a stable identifier that will persist across drafts of the specification." - http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/NOTE-test-methodology-20100128/

[07:02:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me wonders how many thousands of distinct conformance requirements there are in HTML5.

[07:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
That's easy, just use the text of the conformance requirement as the identifier

[07:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess if the text changes, you've changed the conformance requirement anyway . . .

[07:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: I counted 223 requirement statements for <canvas> a while ago

[07:05:01.0000] <Philip`>
so there's going to be quite a lot across the whole spec

[07:05:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lots

[07:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
(I suppose it's more about testable points than about conformance requirements)

[07:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
There are what, like 8,000 tests for CSS2.1?  And HTML5 is how much longer, twenty times as long?

[07:08:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
:/

[07:09:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me is ballparking

[07:09:01.0000] <annevk>
last estimate was 50000 tests needed

[07:09:02.0000] <annevk>
maybe that was optimistic

[07:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
HTML5 has lots of features, many different facets to test for each, very detailed requirements for most of them, and some nontrivial interactions among different features

[07:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so probably the level of test coverage needed is even higher than comparison of length to CSS would imply

[07:11:01.0000] <othermaciej>
though to be fair, CSS is also pretty damn complicated

[07:11:02.0000] <annevk>
CSS is prolly more complicated

[07:11:03.0000] <annevk>
most of HTML5 is written in a pretty straightforward way

[07:11:04.0000] <annevk>
CSS has very complex interactions

[07:11:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
You couldn't test a lot of HTML5 requirements in a cross-browser way, could you?  You'd need something more like Mozilla's mochitests, that can synthesize input and whatnot.

[07:11:06.0000] <othermaciej>
CSS has some very complex interactions by design

[07:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
HTML5 has a fair number of complex interactions by accident of history

[07:12:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there are many HTML requirements that would be hard to test if the browser itself is your only test tool

[07:12:02.0000] <othermaciej>
that doesn't mean you can't do it in a cross-browser way

[07:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
How would you do it, then?  Except manually, of course.

[07:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me doesn't want to see anyone try running 100,000 tests manually :P

[07:13:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[07:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
people have made such tools that work with any given browser, for example for testing Web sites or for general QA of any native application with a GUI

[07:14:01.0000] <zcorpan>
i generated about 15000 tests for a css feature

[07:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Generated"?

[07:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[07:15:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[00:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
foolip, unfortunately, RFC 2426 isn't entirely clear. :-( It states:

[00:42:01.0000] <Lachy>
   Type special note: The structured type value corresponds, in

[00:42:02.0000] <Lachy>
   sequence, to the Family Name, Given Name, Additional Names, Honorific

[00:42:03.0000] <Lachy>
   Prefixes, and Honorific Suffixes. The text components are separated

[00:42:04.0000] <Lachy>
   by the SEMI-COLON character (ASCII decimal 59). Individual text

[00:42:05.0000] <Lachy>
   components can include multiple text values (e.g., multiple

[00:42:06.0000] <Lachy>
   Additional Names) separated by the COMMA character

[00:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
It doesn't explicitly specify which fields allow multiple values and which cannot, suggesting they all cane. Although with it using the plural of Additional Names, Honorific Prefixes and Suffixes, suggesting that it's only those 3 that can.

[00:44:01.0000] <Lachy>
s/cane/can/

[00:44:02.0000] <jgraham>
But it has the character names in all caps!

[00:44:03.0000] <jgraham>
What could be clearer than that

[00:44:04.0000] <jgraham>
?

[00:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
I do know someone here in Norway with 2 first names and 2 last names, and she insists that they're not middle names even though they're not hyphenated. So I'm inclined to say that all fields can contain multiple values.

[01:06:00.0000] <virtuelv>
Lachy: that person would be wrong

[01:06:01.0000] <virtuelv>
unless hyphenated, the last name is one word only

[01:06:02.0000] <virtuelv>
you can have as many first and middle names as you want

[01:09:00.0000] <virtuelv>
§ 7. Doble etternavn 

[01:09:01.0000] <virtuelv>
       To navn som kan tas som etternavn, kan tas som et dobbelt etternavn der de to navnene er satt sammen med bindestrek. I forhold til §§ 3 og 4 regnes et dobbelt etternavn som to adskilte etternavn.

[01:10:00.0000] <virtuelv>
§ 7 Doble surname

[01:10:01.0000] <virtuelv>
       Two names that can be taken as a last name, can be taken as a double last name, where the two names are put together with a hyphen. In relation to § § 3 and 4 is considered a double last name as two separate surnames.

[01:10:02.0000] <virtuelv>
From http://www.lovdata.no/all/tl-20020607-019-002.html

[01:10:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:10:04.0000] <virtuelv>

[01:11:00.0000] <virtuelv>

[01:11:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:11:02.0000] <virtuelv>
von Tetzchner, or von Koengisegg

[01:12:00.0000] <virtuelv>
hsivonen: this is covered by § 9

[01:12:01.0000] <virtuelv>
which says that all acceptable last names are acceptable middle names

[01:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>
virtuelv: ah. so that permits Danish names in Norway

[01:14:00.0000] <virtuelv>

[02:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
the main reason the "allow tags to be optional" camp wins the argument is that if tags are optional, youcan still write software that acts as if they're not

[02:03:01.0000] <annevk>
in fact, what comes natural is omitting stuff :)

[02:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
but if they're not optional, you can't write software that acts as if they are

[02:03:03.0000] <Hixie>
so it's a simple tradeoff

[02:03:04.0000] <workmad3>
omitting tags isn't a problem, as long as you follow the spec wrt what tags can have their close omitted

[02:03:05.0000] <Hixie>
one way, you can get both behaviours, the other way you can only get one

[02:03:06.0000] <Hixie>
2>1

[02:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:13:01.0000] <hsivonen>
qfox: now it looks like scoping is right

[02:14:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:14:01.0000] <hsivonen>
qfox: so you can't just wish this stuff awy

[02:14:02.0000] <hsivonen>
away even

[02:14:03.0000] <zcorpan>
the trailing stray </p> will actually be parsed as <p></p>

[02:15:00.0000] <qfox>

[14:52:00.0000] <jgraham>
What is upposed to happen if I delete an index property from a CanvasPixelArray?

[14:52:01.0000] <jgraham>
*supposed

[14:54:00.0000] <jgraham>
I can't see anything special in the spec which suggests it works like an ordinary js object i.e. the property gets removed 

[14:56:00.0000] <jgraham>
But I wonder if that is detrimental to performance

[15:00:00.0000] <jgraham>
(Needless to say cross browser compatibility here is negligible, but Opera, Safari and Chrome seem to agree that properties should not be deleted by 'delete' even though Chrome and Safari return 'true' for the delete operation. Also Safari doesn't seem to support hasOwnProperty on the CanvasPixelArray)

[15:02:00.0000] <Dashiva>
jgraham: There's no deleter operator on the interface, so delete wouldn't do anything (unless there was a real JS property to delete)

[15:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: Interesting. But why does an index property not count as a real property? It returns true for hasOwnProperty?

[15:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
s/?//

[15:04:00.0000] <KevinMarks>

[15:05:00.0000] <roc>

[15:05:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:05:02.0000] <roc>

[15:05:03.0000] <jgraham>

[15:05:04.0000] <Hixie>

[15:07:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[15:08:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:10:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[15:10:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[01:28:02.0000] <othermaciej>
filed http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=8869

[01:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:29:01.0000] <Hixie>

[01:29:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it also doesn't accept keyboard input

[01:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I am not sure what other security risks people are worried about

benefits of new object:

[01:40:04.0000] <annevk>

[01:40:05.0000] <annevk>

[01:40:06.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:40:07.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:41:03.0000] <othermaciej>
but that wouldn't remove API, just add more restrictions

[05:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:58:01.0000] <Philip`>

[05:58:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[05:58:03.0000] <Philip`>

[05:58:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:58:05.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:59:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
hsivonen, http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Validator.nu_alt_advice?action=render

[06:00:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
hsivonen, you can also fetch wikitext and then feed it back as strings to api.php to get a parsed version.

[06:00:02.0000] <hsivonen>
AryehGregor: ooh. nice. thanks

[06:00:03.0000] <MikeSmithX>
AryehGregor: whatever form of XML output is the most guaranteed to not change again in the future

[06:01:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:01:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
MikeSmithX, API formats are quite stable, as far as I know.  That's really their whole purpose in life.

[06:01:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
hsivonen, well, you could remove it altogether by adding __NOTOC__ somewhere on the page.  If you only want the bot to not get it, then not that I can think of, no.

[06:01:03.0000] <MikeSmithX>
good to hear, if that's an actual policy

[06:02:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:02:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm sure that could be easily added.

[06:07:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:07:03.0000] <MikeSmithX>
I think what I had wanted to do before was, given a section title, return just the content of that section

[06:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:08:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:08:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:09:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:09:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:09:03.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:09:04.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What info are you getting out of the HTML?

[06:10:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:10:02.0000] <hsivonen>
AryehGregor: the stuff between the headings

[06:10:03.0000] <MikeSmithX>
ah yeah

[06:10:04.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:11:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:11:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:12:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:12:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:12:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:12:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm not clear what sort of HTML you want.

[06:13:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:14:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:14:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:15:01.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:15:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:15:03.0000] <hsivonen>
AryehGregor: any change that introduces or deletes markup between the end of a section and the heading for the next section

[06:15:04.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:16:00.0000] <hsivonen>
or that introduces markup between the heading of a section and the section content

[06:16:01.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:25:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>

[06:25:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
There are two options for what sort of HTML to output: 1) whatever happens to lie between the section tags in the actual page, and 2) what you get by running the section's wikitext through the parser (which will strip mismatched tags and such).

[06:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:26:01.0000] <hsivonen>
#2

[06:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

ah

[17:08:00.0000] <tantek>

[17:08:01.0000] <tantek>

[17:09:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:10:00.0000] <tantek>

[17:10:01.0000] <Hixie>

[17:12:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:12:01.0000] <Hixie>

[18:30:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, sorry I didn't see your q re: vcard/n til now

[18:32:00.0000] <tantek>
Much of the "optimizations" for n (and fn and others) were design/built to bridge the impedance mismatch/gap between the way people author content (only what they have to / seems obvious), and the strict top-down a-priori requirements of various formats.

[18:33:00.0000] <tantek>
given the years of experience we've had with hCard (and n and fn uses), there's definitely been a few cases where some optimizations can be dropped, others can be improved/refined, and there's room for a few more too (again, based on experience with what authors have tried to do with hCard)

[18:33:01.0000] <tantek>
I've captured much of this in hcard-brainstorming for hCard 1.0.1 (and similarly for hCalendar)

[18:34:00.0000] <tantek>
essentially all such "optimizations" come down to making the vocabularies more *usable*

[18:34:01.0000] <tantek>
anyway - feel free to jump into #microformats for more on hCard/vcard/n/fn etc.

[18:35:00.0000] <tantek>
btw on another topic (which was mentioned above)

[18:35:01.0000] <tantek>
http://bemasc.net/wordpress/2010/02/02/no-you-cant-do-that-with-h264/

[18:36:00.0000] <tantek>
the video codec situ seems quite messy

[18:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: k. sounds like it would be reasonable for the microdata version to just say that a blank N is generated if it's missing, then, with no special magic to generate it from FN, NICK, and ORG like hCard

[18:44:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, there are probably some cases where a blank n *should* be generated from fn, nickname, org etc., even in hCard

[18:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
how do you mean?

[18:46:00.0000] <tantek>
that is there are some cases where hCard auto-generates a value for the 'n' property when it should probably generate an empty 'n' property

[18:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
ah i see

[18:47:01.0000] <tantek>
I'm going to have to another round of tests with modern vcard consumers to understand the impact of various combinations of implying a blank 'n' vs an 'n' with a non-empty value.

[18:47:02.0000] <tantek>
to have to *do* another

[18:47:03.0000] <Hixie>
k

[18:47:04.0000] <Hixie>
i have to say, one has to love how the vcard spec just says that N is required

[18:48:00.0000] <tantek>
don't get me started

[18:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
without saying how you're supposed to determine its value if it's unknown

[18:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
Atom does the same thing

[18:48:03.0000] <tantek>
Atom is actually much worse

[18:48:04.0000] <Hixie>
a bunch of things are required, but there's no suggestion of what to do when they're unknown

[18:48:05.0000] <tantek>
so many really bad MUSTs on content authoring

[18:48:06.0000] <tantek>
and so many bad requirements for artificial precision - e.g. RFC3339

[18:49:00.0000] <tantek>
e.g. forcing you to specify :00 seconds, even if you don't know/have a value for it from the content/data/authoring

[18:49:01.0000] <tantek>
forced artificial precision = antipattern

[18:49:02.0000] <tantek>
another case of, mandating the author to provide a value for something doesn't mean that you actually get meaningful content for it

[18:50:00.0000] <tantek>
I'm sure you can list examples from the HTML spec for that ;)

[18:50:01.0000] <tantek>
*HTML4*

[18:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
actually html4 doesn't do that much

[18:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
mostly because it requires so little of anything...

[18:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
kinda the opposite problem :-P

[03:46:00.0000] <annevk>

[04:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: it's dom-window-x when i add new things after 2008, it's dom-x when i add new things before 2008. More or less.

[04:11:01.0000] <annevk>
fun

[04:11:02.0000] <Hixie>
(though i'm sure there's lots of exceptions either way)

[04:11:03.0000] <annevk>
more fun

[04:12:00.0000] <annevk>

[04:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, that's more or less the same

[04:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
these days i try to be consistent with the actual case, so that search and replace is easier

[04:13:00.0000] <annevk>
mkay

[04:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
even more inconsistent is how i deal with concepts and algorithms

[04:14:01.0000] <annevk>
fair enough, though at some point we should try to get some consistency if we want this multi-spec cross-linking thing to work

[04:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[04:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
agreed

[04:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
my recommendation would be to leave what we have now as is, but that going forward we use:

[04:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
dom-InterfaceName-attributeOrMethodName

[04:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
event-eventname

[04:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
elementname

[04:17:04.0000] <Hixie>
attr-elementname-attributename

[04:17:05.0000] <Hixie>
dom-elementname-attributeOrMethodName

[04:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
concept-word

[04:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
InterfaceName

[04:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
and just use the whole string for long algorithm names

[04:18:03.0000] <Hixie>
does that work for you?

[04:18:04.0000] <annevk>
yeah, that's more or less what I use

[04:19:00.0000] <Hixie>

TabAtkins, it's not misleading because no one is saying that pirated software is literally a crime of piracy.  It's an extension of the word by analogy.

[07:35:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And you don't need the Supreme Court to tell you that copyright infringement is not theft under U.S. law, just look at the definitions in the relevant statutes.

[07:35:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it can still be called "theft" in a loose, non-legal sense.

[07:35:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: You're naive - people *do* think that actual piracy, as in murder-on-the-high-seas, is precisely what is talked about when talking heads on the news go on about the latest efforts by the RIAA to stop software piracy.

[07:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:36:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:36:08.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:36:09.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:37:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:37:01.0000] <foolip>

[07:37:02.0000] <foolip>
doesn't really say much, though

[07:37:03.0000] <Philip`>
(Not a single person for all things, they'd get very confused)

[07:37:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, but if you can prove that one person does without expending exorbitant resources, it's likely that a *significant* number of people do.

[07:37:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Same thing with using "theft", except probably worse.  *Many* more people believe that infringement is literal theft, because of people using that word to describe it.

[07:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Which makes it *enormously* more difficult to teach them about infinite goods and how they violate expectations based on a scarcity economy.

[07:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It is arguably literal theft in a non-legal sense.

[07:39:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And worse, how to *benefit* from the ways in which infinite goods are different.

[07:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
"To take (the property of another) without right or permission."

[07:39:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:39:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me sighs

[07:39:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
To take, sure.  Who's taking anything?

[07:39:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
You're construing the meaning of all these words very narrowly, according to your specific viewpoint.

[07:39:07.0000] <TabAtkins>
And who's property is being 'taken' anyway?  I'm sharing my own property with friends.

[07:39:08.0000] <Philip`>
There's lots of products where all the expense is up-front and the manufacturing cost is relatively tiny, so it's not significantly different once the manufacturing cost reaches zero

[07:40:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
s/all/most of/

[07:40:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:40:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:40:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, distribution/copying costs for software are nonzero too, they're just very low.

[07:40:05.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:41:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:41:01.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: There's not a big economic difference, so it's not like we're transitioning to a completely novel system of economics once part of the cost of a product drops a lot

[07:41:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you're convinced that filesharers are 'stealing' from you, you'll go to significant effort to stop them, instead of embracing it and using it to make more money.

[07:41:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, "theft" is not purely a legal term.  It has a less precise, nonlegal meaning as well.  And sure, the language being used is prejudiced, but you're just trying to prejudice the language used in the opposite direction.

[07:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:42:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:18:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, there seems to be a design flaw with the way sandboxed iframes work that make it largely inappropriate for some use cases.

[08:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
I realised the issue as a result of this article http://angryamoeba.co.uk/singlecell/2010/01/15/html5-video-and-custom-players.html

[08:20:00.0000] <Lachy>
Use case: For embedding a custom video player from a video site like YouTube, where the iframe's content page handles all the issues like <source> selection, custom player controls, etc. It's useful to have a simple, copy and pasteable piece of markup for authors to use in their own pages

[08:22:00.0000] <Lachy>
but using <iframe src="http://youtube.com/path/to/videoplayer.html?videoid" sandbox seamless> doesn't provide any sandboxing in legacy browsers

[08:23:00.0000] <Lachy>
And being a 3rd party site, there's no way to use the text/html-sandboxed mime type and srcdoc is inappropriate here where the content needs to be served remotely

[08:24:00.0000] <boogyman>
ew @ iframe!

[08:24:01.0000] <Lachy>
That article I mentioned above says that forum software doesn't usually permit iframes to be embedded either, and it's going to be difficult to convince them to do that while there are still legacy browsers out there that would be vulnerable without sandboxing

[08:24:02.0000] <Lachy>
boogyman, there's nothing inherently wrong with an iframe. It just has a few security issues for these use cases.

[08:25:00.0000] <boogyman>
Lachy: server side includes FTW

[08:25:01.0000] <Lachy>
boogyman, and if you're trying to claim that iframe is somehow disgusting like the author of that article did, then you're argument is no good

[08:25:02.0000] <boogyman>
frames are so 1996-8

[08:25:03.0000] <Lachy>
how would server side includes address this use case at all?

[08:26:00.0000] <Lachy>
boogyman, <frameset> and <frame> are bad by design. <iframe> is not if used appropriately

[08:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lachy, plenty of forums allow whitelisted YouTube links.

[08:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like [youtube]some URL[/youtube] which regexes out the video id and outputs the right <object> boilerplate.

[08:27:00.0000] <Lachy>
in fact, even <frameset> isn't bad if used properly, though it frequently isn't and has few valid use cases

[08:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
AryehGregor, nice. But that doesn't allow other video sites to compete very easily by offering their own videos to embed in 3rd party sites

[08:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Sure, but are forums really going to whitelist <iframe seamless sandboxed>?  Maybe, but I have my doubts.  It can do a lot of things, particularly performance-wise.

[08:28:02.0000] <Lachy>
I assume they don't also have tags for [vimeo], [dailymotion], [insert-other-video-site-here], etc.

[08:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:29:01.0000] <Lachy>
that doesn't allow custom controls

[08:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So?  It'll still work.

[08:29:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe if this is your use-case, you should talk to actual forum software developers and ask what they'd allow.

[08:29:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
phpBB probably has a mailing list somewhere.

[08:30:00.0000] <workmad3>
phpBB you'd just define bbcode tags with the correct embed syntax for the sites you want to allow

[08:30:01.0000] <Lachy>
video sites like to use custom controls, their own branding and additional features like links to related videos, etc. All of these features are offered by flash, and can be replicated using <iframe>, but not with <video> alone

[08:30:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me is betting <iframe sandbox> is not going to be allowed anywhere by default without whitelisting of sites.

[08:30:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
("anywhere" meaning "in any forum software package")

[08:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:31:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Unrestricted <iframe sandbox> is kind of scary even if browsers support it.

[08:32:00.0000] <Lachy>
what's scary about it?

[08:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It allows arbitrary scripts to run on the page, just theoretically they can't do anything that actually steals data.

[08:33:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
They can use tons of CPU, for one thing, making it slow to browse.

[08:33:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Can it do alert() or other things like that?

[08:33:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If no, are you really sure you've gotten all of them?

[08:34:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Apparently no.

[08:34:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
"scripts are still prevented from creating popups"

[08:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What if they trigger an endless loop of HTTP authentications, say, in a browser where those are modal dialogs?

[08:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or any number of other obnoxious things.

[08:36:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Surely a modal dialog counts as a popup for those purposes?

[08:37:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:37:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:37:02.0000] <Lachy>

jonnybarnes, you don't have to worry about a member of the HTMLWG having undisclosed patents on anything covered by the spec, no.

[16:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
At least, not on anything necessary to implement it.

[16:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not sure how far that goes into related technologies.

should we make lang="" missing on <html> trigger a warning?

[18:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[18:12:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[18:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[18:31:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: fwiw, validator.nu already emits a warning for a similar case, which is if there's no character-encoding information given in the doc

[18:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
even if the doc is all-ascii?

[18:31:03.0000] <KevinMarks>

[18:31:04.0000] <MikeSmith>

[18:31:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: yeah, even for all-ascii, I think

[18:32:00.0000] <KevinMarks>
character encoding is not similar to language

[18:32:01.0000] <KevinMarks>
encoding is a computational construct, language is a human one

[18:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: iirc the spec has a MUST if there's no encoding and it's not ascii (and some other conditions aren't met, e.g. boms, http headers), and there's no conformance problem at all without one if it's pure ASCII

[18:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I'm not sure that it's possible to have validator.nu make a determination of whether a doc is pure ascii or not

[18:35:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it would have to sniff the entire doc, would it not?

[18:35:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Doesn't it have to do that anyway?

[18:35:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, my point was that we do have a precedent of emitting a warning for a case that's not a strict conformance error but that could lead to problems with portability of the document

[18:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[18:37:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the message it currently emits is something that it emits early in processing, by looking just at the first 512 bytes for a character-encoding declaration

[18:37:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
or for a lack of one

[18:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
yeah it would take more work to do the right thing there

[18:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it's certainly do-able, but not sure it would be worth it or not

[18:38:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that code is in the HTML parser

[18:38:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[18:38:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[06:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
othermaciej: If people find collision attacks on SHA512, I think HTML sandboxes are likely to be the least of people's concerns

[06:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Salt is helpful to make dictionary attacks n times harder where n is the number of users you're trying to attack simultaneously, and I'm not sure it's relevant here)

[06:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it would mean that even if you computed one viable attack input by brute force, it would only work when the salt value you used in generating it comes up

[06:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(which leaves you with as strong a defense as just using a good quality random number

[06:30:00.0000] <annevk>
jgraham, shouldn't browsers fix that?

[06:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you pick an arbitrary $token and then manage to find an input that hashes to that (with </sandbox token=$token> inside it), then the hash is severely broken and lots of cryptographic systems would collapse

[06:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
and I don't see how the token thing could be broken in easier ways

[06:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
and I'm happy to believe SHA512 is not severely broken enough for this to be an issue in the next decade

[06:35:00.0000] <jgraham>
annevk: Browsers are not the only UAs, you know (and not all browsers fix it)

[06:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
(...and you're not going to compute one viable attack by brute force, because there's more hash outputs than there are atoms in the universe)

[06:52:00.0000] <annevk>
why do we want <sandbox>?

[06:52:01.0000] <annevk>
what's wrong with <iframe srcdoc>?

[06:52:02.0000] <Philip`>
We probably don't

[06:52:03.0000] <othermaciej>
sure, you'd want more than 32 bits of randomness, but it doesn't really matter if you convert numbers to strings as ASCII or in some other way

[06:52:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
I still like srcdoc.  Nuts to randomness or hashing.  Just a single, trivial, quickly-and-obviously-failing escaping step is better.

[06:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
<sandbox> would have some potential advantages over <iframe srcdoc>:

[06:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
1) frames have high memory and performance overhead - a page with hundreds or thousands of iframes would likely be a bad user experience

[06:54:00.0000] <jgraham>
Oh I thought we wanted it because security is a fun new thing to argue about once we are bored with accessibility and Process

[06:54:01.0000] <Lachy>
othermaciej, if your token is just a number convered to ascii, like <sandbox-18489>, where that number is randomly generated each time the page is generated, then an attacker could insert </sandbox-25930> and get a successful attack on approximatley 1/32768 visitors

[06:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
2) if your desired fallback is content that sizes naturally in the document, then it's hard to use <iframe> at all until all browsers support seamless iframes

[06:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(i.e if you are using sandboxing in combination with server-side sanitization for defense in depth)

[06:55:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: By the time @sandbox and @srcdoc are supported properly, @seamless should be too.

[06:55:03.0000] <annevk>
it seems it would be even harder to use <sandbox> othermaciej

[06:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not saying it's better overall, just listing the possible advantages

[06:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it has some disadvantages too

[06:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
there's no obvious way to do <sandbox allow-script>

[06:56:03.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: If your token is based on a number between 0 and 32767 converted to a long randomised string by applying sha512() to it, you'll have the same problem

[06:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[14:42:05.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:42:06.0000] <Johnny__>

[14:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
But if you need to style things more specifically, certainly use classes and ids.

[15:01:00.0000] <Johnny__>
Do you style the section tag in css after declaring it as a block element?

[15:01:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If necessary?

[15:02:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's just like any other element.

[15:02:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I just feed it the IE shim and the quick block declaration for current-browser compatibility, then style it as I would any other element.

[15:02:02.0000] <Johnny__>
I've read an article saying that section is not for that and should use div instead.

[15:02:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think you misinterpreted the article.

[15:03:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
<section> is not meant to be used *solely* as a styling hook.

[15:03:01.0000] <zcorpan>
1280x800 is more common than 1024x768

[15:03:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That is, if you need an element *only* to hang styles on.  <div> is appropriate there.

[15:03:03.0000] <Johnny__>
I'm talking about the html5doctor.com's article on how to use the section tag.

[15:03:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, I suspected you meant that article.  That's not what they meant.

[15:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The rule is to just make sure that you're using <section> properly for its semantics, just like you should use all elements properly for their semantics.

[15:04:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
After that, style away.

[15:07:00.0000] <Johnny__>
I think I'm still a bit confused as to when should one use section and when should one use article.

[15:10:00.0000] <Johnny__>
<section><h1>title</h1><article>content</article></section> Is this wrong?

[15:16:00.0000] <Johnny__>

[15:17:00.0000] <Johnny__>
Now I understand. 

[15:20:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[15:25:00.0000] <Johnny__>
Thanks TabAtkins, and zcorpan

[15:33:00.0000] <zcorpan>
nn

[15:36:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Johnny__: The difference between <section> and <article> is somewhat subtle, but there's an easy rule-of-thumb to tell them apart.

[15:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Use <section> whenever it would be appropriate to put a heading on the stuff you're enclosing (even if you don't actually end up putting one there).

[15:37:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Use <article> when you have something that could be a <section>, but would also be appropriate to link directly to, or to view by itself.

[15:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
That rule-of-thumb helps capture the "independent content" semantic that <article> has.

[15:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Basically if it would be useful to link to a page that had *nothing* on it but the content of the <article>, then <article> is appropriate.

[15:46:00.0000] <Johnny__>
I see. 

[15:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Frex, I have a CMS with multiple tabs, one for each segment of my application.  Each tab is an <article>, because it would make sense to have them on a separate page (though I happen to collect them on a single page for convenience).

[15:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think using <article> or <section> for applications typically makes sense

[15:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I mean, look at the GMail UI, almost none of the logical groupings of UI elements have anything resembling a header

[15:51:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Eh, works for me.  Helps to delineate major sections of the app (using <article>) from minor sections (using <section>).

[15:51:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
They certainly *could* have a header.

[15:51:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the only thing that might be an <article> is an individual email message

[15:51:04.0000] <othermaciej>
they *could* but they don't

[15:51:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
They don't, because it's obvious from context.  But it wouldn't be weird to add one.

[15:52:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.  Presentational details like that shouldn't affect the semantics of the element.

[15:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't see any reasonable way to decide which groupings in the UI should be <section>s and which should be <div>s

[15:52:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Just use the guideline I just said.

[15:52:03.0000] <othermaciej>
<section> is a concept that makes sense for documents but not as much for applications

[15:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I agree, though, that the major sections of GMail should be <section>, and email messages should be <article>s.

[15:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you were explaining the difference between <section> and <article>, but that doesn't really clarify the difference between <section> and <div> in an app context

[15:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sure.  The differernce is that <div> just groups things for some arbitrary reason, usually for styling or scripting purposes.  <section> groups them according to a logical division of the doc/app, with the "heading" rule of thumb helping to determine what's an appropriate "logical grouping".

[15:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That just keeps you from overthinking things and over-dividing the app.

[15:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Like, say, the Labels panel in the GMail ui - individual labels, with their color spot, would probably be <div>s.  It's not appropriate to use <section> there, because you wouldn't put a heading on individual labels.

[15:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though, if you were on a label-centric page with a lot of info on each label, then it would be appropriate.

[15:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Same as how, frex, a group of ledes for blog posts on a blog home page should just be <div>s, but a group of full posts (or perhaps truncated posts with a "Read More" link) are appropriate for <article>.

[15:57:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
<div> or <li> or something, that is.


2010-02-09

[01:46:04.0000] <annevk>

[01:47:00.0000] <annevk>

[01:47:01.0000] <annevk>

[01:47:02.0000] <Hixie>

[01:47:03.0000] <annevk>

[01:47:04.0000] <Hixie>

[01:49:00.0000] <Hixie>

[01:49:02.0000] <Hixie>

[03:27:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[03:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: nice, thanks

[03:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, or not, maybe

[03:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that's just giving the raw wikitext, right?

[03:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[03:36:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I'm discovering that once you have a workspace that you've used with a newer version svn client, you can't then go back to using that workspace with an older version of an svn client

[03:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
gsnedders: what makes you sigh about them?

[03:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: once you've boiled the ocean, retiling your floor is no big deal

[03:38:02.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: Well, basically, we have interop on behaviour of \09 and \9, but because the comittiee doesn't like octal escape sequences, we're just going to make them illegal.

[03:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, it gives you wikitext.  As discussed, it's not obvious what HTML output would be correct.  You can feed it back with action=parse: http://wiki.whatwg.org/api.php?action=parse&title=Validator.nu+alt+advice&text=''Foo''

[03:39:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(you might want to POST if you're using lots of text, I guess)

[03:39:02.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/es5-discuss/2010-February/003491.html

[03:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
gsnedders: what does it mean to make them "illegal"? will the required behavior for \07 change, or will it be mandatory to reject it, or will it just be "undefined"?

[03:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there's not even a surface-level ECMAScript conformance checker so it's hard to say what is illegal for the language

[03:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(I think maybe there should at least be a checker to verify that your program is correct syntax per the ECMAScript grammar, even though that wouldn't catch many other kinds of undefined constructs)

[03:42:00.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: Per spec, "\07" does not meet the grammar, except if you allow octals (defined in appendix B). "\08" equally does not match the grammar.

[03:42:01.0000] <gsnedders>
The problem is the latter case

[03:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I see, so pseudo-octal is the problem?

[03:42:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Everything treats that as \x008

[03:42:04.0000] <gsnedders>
OR octal-followed by non-octal

[03:42:05.0000] <othermaciej>
and by "problem" I mean not part of the defined grammar and behavior not defined

[03:43:00.0000] <gsnedders>
The grammar uses lookaheads to forbid it

[03:43:01.0000] <gsnedders>
So yeah, behaviour is undefined

[03:43:02.0000] <othermaciej>
gsnedders: if Brendan thinks it's not used on the Web, I kinda wish he would test that with the Mozilla code before failing to spec t

[03:43:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Whereas if the lookaheads asserting != OctalDigit and not != DecimalDigit, it would match the spec

[03:44:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me sends email asking when they intend to change Gecko

[03:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
othermaciej, surely you could write a decent ECMAScript validator by just adding extra code to normal JS engines, which (maybe optionally) raise a warning whenever they hit spec violations?

[03:48:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, it wouldn't be perfect, but it would catch errors that were actually hit at runtime.

[03:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: the word "just" in your question contains a large assumption

[03:49:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That it would be easy to do that?

[03:50:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, you could presumably offer to raise warnings for at least *some* conformance requirements.

[03:50:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Even if most would be hard to check for.

[03:50:02.0000] <othermaciej>
JavaScriptCore couldn't even easily be used to check the syntax level, since we support many extensions

[03:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so step 1 would be rewriting the tokenizer and parser to remove all grammar extensions

[03:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Shouldn't those extensions raise warnings as spec violations if used?

[03:51:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess it's not quite that simple.

[03:51:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it's doable in principle.  Gecko is rewriting its HTML parser right now for spec compliance, right?

[03:51:04.0000] <gsnedders>
/me thinks it would be non-trivial even in Carakan without us supporting many extensions

[03:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Just depends on how much people want it.

[03:52:01.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: That doesn't throw warnings on parse errors

[03:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
gsnedders, well, no.  It's not meant to.
