[07:02:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"I'm not so concerned about implementers, I'm concerned about people reading just HTML5 and concluding that the spec requires sniffing"

[07:02:01.0000] <Dashiva>
What is the danger here?

[07:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You mean, like, what could happen if an author were to somehow read that and gain that impression?

[07:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
Users might decide that since the spec requires sniffing, it's safe for them to produce content that relies on sniffing

[07:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
and that would harm the UAs that don't sniff

[07:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
The one user doing that seems rather insignificant compared with the thousands of users who don't read the spec, but produce content that requires sniffing anyhow

[07:06:00.0000] <annevk>
if users read the spec there would be no need for sniffing

[07:06:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Dashiva: you could point that out in the bug

[07:06:02.0000] <Philip`>
That's still one user who would benefit from the spec being clear that sniffing is not required (from which they infer that they can't rely on sniffing)

[07:06:03.0000] <annevk>
because HTTP requires UAs to adhere to the Content-Type currently

[07:06:04.0000] <Philip`>
(and hence they will produce content that works in more UAs, so everyone wins)

[07:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
so it's better than nothing

[07:07:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: UAs that don't sniff would still be in an equally bad position

[07:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
They'd be in a marginally better position, and the author would be in a wider marginally better position

[07:08:01.0000] <Philip`>
and the HTML5 spec is a collection of tens of thousands of things that each make the world only a tiny bit better

[07:08:02.0000] <Dashiva>
If the author cared about UAs that didn't sniff, he wouldn't make content that relies on sniffing

[07:09:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
On the other hand, if he thinks that all UAs are required to sniff, then he might not care about ones that don't, as they're non-conformant in his eyes.

[07:09:01.0000] <Philip`>
If he reads just HTML5 and concludes the spec requires sniffing, then he is more likely to believe there are no UAs that don't sniff

[07:10:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Surely not

[07:10:01.0000] <Dashiva>
If he cares about UAs that don't sniff, then he knows about them

[07:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
That seems untrue

[07:11:01.0000] <Philip`>
I care a bit about people who visit my sites in browsers I've never even heard of

[07:11:02.0000] <Philip`>
and search engine crawlers I've never heard of

[07:11:03.0000] <Philip`>
etc

[07:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
so I want to make content that is likely to work for them, even if I don't know any details about them

[07:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
and to some extent I do that based on the assumption that if a spec requires something then these unknown UAs are likely to follow it

[07:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
(particularly if all desktop browser I test in follow it too)

[07:14:01.0000] <Philip`>
s//s/

[07:17:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: But that's trivially untrue, since a large amount of tools don't use HTML parsers.

[07:19:00.0000] <gsnedders>
regexp ftw!

[07:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: It's an unsafe assumption, but (in the absence of better information) it's the best assumption I can make

[07:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
I have no idea how Googlebot parses HTML but I assume that if my page is valid HTML and parses correctly in desktop browsers then probably Googlebot will parse it correctly too

[07:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
and I'll happily omit </p> and <html> tags, and write <br /> etc, based on that assumption

[07:25:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: But that changes your assumption. You aren't actually aligning with the spec, but rather with desktop browser behavior

[07:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'm aligning with the information I have available, which consists of the spec plus observable behaviour

[07:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
If they agree then I'll be reasonably confident in my assumption

[07:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
But if I conclude from reading the spec that some UAs might not have that behaviour, I'll be much more cautious about assuming it

[07:29:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, the spec says UAs don't have to support text/html, so leaving out </p> will break a class of conforming UAs

[07:30:00.0000] <zcorpan>
using text/html at all will break a class of conforming UAs (regardless of tags used)

[07:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
My available information also consists of knowledge that most implementors are not entirely insane, and therefore will attempt to support text/html

[07:31:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Equally, most implementors are not entirely insane, and will sniff as required

[07:32:00.0000] <zcorpan>
maybe they'll sniff but not exactly as required

[09:03:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[10:03:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:06:00.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: http://github.com/gsnedders/complexpie/blob/master/src/cachearray.php — fun with PHP!

[10:07:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(complete with my own very naïve GC impl within PHP!)

[10:07:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yay!

[10:08:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(basically for static variable caches within functions to avoid computing stuff all the time, and with GC to stop it from growing to really large amounts of memory)

[10:08:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(the GC is really too naive though, I expect, but it gets pretty good cache hit rates)

[10:09:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(compared with having no GC whatsoever)

[10:10:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(there again, for it to be worthwhile to still have the cache, the GC needs to be really cheap)

[10:11:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, so a helper for manually implementing memoization.  Cool.

[10:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
How does that actually cache anything?

[10:13:01.0000] <Philip`>
It looks like it's deferring to the parent all the time, and never returning anything from a cache

[10:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's an ArrayObject, which has an internal array backing.

[10:14:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And uses parent::offsetGet and parent::offsetSet to actually do the storing/retrieving.

[10:14:02.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: Yeah, basically

[10:14:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
It just wraps gc around it.

[10:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, so this code isn't actually caching anything, it's more of a SelfCleaningArray?

[10:15:01.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: Indeed, and offsetExists is deliberately not overridden to keep it quicker

[10:15:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: yeah

[10:15:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's meant for *other* things to use it for caching.

[10:15:04.0000] <gsnedders>
http://github.com/gsnedders/complexpie/blob/master/src/iri.php#L788

[10:15:05.0000] <gsnedders>
for example

[10:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
function foo(){ static $cache = new CacheArray; }

[10:16:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(it turns out doing IRI processing is amazingly expensive)

[10:16:02.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: That's invalid syntax, you can't set a new object like that

[10:16:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sure you can.

[10:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
As long as your constructor can be called with no args.

[10:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Frex, I use foreach(new UserList as $user){} all over my code.

[10:18:01.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: Parse error: syntax error, unexpected T_NEW

[10:18:02.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: That's totally different

[10:18:03.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: It's the fact it's on the RHS of a static dfn

[10:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
Seems like a weird cache eviction policy

[10:19:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you access "x" 100 times, then "y" once, then "x" 99 times, it will throw away "x" and keep "y"?

[10:19:02.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: http://pastebin.ca/1791616

[10:19:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: I said naïve for a reason

[10:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
Naive is different to stupid ;-)

[10:20:01.0000] <gsnedders>
patches welcome :)

[10:20:02.0000] <gsnedders>
(provided they don't make the getter in the general case more expensive)

[10:20:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, is that something special just for static vars?

[10:21:00.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: static and global, IIRC

[10:21:01.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: It's a property of the keywords

[10:21:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
How weird.

[10:21:03.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: Same applies for public $foo = 'bar'; in a class dfn

[10:21:04.0000] <Philip`>
LRU would probably the most common arguably-naive algorithm, I guess

[10:21:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Okay, well, I use static vars very rarely.

[10:22:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: The aim was more some fairly basic LFU

[10:23:00.0000] <gsnedders>
With a really bad LFU-aging impl

[10:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You could perhaps drop $oldaccess, and just determine what to drop based on $access.

[10:25:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Perhaps just array_slice($access,0,80) to allow young accesses to stick around.

[10:25:02.0000] <gsnedders>
I could just move over to LRU, but I don't think that's very good for what I need

[10:26:00.0000] <gsnedders>
e.g., given parsing a URL like '/', it may in general come up a lot, but in one file I get a thousand unqiue other items. I don't want to push that out of the cache

[10:27:00.0000] <gsnedders>
There's a very long tail for this from the data set I was testing with, so caching that tail doesn't gain much

[10:27:01.0000] <gsnedders>
What is important is you get the high priority things

[10:27:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Which is why I really want some sort of LFU impl

[10:27:03.0000] <Philip`>
If it comes up a lot, it will always be recently used, and you'd only push it out of the cache for the duration of that one file where it's not used

[10:27:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Okay, then just cut things based on array_count_values(

[10:27:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
$access)

[10:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
Things that are used frequently are used recently

[10:28:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: It's a question of whether I want to push it out for that one file, whether I gain anything by losing that cache

[10:28:02.0000] <Philip`>
Also, RAM is cheap so make the cache much bigger :-)

[10:28:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: PHP often runs with small memory limits

[10:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose PHP isn't clever enough to have weak references

[10:29:01.0000] <gsnedders>
It isn't, sadly.

[10:29:02.0000] <Philip`>
Does it throw an exception when you run out of memory, or just crash?

[10:29:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Exception, usually.

[10:29:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sometimes just a crash.

[10:29:05.0000] <gsnedders>
Throws E_ERROR, a non-catchable error.

[10:29:06.0000] <Philip`>
That's not so helpful

[10:30:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Indeed. The only option for keeping caches within a sane size is something like this.

[10:31:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me does still use an unbound (direct associative array) cache in one place, but where it grows to a certain size and stops growing due to the nature of the cache

[10:31:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(and where any indirection to another PHP function call is too expensive to be worthwhile even having the cache)

[12:00:00.0000] <wycats>
so why does uncredentialled CORS still require approval to make the request?

[12:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
To stop pages from arbitrarily reconfiguring the user's router on http://192.168.0.1, perhaps?

[12:01:01.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: for "simple requests" it doesn't require approval to make the request, just to read the results

[12:01:02.0000] <Philip`>
/me may be misunderstanding the question

[12:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
for non-simple requests, there is at least the risk of exposing servers behind firewalls to CSRF (beyond what is possible with cross-site form submission)

[12:06:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: why is approval required to read the requests?

[12:06:01.0000] <wycats>
without credentials == no CSRF, no?

[12:06:02.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: I'm curious why there's no "safe" API to make an HTTP request that doesn't expose any security issues

[12:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: you can't use CSRF to read a resource served from another server, whether with or without credentials

[12:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: in intranets, there are servers where the only "credential" required to access them is being behind the firewall, which is a credential XHR can't remove

[12:08:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: isn't this something UAs can handle?

[12:08:01.0000] <wycats>
and behind the firewall people can lock down the credential?

[12:09:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: in practice, this means that I can't use certain public APIs until people get around to supporting CORS :/

[12:09:01.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: what I'm saying is, there's servers behind firewalls containing confidential information that require no explicit credential to access

[12:09:02.0000] <othermaciej>
their only protection is being behind a firewall

[12:09:03.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: right... and people can already get that info by installing a native app

[12:09:04.0000] <wycats>
the way around that is permissions

[12:10:00.0000] <wycats>
so UAs can allow the "corporate security" to disallow access

[12:10:01.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: browsing to a web page in your browser should not be equivalent to installing a native app

[12:10:02.0000] <wycats>
of course not

[12:10:03.0000] <wycats>
but making an HTTP GET request is a reasonable thing to be able to do

[12:10:04.0000] <wycats>
in the vast majority of cases

[12:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and indeed the spec lets you make such a request, just not read the result unless the server opts in

[12:12:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: in general, getting the results of an HTTP request is not considered a secure transaction

[12:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
browsers enforce the same-origin security model and therefore have created the expectation that it is, in the browser context

[12:15:00.0000] <wycats>
brb

[13:49:04.0000] <wycats>

[13:49:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:49:06.0000] <wycats>

[13:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you may want to give the option of allowing access to anyone or to a whitelist, and whether to allow credentials or not

[13:50:01.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: I work with the 37 signals guys and they say "cool" to adding CORS to their Campfire API but it's not on their list

[13:50:02.0000] <zcorpan>
working around the height:auto limitation with script gets really ugly

[13:50:03.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: yeah

[13:50:04.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: Rails tends to go with 90% case first and then refine to other cases

[13:50:05.0000] <wycats>
instead of trying to preplan everything... but some additional config wouldn't be bad

[13:50:06.0000] <othermaciej>
so you're thinking the 90% case is fully public data source that takes no credentials and is open to everyone?

[13:52:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: the 90% case I think takes credentials via an API token

[13:52:01.0000] <wycats>
or basic auth

[13:52:02.0000] <wycats>
more likely an API token

[13:52:03.0000] <othermaciej>
depends on what kind of credentials you have in mind

[13:52:04.0000] <othermaciej>
if it's a resource that is somehow per-user, people may want to use cookies

[13:53:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: that's not a common case

[13:53:01.0000] <wycats>
the common case is you have an API that is available from Ruby or Java or something

[13:53:02.0000] <wycats>
via HTTP

[13:53:03.0000] <wycats>
and you want to open it up for web access

[13:53:04.0000] <othermaciej>
if for example GMail wanted to offer a contacts service as a data API

[13:53:05.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: I'd consider that the 10% case

[13:53:06.0000] <wycats>
Gmail has smart engineers

[13:53:07.0000] <othermaciej>
or flickr wanted a photostream data API

[13:53:08.0000] <wycats>
and we can converge on that case if it gets common

[13:54:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: why wouldn't an API token work for that case?

[13:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: how does an API token tell you which flickr user is logged into the browser?

[13:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
is the token per-user or is it an "app key"?

[13:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if it's per-app, then if you ship it down to the client anyone can rip it from your client-side code

[13:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if it's per user, then you need a server-to-server communication to do setup per-user

[13:55:02.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: nah it'd be stored in local storage

[13:55:03.0000] <wycats>
the user would type in their un/pw, and a call would be made to get the token

[13:55:04.0000] <othermaciej>
a call to who?

[13:55:05.0000] <wycats>
a fully open CORS service

[13:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you sure don't want the user typing their site A password into site B

[13:56:01.0000] <wycats>
ha

[13:56:02.0000] <wycats>
see: the internet :P

[13:56:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the whole point of CORS is to avoid brokenness like that

[13:56:04.0000] <wycats>
but yeah

[13:56:05.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: seems basic auth would work

[13:57:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: I was being snarky -- I of course realize that's bad

[13:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
basic auth over CORS requires the same level of opt-in as cookies, so you may as well use cookies since that is probably what the service already uses for normal login

[13:57:02.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: hmmm

[13:58:00.0000] <wycats>
so why wouldn't the default just be "allow cookies"?

[13:58:01.0000] <wycats>
in the non-preflight case we don't even need to do anything

[13:58:02.0000] <othermaciej>
well it's pretty easy for a server to opt into cookies

[13:58:03.0000] <wycats>
in the preflight case it seems "yes" is the right default

[13:58:04.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: yeah I've read the spec

[13:58:05.0000] <othermaciej>
all it has to do is add Access-Control-Allow-Cookies: true

[13:58:06.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: I know

[13:59:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: it seems the make_cors_friendly should do that by default

[13:59:01.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: I understand how the spec works, I'm thinking through the 90% case here

[13:59:02.0000] <othermaciej>
seems fine for a framework to make it the default if that is well-documented and well-understood

[13:59:03.0000] <wycats>
(you are being very helpful, thank you)

[13:59:04.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: make_cors_friendly :cookies => false

[13:59:05.0000] <wycats>
would be the opt-out

[14:00:00.0000] <wycats>
obviously that would not be the method name

[14:00:01.0000] <wycats>
:p

[14:00:02.0000] <wycats>
probably something more like allow_cross_origin_requests

[14:00:03.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: and could be implemented as Rack middleware, although you'd probably want finer control than that offered

[14:05:00.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: what is the one-sentence answer to "I need to explore the security considerations"

[14:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: I don't know if there is one - depends on the context

[14:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
wycats: if it's a fully public data service that's not per-user and would work without cookies, you could say "other sites can already do this by routing requests bak through their own servers"

[14:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
*back

[14:09:00.0000] <wycats>
lemme look at how conceptually campfire works

[14:09:01.0000] <wycats>
othermaciej: why is it considered verboten to type un/pw into "some random web app" but not in "some random native iphone app"?

[14:09:02.0000] <wycats>
expectation discrepancy?

[14:13:00.0000] <wycats>
"When you're using the API, it's always through an existing user in Campfire. There's no special API user. So when you use the API as "david", you get to see and work with what "david" is allowed to. Authenticating is done with an authentication token, which you'll find on the "Edit my Campfire account" screen in Campfire (click the "Reveal authentication token for API" link).

[14:13:01.0000] <wycats>
When using the authentication token, you don't need a separate password. But since Campfire uses HTTP Basic Authentication, and lots of implementations assume that you want to have a password, it's often easier just to pass in a dummy password, like X."

[14:13:02.0000] <wycats>
I think this is pretty representative

[00:33:06.0000] <Hixie>
phrasing content has nothing to do with inline content in CSS, it's similar to what HTML4 called "inline elements" but we renamed it because it was very confusing having CSS and HTML both call things "inline" that had nothing to do with each other

[01:19:02.0000] <Hixie>

[01:19:03.0000] <Hixie>
well i mean it can _exist_ there, but it's not allowed there

[01:20:00.0000] <wycats>
"The title element of a document is the first title element in the document (in tree order), if there is one, or null otherwise."

[01:20:01.0000] <wycats>
"Returns the document's title, as given by the title element"

[01:20:02.0000] <wycats>
doesn't prevent it from being in the body

[01:20:03.0000] <wycats>

[01:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
right, that's an example of error handling, where the spec tries to handle errors gracefully, but tries to minimise authors making new errors

[03:18:01.0000] <wycats>
Metadata content is content that sets up the presentation or behavior of the rest of the content, or that sets up the relationship of the document with other documents, or that conveys other "out of band" information. => base command link meta noscript script style title

its

[03:20:00.0000] <Hixie>

[14:19:00.0000] <jgraham>

[14:19:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[14:21:00.0000] <jgraham>

[14:22:00.0000] <jgraham>
It's like saying that ruby and python should be unified because they cover a similar problem space

[14:22:01.0000] <jgraham>
Well sure, but they have totally different philosophys and make entirely differnt design trade offs

[14:22:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
jgraham: That is a good post.

[14:23:00.0000] <jgraham>
Surely better to let end users decide which is the better than spend years trying to reach some compromise that no one likes and has none of the original advantages of either approach

[14:24:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Surely we should see if improvements are possible before rejecting it

[14:24:01.0000] <Dashiva>
RDFa 1.1 isn't just "let's keep RDFa 1.0 completely intact"

[14:25:00.0000] <jgraham>
I am quite happy to let RDFa evolve however it likes and Microdata evolve however it likes and see which one works best at the end

[14:25:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Similarly, microdata is open-ended with regard to full graphs and data types

[14:26:00.0000] <jgraham>

[14:28:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It's not like it'd be one or the other. The hybrid might favor one side over the other. Even if a hybrid is proposed, people could still use the "originals" if they preferred.

[14:28:01.0000] <Dashiva>
But if one side can accomodate the other better without any real loss, it would be a better candidate to become majority use

[14:33:00.0000] <carllerche>
Is there a way in canvas to draw the shadow for a path but not the actual path? when I set the fillStyle to 'rgba(0,0,0,0)' the shadow is not drawn either

[14:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
carllerche: No

[14:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
It uses the alpha from the drawn shape to generate the shadow

[14:36:01.0000] <carllerche>
Philip`: Is there a way to do this? will I have to draw the shadow myself?

[14:36:02.0000] <Philip`>
and it always composites both the shadow and the original shape onto the canvas

[14:36:03.0000] <carllerche>
Philip`: Is it possible to render multiple shadows per shape?

[14:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could set the shadow offset to be very large, and draw the shape somewhere off-screen, so only the shadow is visible

[14:38:00.0000] <carllerche>
hmm, tricky :)

[14:38:01.0000] <carllerche>
i'll try that

[14:38:02.0000] <Philip`>
The shadows are rendered once each time you call fill()/stroke(), though you can call fill/stroke multiple times per path

[14:39:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Maybe easier to just draw the shadows manually :)

[14:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/misc/shadow/shadow2.html emulates shadowing manually

[14:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
by doing the Gaussian blur

[14:41:01.0000] <carllerche>
thanks for that tip

[14:42:00.0000] <carllerche>
for some reason, if the fillStyle is set to 'black' the shadow renders correctly, if it's set to a gradient the shadow is only visible right around the edges of the shape...

[14:42:01.0000] <carllerche>
I might end up doing the shadows by hand :-/

[14:44:00.0000] <carllerche>
woah, my canvas renders completely differently in firefox than webkit

[14:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
Shadows ought to work with gradients, I believe

[14:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
It'd be great if you could produce a minimal test case that indicates browser differences and report them as bugs :-)

[14:51:00.0000] <carllerche>
Philip`: this is my test http://carllerche.com/stuff/tests/index.html

[14:51:01.0000] <carllerche>
I don't think i'm doing anything crazy

[14:52:00.0000] <carllerche>
the shadow doesn't seem to render when it's a gradient (it does if fillStyle is set to black) and the shape is way off in firefox...

[14:52:01.0000] <carllerche>
i should probably make sure i'm on the latest FF

[14:53:00.0000] <carllerche>
Philip`: Indeed, I just updated FF and the shape is correct and the shadow renders. So, it seems to be a bug with webkit nightly

[22:45:00.0000] <asmodai>
One thing I did not understand. If the HTML(5, 6?) features are going to be documented/implemented unversioned, how does this impact website designers? Will the spec provide guidelines for capabilities sniffing/exchange or?

[22:46:00.0000] <annevk>
there's no change for designers because as far as they are concerned it has always been unversioned

[22:47:00.0000] <annevk>
i.e. browsers have always done incremental improvements

[22:48:00.0000] <asmodai>
So basically we stay with capabilities sniffing then.

[22:48:01.0000] <annevk>
the idea with unversioning it and making incremental improvements is to reduce the gap between reality and spec writing

[22:49:00.0000] <annevk>
asmodai, yup

[22:49:01.0000] <asmodai>
Well, sure, writing a spec in isolation takes time, especially if features get implemented at the final publication of said spec. :)

[22:49:02.0000] <asmodai>

[22:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
exactly :-)

[22:50:01.0000] <asmodai>

[22:50:02.0000] <Hixie>

[09:31:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, this is a channel for a standards development group, so saying you want to use a Flash-based solution when a semi-usable standards-based solution is available is unlikely to get you a lot of enthusiastic assistance here.  :)

[09:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(a standards development group that has killing Flash as one of its major goals, for that matter)

[09:33:00.0000] <Traveler0>
I see. Can I ask why do you hate it though?

[09:33:01.0000] <Traveler0>
It makes websites look better, you have to agree on that. 

[09:34:00.0000] <Traveler0>
I'm not very enthusiastic about flash either and I don't particularly like entire flash websites, but I think sifr is ok.

[09:34:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Flash is a proprietary solution that's locked the web into one program written by one vendor, and forces us all to dance to their tune.  It stifles competition and innovation.  Flash is also notoriously buggy and unstable, to the point that multiple browsers are now putting a lot of work into sandboxing plugins largely so that Flash doesn't cause them to crash so often.

[09:34:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
For the web to remain healthy, we need standards that can be implemented by many vendors competing against each other, so that we get the best possible implementation and no one is left out.

[09:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Flash doesn't support all platforms either, because Adobe can't be bothered supporting some, and some platforms don't want to depend on Adobe (e.g., iPhone/iPod Touch/iPad).

[09:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
HTML5, when more widely implemented, should supersede Flash in most common use-cases, e.g., videos and simple games.  With any luck, this will reduce Flash market penetration until it eventually becomes unattractive as a development target.

[09:37:00.0000] <Traveler0>
hm

[09:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
I don't think killing Flash is a major goal

[09:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
Making Flash unnecessary by providing better solutions to relevant use cases is much more of a goal

[09:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yes.  Same deal, from a slightly less aggressive perspective.

[09:39:01.0000] <Philip`>
Not really

[09:39:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:39:03.0000] <Philip`>

[09:40:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:40:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:40:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:41:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:41:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:41:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
which isn't necessarily the best sense, e.g. <video> is useful because it makes Flash unnecessary for a subset of use cases, even though it does nothing for many other use cases that Flash satisfies

[09:42:01.0000] <Philip`>
I mean you seemed to mean you wanted to kill Flash in the sense of making the entire thing disappear / become irrelevant / etc

[09:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
As long as Flash has 98% market penetration, authors will use it, forcing users to install it, in a vicious cycle.  The only way to break out of this and get to standards-land is to sharply reduce Flash's market share, by making it less necessary to users, thereby less useful to authors, etc.

[09:44:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Loosely speaking, that's "killing" it 

[09:44:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
.

[09:44:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:55:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:55:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:58:02.0000] <tantek>

[09:58:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:59:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
Because H.264 is popular, lots of people put lots of effort into implementing it well

[10:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
(for lots of different meanings of "well", involving different tradeoffs of quality and size and encoding speed and latency and decoder capabilities etc)

[10:00:01.0000] <Philip`>
whereas it seems Theora has had a not-very-good encoder for most of its life, with recent work on one better encoder, and that's about it

[10:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip`: To the best of my knowledge, there is no way to efficiently do a random sample in mysql.  All methods that I'm aware of are bad.

[10:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you only want one random row at a time, you can make an extra column containing a random number.

[10:52:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then select the first row whose random value is bigger than a randomly-chosen value you just picked.

[10:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But that doesn't work if you want a random sample bigger than one, because the order won't be random; all of the results will be predictable from the first one.

[10:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You could just repeatedly query and filter out duplicates on the application side, though, I guess.

[10:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
(this is how "Random page" on Wikipedia works)

[10:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
This is just a one-off random sample, it doesn't need to be a different random order multiple times

[10:55:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, but it requires adding, populating, and indexing a new column, so it's not very helpful for one-off stuff.

[10:55:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess I could have done the query on the page table using page_random and filtered out non-image pages.

[10:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although not every image corresponds to an image page, nor conversely.

[10:56:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I guess every image probably has an image page.

[10:56:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Dunno about the converse.

[10:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, MySQL says it does explicitly support ORDER BY RAND()

[11:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
so can't you do "select count(*) from (select * from image order by rand() limit 100000) where img_minor_mime = 'ogg'" to count within a random sample?

[11:01:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes.

[11:01:01.0000] <Philip`>
and then multiple by the total number of rows to get an accurate estimate of the number of oggs

[11:01:02.0000] <Philip`>
*multiply

[11:01:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then it will dump the entire contents of the table into a temporary table, generate a random number for each row, sort according to the random number, drop all but the first 100000 rows, and run the query on what's left.

[11:01:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
You did ask for "efficiently", right?

[11:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
Surely it'll just extract the list of row IDs and pick randomly from them?

[11:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
It doesn't need to copy any other data from the table

[11:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
|  1 | SIMPLE      | image | ALL  | NULL          | NULL | NULL    | NULL | 8529989 | Using temporary; Using filesort | 

[11:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, but it will still hit every row of the table.

[11:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The filesort might only use the row ID and the random number in the actual sorting phase, you're right.

[11:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
The IDs would be in an index so that should be fast

[11:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
and then it would only need to load the rows that are in the sample, to check their mimes

[11:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
This is InnoDB, so the table is a B-tree with the IDs as keys, they're not in a separate table.

[11:05:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me doesn't know enough about MySQL's query optimiser or EXPLAIN output

[11:05:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, MySQL is stupid about optimizing subqueries, it will probably execute the subquery naively here.

[11:05:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Is <nav role="navigation"> redundant for screen-readers? Would the nav element on its own be okay?

[11:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me has only ever looked at query optimisation in PostgreSQL, and then in not much detail

[11:06:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You told it to retrieve *, so it will probably do that.  Since it's using filesort, it can't do it before limiting, it will filter after.

[11:06:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it will hit all rows either way.

[11:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, I assume so.  It would be kind of ridiculous, otherwise.

[11:07:01.0000] <Philip`>
I thought a fundamental point of SQL was that it's based on relational algebra so there's valid ways to reorganise and optimise queries, and it doesn't just blindly do what you type in

[11:07:02.0000] <paul_irish>
AryehGregor: indeed though would the browsers need to "support" the nav element? which, of course, many do not right now

[11:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
(like it knows project(select(...)) is equivalent to select(project(...)) (but faster) etc depending on what columns you use)

[11:08:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:16:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:38:00.0000] <carllerche>
Philip`: Hey, i figured out a nice way to draw a shadow without the object 

[12:38:01.0000] <carllerche>
I discovered that compositing only seems to take into consideration the previous fill / store or drawing

[12:39:00.0000] <carllerche>
so, I draw the shape with a shadow, then redraw it with globalCompositeOperation = 'destination-out'

[12:56:00.0000] <Philip`>

[12:56:01.0000] <Philip`>

[12:58:00.0000] <carllerche>

[13:01:00.0000] <carllerche>

[13:01:01.0000] <carllerche>
Philip`: Is there a way to do something like "layers" as in, set globalCompositeOperation that does not effect the background?

[13:05:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:09:00.0000] <carllerche>
I will

[13:09:01.0000] <carllerche>
although, i find that the bugs I hit are usually reported :P

[13:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
Ah, fair enough :-)

[13:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
There isn't really anything like layers (unless you make independent overlapping <canvas>s) - when you draw a shape, it just constructs the shadow bitmap and composites that onto the canvas, then composites the drawn shape bitmap onto the canvas, and you can't access the intermediate bitmaps or change the compositing mode between those steps

[04:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:03:02.0000] <meledin>
I do POST to /delete

[04:04:00.0000] <meledin>
Well, the theory being that if you would PUT to, e.g. a post reply on a forum, there would be no risk of double posts since you'd overwrite the last one

[04:05:00.0000] <asmodai>
I still find the names of PUT and POST confusing. My mind is also nagging me about missing implementations of DELETE in some webservers or so since it is hardly used. Good chance I'm confusing it with something else though.

[04:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
now I am curious how control values affect the request for a PUT or DELETE form

[04:06:01.0000] <meledin>
It would be useful if people doing forms subscribe to REST. Otherwise, no, not really. So to me that's the question to ask.

[04:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it looks like per HTML5, method=DELETE ignores the contents of form controls and just makes a DELETE method request to the action URI

[04:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that would make DELETE as a form action kind of useless

[04:11:01.0000] <annevk>
hmm, IETF fail

[04:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
for PUT, the form contents are encoded into the body, but it seems unlikely that you'd want to upload a resource using any of the three formats...

[04:12:01.0000] <annevk>
http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5646 says it is bcp47 but http://tools.ietf.org/html/bcp47 says it is http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4647 which is not obsoleted by the first URL...

[04:12:02.0000] <hsivonen>
yay for BCP stability

[04:13:00.0000] <meledin>
Well, for DELETE I would assume if there were form contents (such as a list of items to delete) you could encode it in the URL like for GET.

[04:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, but HTML5 does not say to do that, and it's not clear that would be a good behavior anyway

[04:14:01.0000] <othermaciej>
because then you could only delete resources that have a query in their URI

[04:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah it'd make no sense to do that

[04:15:01.0000] <meledin>
I don't see why? Isn't the query ignored if the remote side isn't interested in it?

[04:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
DELETE would only make sense in the context of a <button> with a formaction="" attribute

[04:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
PUT doesn't really make any sense at all

[04:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
both were mostly added for parity wiht xforms back in the day

[04:16:02.0000] <annevk>
lots of people seemed to want them

[04:16:03.0000] <othermaciej>
PUT would make sense if you could upload the contents of a file (from <input type=file>) without any other junk prepended or appended

[04:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or upload the contents of a text field or contentEditable area

[04:17:01.0000] <meledin>
PUT doesn't literally mean what the form PUTS to the resource is the end result, though?

[04:17:02.0000] <othermaciej>
uploading urlencoded or multipart form data does not seem very useful

[04:17:03.0000] <othermaciej>
meledin: that's what http PUT is supposed to mean

[04:17:04.0000] <othermaciej>
(roughly)

[04:17:05.0000] <meledin>
My understanding is it just means it overwrites the previous data and it's deterministic in its behaviour

[04:18:00.0000] <annevk>
how the data is encoded has no relevance to PUT afaict

[04:18:01.0000] <othermaciej>
for PUT wouldn't you normally want to submit something in a form that could make sense to serve as a resource?

[04:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that's certainly how atompub uses it

[04:19:01.0000] <meledin>

[04:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
meledin: Why doesn't it?

[04:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
How does the HTTP method make any difference to that, in particular?

[04:21:01.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, but the server could take the data out of the multipart and use it as resource, no?

[04:21:02.0000] <Philip`>
Seems like you could do it with POST if you just add some unique form identifier each time you generate the editing form

[04:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
which is the same as you'd have to do with PUT except there you'd put the unique ID in the URL to make it point at a new resource, I guess

[04:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: could in theory - but that doesn't seem to be the intent of PUT as I understand it

[04:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: for example it seems like you might want to be able to use PUT to talk to an atompub service, but PUT from a form HTML5-style would make that impossible

[04:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I do think PUT could make sense if you could identify a single control and PUT its value

[04:24:02.0000] <meledin>
"Unless otherwise specified for a particular entity-header, the entity-headers in the PUT request SHOULD be applied to the resource created or modified by the PUT." -- othermaciej seems right.

[04:25:00.0000] <meledin>
Don't see any mention of "servers can/should ignore content-type on PUT".

[04:28:00.0000] <annevk>
entity-header != entity body

[04:28:01.0000] <annevk>
but I don't really care either way :)

[04:29:00.0000] <annevk>
maybe not allowing them is better because they have this awkward same-origin restriction

[04:30:00.0000] <meledin>
Philip`: Basically, you're right. The end result is the same. In the PUT case, though, the end result is forced as part of the programming model, while in the POST case the programmer has to think. Being a dumb monkey, I like not thinking.

[04:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
Seems like the actual implementation requires the same amount of thinking in either case

[04:32:01.0000] <Philip`>

[04:33:00.0000] <meledin>

[04:33:01.0000] <Philip`>

[04:34:00.0000] <Philip`>

[08:00:02.0000] <othermaciej>

s////

[13:54:00.0000] <ment>
0 == strcmp("a" "b", "ab")

two string literals that are adjacent to each other get concatenated

[16:20:00.0000] <rektide>
chrome you anger me

[16:21:00.0000] <rektide>
even after window.name = "foo",  from another tab doing window.open(sameUrl,"foo",null,false) tries to open a new window

[16:21:01.0000] <rektide>
i use this as my final contention for postMessage() being utterly and completely worthless.  unless you open it, you cant talk to it.

[16:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
rektide: It ought to work in any situation where you already have a reference to another window, I believe

[16:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
There's no guarantee that window names are unique within a browser session, so you can't use them as way to acquire references

[16:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
I guess you have to use something like localStorage if you want some shared communication medium between otherwise-independent windows

[16:38:00.0000] <rektide>
Philip`: theres no guarantee window names are unique, so you cant _rely_ on them to acquire references

[16:39:00.0000] <rektide>
however you should be able to acquire references to other windows, according to the window.open() spec

[16:40:00.0000] <rektide>
and according to my own testing, and google chrome bug 8751, chrome is currently in violation of the spec

[16:40:01.0000] <rektide>
http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=8751

[16:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think HTML5 allows Chrome's behaviour

[16:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/browsers.html#dom-open - "the user agent must first select a browsing context to navigate by applying the rules for choosing a browsing context given a browsing context name using the target argument as the name"

[16:43:01.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/browsers.html#the-rules-for-choosing-a-browsing-context-given-a-browsing-context-name

[16:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
"If the given browsing context name is not _blank and there exists a browsing context whose name is the same as the given browsing context name, and the current browsing context is allowed to navigate that browsing context, and the user agent determines that the two browsing contexts are related enough that it is ok if they reach each other, then that browsing context must be the chosen one."

[16:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
The "related enough" bit allows Chrome to consider browsing contexts associated with separate browser windows to be unrelated

[16:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Oh, that bug points at SharedWorker which is possibly a reasonable way to communicate between independent windows)

[16:52:00.0000] <rektide>

[03:19:01.0000] <Philip`>

[03:23:01.0000] <annevk>

[03:25:00.0000] <Hixie>

[03:25:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[03:25:02.0000] <Hixie>

[03:26:00.0000] <Hixie>

[03:26:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[03:26:02.0000] <Hixie>

[03:28:00.0000] <annevk>
though those were disallowed

[03:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah but they're still exposed in dataset currently

[03:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'll just exclude any with capital letters from dataset and we'll be golden

[03:29:01.0000] <Dashiva>
A custom data attribute is an attribute in no namespace whose name starts with the string "data-", has at least one character after the hyphen, is XML-compatible, and contains no characters in the range U+0041 to U+005A (LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A to LATIN CAPITAL LETTER Z).

[03:29:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Doesn't that already exclude it?

[03:29:03.0000] <Hixie>
that's the authoring conformance requirement

[03:29:04.0000] <Hixie>
doesn't say jack about what dataset does

[03:30:00.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
for example, with dataset properties set programatically

[03:31:00.0000] <Dashiva>
So make the access algorithm replace capital letter with - followed by lowercase letter? That way it can't map to invalid attributes at all

[03:32:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, no... initial capital letter would give data--... but it wouldn't map to a uppercase letter 

[03:33:00.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
is data--foo invalid?

[03:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
Dashiva: so data-aB="" would become dataset['a-b']? Then it would clash with data-a-b="".

[03:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
GarethAdams|Home: the definition of what's valid is what Dashiva quoted above

[03:33:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Hixie: data-aB wouldn't become anything, it would just be an attribute that's never used

[03:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm confused as to what you're suggesting

[03:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
the solution i'm following is trivial

[03:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
just exclude content attributes with a capital letter from the API

[03:34:03.0000] <Hixie>
and then do the adjustments

[03:35:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I'm suggesting you change the "Let name be the concatenation" steps to also replace uppercase letters with hyphen followed by lowercase equivalent

[03:35:01.0000] <Dashiva>
datalist.doQuery would map to data-do-query

[03:36:00.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
Dashiva is saying that dataset['aB'] would be identical to dataset['a-b'] - with the data-aB attribute still being invalid

[03:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
yes, that has to be part of the solution also

[03:36:02.0000] <Hixie>
except dataset['a-b'] wouldn't be there

[03:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
not sure whether to make setting that throw an exception, silently fail, or silently passthrough

[03:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm leaning towards exception

[03:37:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Why not allow it?

[03:37:03.0000] <annevk>
yeah, SYNTAX_ERR

[03:38:00.0000] <annevk>
Dashiva, enforce some consistency

[03:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
allowing it leads to a confusing situation where you can compare two strings, be sure they're not the same, then set both and trample each other

[03:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
very bad

[03:40:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Although WebIDL would make it fail anyhow, since a-b wouldn't be in the supported property name list

[03:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
Could make dataset['a-b'] map onto attribute data-a--b

[03:40:02.0000] <Philip`>
because that should avoid conflicts and avoid forbidding certain strings

[03:41:00.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
I was about to say, transparently switching a-b and aB wouldn't help with multiple consecutive -

[03:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
Dashiva: i use the same algorithm for creation

[03:41:02.0000] <Philip`>
although actually that probably wouldn't work

[03:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: and map ---x to --x when reading? that way leads madness

[03:42:01.0000] <Philip`>
because you'd need to do something with data-a-0 attributes, which presumably can only can be dataset["a-0"], and that needs to be reversible

[03:43:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Map - followed by non-uppercase to _? :)

[03:43:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Um, non-lowercase

[03:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
Does IE have some rules for mapping '-'-separated strings onto camelCase strings?

[03:43:03.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
well not all dataset keys are mappable to DOM properties, so you don't need to provide for all possibilities

[03:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
for expandos or whatever they are

[03:44:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders what the exact rules are

[03:46:00.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
for most CSS properties, the rule is -[a-z] maps to [A-Z] - that's all. Trying to cover multiple hyphens, numbers etc isn't going to be possible because NameChar in HTML isn't the same as e.g. Javascript

[12:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[12:16:01.0000] <virtuelv>
even with longdesc being used in a useful manner in 75% of the cases used, why is longdesc used on less than 1% of pages?

[12:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[12:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[12:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I should also mention that because of the very large sample sizes, the standard error is ridiculously small, so some form of systematic error is the only way the study's conclusion could be wrong

[12:42:01.0000] <Dashiva>
AryehGregor: Make a statement of what the web is like, then change your sample methodology until it matches

[12:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
her use of "anecdotal" to refer to large data sets where she is not fully confident that the methodology provides a representative random sample is an unusual use of the term, I think

[12:42:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Um, why not?  First approach: unifoermly sample from Google's cache of pages.

[12:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one could form a hypothesis that certain things missed by the bot would be more likely to contain longdesc attributes, and more likely to contain valid longdesc values in those cases where the attribute is present

[12:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Second approach: take a large directory, wide enough to remove many forms of systemic bias, and uniformly sample from all linked pages.

[12:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, "random" isn't well-defined.  You have to further specify.  See also: Bertrand's paradox.

[12:44:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: In the absence of further clarification, lay usage of "random" means "sampled from a uniform distribution".  Assuming otherwise is being uselessly pedantic.

[12:44:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Sure.  Uniform over what set?

[12:44:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
The same is true in Betrand's paradox.

[12:44:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Over some representatively large set of pages.

[12:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So you mean uniform over all pages, with no weighting?  All pages everyone has viewed in the last X days, maybe?  Including if it was only viewed by search spiders, or also humans?  Including intranets too, or only the public Internet?  How large is X?

[12:46:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Some of those considerations will materially affect the resulting set, especially whether you include intranet pages.

[12:46:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
X is sufficiently large.  For most of your questions I would hypothesize that it would not affect the sample for the types of variables we're testing.

[12:46:02.0000] <othermaciej>
hypotheses about intranet contents tend not to be falsifiable

[12:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
There are well-established methods of figuring out how large is "sufficient" based on the desired strength of the test you're performing.

[12:47:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not if you don't define the set in the first place.

[12:47:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though, "a billion" is pretty much always large enough.

[12:47:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not if it's nowhere close to representative.

[12:47:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Do you believe that the sets that have been sampled are non-representative for the relevant variables?

[12:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't believe they're non-representative enough to create such a skewed result incorrectly, no.  But if you're trying to convince me, you're wasting your time, because I already agree with you.

[12:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm not trying to establish a new test here, just defend the existing tests as being acceptable in their methodology.

[12:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it's defintiely possible for a sample to be very large, but still not random with respect to the variable under study

[12:48:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, I was objecting to your use of the term "random" as though there were only one way to sample a "random" set of pages.

[12:48:04.0000] <othermaciej>
there is a limit to how much you can control for that

[12:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one possibility is to guess what variables may be correlated, and try to sample from subpopulations to preserve the right ratio

[12:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: You were being pedantic.  ^_^  Like I said, you *know* what "random" means when used like that, and you also know roughly what sort of page distribution we're talking about, and have at least some idea of how to construct a reasonably "representative" set of pages.

[12:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
calling something a "random sample" doesn't imply that there is only one way to do it, at least not in any statistics I've heard of

[12:50:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: Indeed.

[12:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But still, unless one has reason to believe that the used population *is* biased in that variable, one cannot reasonably suggest that the study sampling from that population is biased.

[12:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
For some definitions of "random" there's no feasible way to construct a random selection of pages, particularly not if you include intranets.

[12:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
intranets are for practical purposes outside the realm of science

[12:52:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
We typically don't include intranets for that reason.

[12:52:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's my point.  :)

[12:52:03.0000] <othermaciej>
because general hypotheses about intranets are for practical purposes not falsifiable

[12:52:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
There may be a bias introduced through that, but one must also consider the population of disabled web users as a whole and ask if this bias is likely to affect them.

[12:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway.

[12:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That is, is an average disabled web user going to be affected by a higher or lower prevalance of correct @longdesc usage in intranets?

[12:53:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'd argue not.

[12:53:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Counterargument: disabled users aren't average

[12:53:04.0000] <othermaciej>
you don't have to assume anything about intranets really, just accurately state the result as being about publicly available web content

[12:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Are they non-average in a way that would bias them strongly towards using intranets, and thus being more highly affected by them than a normal web user?

[12:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
then anyone who wants to make a separate hypothesis about intranet content has the burden of proof to demonstrate their hypothesis

[12:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if they feel that would provide relevant evidence

[13:08:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Bertrand's paradox doesn't apply here.  In there you have a continuous variable that you're attempting to sample, and so the distribution you use to sample it matters quite a lot.  A discrete variable, on the other hand, can be given a very simple uniform distribution.  The example given by Bertrand matters because there *is* no uniform distribution over all possible chords of a...

[13:08:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
...circle.

[13:09:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
However, I unfortunately will have to leave before I see a rebuttal, as I've got to head out to meet with my parents.  Feel free to disagree with me, though, and I'll see it when I get back.  ^_^

[13:09:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's correct, but you have no feasible algorithm for uniformly sampling pages on the web.

[13:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If I have all the pages, I certainly do.  I don't have all the pages, of course, so we can then argue over whether the pages I have access to are representative, but that's a different issue I think.

[13:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So the same general principle applies: you're suggesting someone sample something at random, but since uniform sampling is impossible (practically in this case, logically in Bertrand's), it's not clear what distribution you're asking for.

[13:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The obvious algorithm would be to collect all the pages and then sample in a usual fashion, yes.  But presumably you were not suggesting that Shelley do that.

[13:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
studies do random samples of persons residing in the United States, but I am not sure anyone has an accurate, up-to-date and complete list

[13:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
nor is every person in the United States equally convenient to reach

[13:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
They try to find representative cross-sections, but only by carefully controlling certain variables and hoping those are the relevant ones.  The people who agree to participate in studies aren't representative, after all.

[13:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>
usually you try to estimate how much your sampling methodology might correlate with the variable of interest

[13:15:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and apply that to your error estimates

[13:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Probably this all sounds more reasonable to a scientist than to a mathematician.

[13:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you don't generally say "I am not sure if my sample is perfectly representative, therefore I assume my error bar is unbounded"

[13:16:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
(a pure mathematician, specifically)

[13:16:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, no, that's a silly thing to say.

[13:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
perhaps Ian should have reported an estimated error for his study, then one could debate the size of the confidence interval rather than the statistically dubious question of "valid or invalid"

[13:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I believe he studied physics so I assume he knows how to do that sort of thing

[13:30:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:33:00.0000] <jgraham>
AryehGregor: Theoretically, yes.

[13:33:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:35:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:36:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:37:02.0000] <jgraham>

[13:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:38:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:38:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:39:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:39:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:39:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
othermaciej: "the size of the confidence interval" - if I remember correctly that's proportional to 1/sqrt(n), and if n=1e9 then it's going to be pretty close to zero and uninteresting and completely insignificant compared to even tiny systematic biases

[13:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: yes, the standard error is tiny if you assume no sample bias

[13:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or rather, I should say, the standard error is tiny, and if you don't assume sample bias or measurement error or something of that nature, that's about the only thing that factors into your confidence interval

[13:57:00.0000] <jgraham>
I think that is almost always true though, in the sense that if you are in a regime where your measurement is only just significant within random errors, it is almost certianly insignificant due to systematic errors you weren't accounting for

[13:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: I did compute the standard error, and both with the 1 billion sample of pages and the 13 billion subsample of pages containing longdesc it is very small

[13:57:02.0000] <Philip`>
Is it possible to come up with a confidence interval based on any other kind of error, that is not completely meaningless?

[13:57:03.0000] <jgraham>
("90% of 2 sigma results are noise")

[13:57:04.0000] <othermaciej>
well, you could assume a statistical distribution of sample bias, but I have no idea if that is meaningful

[13:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:58:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:58:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:59:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:59:02.0000] <jgraham>

[14:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:00:01.0000] <Philip`>

[14:00:02.0000] <othermaciej>
which by the way, if you compute the confidence level for that sigma level, I think the number by which it is less than 100% probably doesn't have a name

[14:00:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:00:05.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:04:01.0000] <jgraham>

[16:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:25:00.0000] <NickYoung>

[16:27:00.0000] <Hixie>

[16:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:29:00.0000] <daedb_>
Are there *any* new features that hasn't had any objections?

[16:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's circular thinking. Authors can't do anything _but_ use CSS at the moment.

[16:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
daedb_: there's a lot of them that haven't been noticed by the people complaining, i think

[16:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, in well-written HTML, you're better off just ignoring the CSS.  I once had a blind user in #mediawiki asking how to turn off all CSS on his wiki for blind users.

[16:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
HTML5 has added numerous features to try to reduce the need for CSS

[16:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
(for that kind of semantic-level stuff)

[08:53:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:07:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:08:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[09:10:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:10:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:11:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[09:11:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:11:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:12:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[09:13:00.0000] <Philip`>

[11:34:00.0000] <smaug>
Hixie:now that you're here,  why does the websocket protocol have the optional binary-frames?

[11:34:01.0000] <smaug>
or what to call them, semi-optional

[11:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
so that we can add support for binary in the future

[11:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
they're not optional, they're invalid at the moment

[11:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
the support is just error handling

[11:35:03.0000] <Hixie>
and you can handle them by either ignoring them or failing the connection

[11:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
(only ignoring them if you're a browser client)

[11:36:01.0000] <smaug>
well, might be better to define that they are really invalid now

[11:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
i thought it did

[11:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
where does it say they are alid?

[11:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
valid

[11:37:03.0000] <Hixie>
neither the server nor the client is allowed to send them

[11:37:04.0000] <Hixie>
they're only allowed to send 0x00 frames currently

[11:38:00.0000] <smaug>
well, the server side part says that "If /type/ is not a 0x00 byte, then the server may disconnect from

[11:38:01.0000] <smaug>
       the client."

[11:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
right

[11:38:03.0000] <smaug>
it is just "may"

[11:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
indeed

[11:38:05.0000] <Hixie>
that's the right thing to do as far as i can tell

[11:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
the server knows the subprotocol that the conneciton is using

[11:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
so it can know that if it sees a binary frame it can disconnect since it's not valid

[11:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
and it can equally know that it might want to use binary frames in the future and will therefore know that it can try to be future-compatible and not disconnect, but just ignore the packet

[11:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
s/packet/frame/

[11:40:01.0000] <smaug>
server may not really know the subprotocol. I'd assume the subprotocol was implemented by some cgi-like script

[11:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's still the server

[11:42:00.0000] <smaug>
and anyway, the client can't handle binary data at all

[11:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
today, right

[11:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
but in the future we'll add binary frames

[11:42:03.0000] <smaug>
yeah

[11:42:04.0000] <smaug>
so why define some sort of server side support for binary, but not client side

[11:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
the clients ignore binary frames just like the server does

[11:43:01.0000] <smaug>
not the same way

[11:43:02.0000] <smaug>
client does always "Discard the read bytes."

[11:43:03.0000] <Hixie>
well the clients aren't allowed to disconnect, sure

[11:43:04.0000] <smaug>
server just may close the connection

[11:43:05.0000] <Hixie>
right

[11:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
the server knows the protocol, the client doesn't (it's running JS that does the protocol)

[11:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
so the server can know if it's expecting binary frames or not

[11:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
the clients on the other hand have to all interoperate exactly

[11:45:03.0000] <Hixie>

[11:45:04.0000] <smaug>

[11:46:01.0000] <Hixie>

[11:46:02.0000] <Hixie>

[11:46:03.0000] <smaug>
why can't you write the protocol so that it supports that already?

[11:46:04.0000] <Hixie>
no point, the API doesn't do it

[11:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
what would you do with the data?

[11:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
the client can neither send nor receive binary

[11:47:02.0000] <zcorpan__>

[11:47:03.0000] <smaug>
currently it can receive binary

[11:47:04.0000] <smaug>
it just discards the data immediately 

[11:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
right

[11:48:01.0000] <smaug>
in the future the protocol will need backwards incompatible change

[11:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan__: that'd be unwise, since we don't know exactly what the conventions will be

[11:49:00.0000] <smaug>
client may not discard the data anymore

[11:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
how is that not backwards compatible?

[11:50:00.0000] <smaug>

[11:50:01.0000] <smaug>
and rely on that client doesn't handle that

[11:50:02.0000] <smaug>

[11:50:03.0000] <Hixie>

[11:51:00.0000] <smaug>

[11:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
yes, but the script the author wrote isn't going to suddenly support it without the server being fixed to not send those frames

[11:53:00.0000] <smaug>
right

[11:53:01.0000] <smaug>
so why not say now that client may use the binary frames

[11:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
JS doesn't support binary

[11:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
so what are we supposed to do with the binary frames?

[11:54:01.0000] <smaug>
I assume there can be other than WebSockets API which use the protocol

[11:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh, no, that would be silly

[11:54:03.0000] <Hixie>
if you're not a browser just use TCP

[11:54:04.0000] <smaug>
huh

[11:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
the only things WebSockets gives you are an origin-based security model (only helpful for browsers) and basic framing

[11:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
basic framing is so trivial to do that you can do it in your own protocol, you don't need websockets

[11:55:02.0000] <smaug>
if you have some service which already uses websockets, why not use the same protocol everywhere?

[11:55:03.0000] <Hixie>
well i guess you could, but then you have to worry about JS clients again

[11:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
my point is you'd only ever use websockets if at least one of your clients is going to be a browser

[11:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
and if that's the case, then you can't use binary frames

[11:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
until we add binary to the protocol

[11:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
er, to JS I mean

[11:57:00.0000] <smaug>
right

[11:58:00.0000] <smaug>
but since the binary frames are defined already, server-to-server (or server-to-C++) communication could start use binary-frames already

[11:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
personally i'd strongly recommend that if your client isn't a browser, you just use a custom protocol

[11:58:02.0000] <smaug>
and once the JS API is ready, it can just start use the same (binary) subprotocol

[11:58:03.0000] <Hixie>
it might look very similar to websockets, but it needn't be websockets itself

[11:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
for example the whole handshake is a waste of time if you're not a browser

[11:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
and if you're not using websockets, you can write your own spec that uses whatever frames you want

[11:59:01.0000] <smaug>
yet you mention in the draft that not all communication is server-to-browser

[11:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, people keep telling me to make the spec more generic

[11:59:03.0000] <Hixie>
i think it's a mistake

[12:01:00.0000] <smaug>

[12:01:01.0000] <smaug>
not a big change

[12:02:00.0000] <smaug>

[12:02:01.0000] <Hixie>

[12:02:02.0000] <Hixie>

[12:02:03.0000] <Hixie>

[12:02:04.0000] <Hixie>

[12:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
and there's no need for it -- if you want to speak a custom protocol to a server, you don't need this spec

[12:03:01.0000] <Hixie>

[12:12:02.0000] <Hixie>

[12:12:05.0000] <Hixie>

[12:13:00.0000] <Hixie>

[12:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
only 0x00 frames get processed currently without discarding

[13:14:02.0000] <Hixie>

[13:14:03.0000] <smaug>

[13:15:00.0000] <smaug>
Hixie: oops, seems like I've missed

[13:15:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah but any IPC basically has to be async

[13:15:02.0000] <smaug>
sorry

[13:15:03.0000] <smaug>
IPC doesn't have to be async

[13:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
if you try doing sync IPC with the kind of model a browser implies, you're very likely to end up with either deadlocks or EXTREMELY complicated code

[13:17:00.0000] <roc>
you just force the event loops into a directed acyclic graph and then require all calls in one direction to be async

[13:18:00.0000] <smaug>
IPC from client process to parent doesn't have to be async

[13:18:01.0000] <smaug>
and especially if there was a separate process for a "tab", that could handle session history

[13:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
history traversal requires two-way communication

[13:19:00.0000] <smaug>
if there was some problem with it, the main process could kill it

[13:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
if you can come up with a model that has each iframe in a different process, and can do sync history traversal, I'm certainly eager to hear how it would work.

[13:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
please do e-mail such proposals to the list

[13:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
currently, i'm not aware of any plausible way to do it that isn't insanely complicated compared to just making history traversal async

[13:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
and since history traversal has to be mostly async anyway when you're doing cross-page traversal, it seems simple enough to do it async

[13:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
(generally we want everything async anyway)

[13:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
(so that e.g. script doesn't block on disk I/O)

[13:21:01.0000] <smaug>
I'll think about the sync sh

[13:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
frankly the best argument for keeping the same-page session history sync would be evidence that it's needed for back compat

[13:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
lacking that, making it trigger based on queueing a task seems like a big win all round

[13:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
(i wish we could make location.href async too, but that one clearly does have back compat requirmenets)

[14:53:00.0000] <boblet>
Microdata q: wondering why this doesn’t work in microdatajs; <li itemprop="location" itemscope itemtype="http://microformats.org/profile/hcard">

[14:54:00.0000] <boblet>
but this does <li itemprop="location"><span itemscope itemtype="http://microformats.org/profile/hcard">

[14:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
when you say "Work", what are you looking for?

[14:55:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: atm “work” = card data in http://foolip.org/microdatajs/live/

[14:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
what's the complete document?

[14:56:01.0000] <boblet>
so I realise it might be a problem there. just sanity-checking I’m not making a mistake

[14:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
I'm not 100% sure I understand what you're trying to do

[14:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
(in particular, I'm curious what the itemprop="location" is intended to be part of)

[14:57:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: converting uF to Microdata. this is an hcard embedded in hcalendar

[14:57:01.0000] <Hixie>
in microdata, <li itemprop="location"><span itemscope itemtype="http://microformats.org/profile/hcard"> means the same as <li itemprop="location"></li> ... <span itemscope itemtype="http://microformats.org/profile/hcard">

[14:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
that is, there's no link between the itemprop=location and the vcard in that case

[14:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
if you have an hCalendar and it contains a vCard, then I don't think foolip's tool will show you the nested vCard

[14:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
(the spec only says to extract the top-level vCards)

[14:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
(e.g. it won't exact Agents either)

[14:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
technically the vEvent vocabulary doesn't allow nested vCards currently iirc

[14:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete.html#md-vevent-location says "The value must be text."

[15:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
(as opposed to "The value must be either an item with the type http://microformats.org/profile/hcard, or an absolute URL, or text." which is what the spec for vCard "agent" says)

[15:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
hth

[15:02:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: sorry, uploaded code http://oli-studio.com/temp/uf/microdata.html

[15:02:01.0000] <boblet>
and that “value must be text” part is a bit limiting if it means no contained elements

[15:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
the "value" there is the value of the itemprop="" property

[15:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
which can generally be either text, or a URL, or a datetime, or a nested itemscope="" item,

[15:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
s/,$//

[15:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
it doesn't preclude nested markup, but nested markup doesn't affect microdata

[15:05:00.0000] <boblet>
by that do you mean any text in nested markup isn’t included, eg as the location value in this case?

[15:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's flattened

[15:06:00.0000] <boblet>
or that the markup is ignored but the contained text is used?

[15:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
in:

[15:06:02.0000] <Hixie>
<div itemscope><span itemprop="a">hello <em>world</em> how <em>are</em> you</span></div>

[15:06:03.0000] <Hixie>
...there is a singel item, and it has a single property named "a", and its value os "hello world how are you" with no markup.

[15:06:04.0000] <boblet>
ok, that’s what I hoped

[15:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
in:

[15:08:00.0000] <boblet>
so when you say “technically the vEvent vocabulary doesn't allow nested vCards currently” is that in Microdata or uF?

[15:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
<div itemscope><span itemprop="a"><em itemscope><span itemprop="b">B</span></em></span></div>

[15:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
...tehre are two _top-level_ microdata items

[15:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
one has a property "a" with the value "B"

[15:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
the other has the property "b" with the value "B"

[15:09:02.0000] <boblet>
(I kinda thought that each itemtype instance wouldn’t affect the others)

[15:09:03.0000] <Hixie>
they are not related items -- there's no link between them in the microdata model

[15:09:04.0000] <Hixie>
however, in:

[15:09:05.0000] <Hixie>
<div itemscope><span itemprop="a" itemscope><span itemprop="b">B</span></span></div>

[15:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
there is _one_ top-level microdata item, and it has a property "a" whose value is a nested item, which itself has one property "b" whose value is "B".

[15:10:01.0000] <boblet>
aaah

[15:10:02.0000] <boblet>
a bit more rigor than uF classes

[15:10:03.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, that was one of the main goals of microdata

[15:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
the above and itemref="" are basically the two complicated parts of microdata

[15:11:01.0000] <Hixie>
(i recommend ignoring itemref="" for now)

[15:11:02.0000] <boblet>
am ignoring itemref="" for now :)

[15:11:03.0000] <boblet>
snap

[15:12:00.0000] <boblet>
have yet to make the slides, but will post here when I’m done for feedback (hopefully before the event :| )

[15:12:01.0000] <boblet>
thanks for explaining

[18:00:00.0000] <mikl0>
HTML5 is no longer an XML vocabulary?  Just making sure I understand.

[18:03:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
Hixie: here now

[18:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
mikl0: it's a DOM vocabulary, and there's an XML serialisation and a text/html serialisation

[18:10:00.0000] <mikl0>
Hixie: If I wanted to use an XML application like MathML I would do what to make everything valid use XML serialisation? MIME type of application/xhtml+xml or application/xml ?

[18:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
text/html (as of HTML5) supports the MathML, SVG, and HTML vocabularies

[18:11:01.0000] <Hixie>
for XML, you can use any MIME type text/xml, application/xml, or */*+xml

[18:11:02.0000] <Hixie>
as far as HTML5 goes

[18:13:00.0000] <mikl0>
Hixie: ah, that clears my confusion so HTML5 text/html is fine with MathML, SVG and HTML perfect!  Thank you.

[18:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
mikl0: Just be careful when using namespaced elements.  IIRC they sometimes don't act as you'd expect in the text/html serialization.

[18:25:00.0000] <mikl0>
TabAtkins: ok i will be and i plan on being here in the channel frequently as i work, to give back for others who have questions and to ask some of my own i'm sure.

[18:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok, so, elementary TCP questions ahoy.

[18:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
if i want to initiate a graceful close, it seems relatively easy

[18:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
I send a FIN (shutdown with SHUT_WR), then I wait until the socket is ready to read and recv() returns zero, then I call close().

[18:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
but what does the other side do?

[18:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
If I'm in full swing of a connection, and my peer sends a FIN (recv() returns zero), what do I do to make sure that all my sent data gets to the other side?

[18:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
I can't call close(), because that will empty the send buffer and send a RST, as far as I can tell.

[18:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
I can't call shutdown() with SHUT_WR, because I'll have no way to know to move on to the next step, since recv() has already returned zero.

[18:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
hm, it seems i'm wrong about close() clearing the _send_ buffer

[18:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
what's going on is normally it sends an RST if there's any pending data to _read_, and _that_ causes the other side to throw away _its_ read buffer

[18:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
so

[18:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
a simple graceful shutdown can be done just by one side or the other sending a FIN

[18:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
then it waiting for recv()=0 and calling close()

[18:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
and the other side just calling close()

[18:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
when it gets recv()=0

[23:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: it's clear from the spec that <p spellcheck=""> and <p contenteditable=""> are conforming, but the spec seems to be ambiguous about whether <p spellcheck> and <p contenteditable> are conforming.

[23:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
where is a difference between the two expressed?

[23:11:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: the difference is that in the first case the empty string is explicitly specified

[23:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's explicitly specified in the second case also

[23:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
unless we're talkign about different parts of the spec

[23:13:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
is there a place in the spec that says using empty-attribute syntax is equivalent to explictly including '=""' ?

[23:14:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: the spec defines empty-attribute syntax but does not say it's equivalent to including =""

[23:14:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I realize that parsing algorithm makes it clear that empty attributes get assigned the empty string as values

[23:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: hm, yeah, the syntax could be clearer about that. i'll file a bug, thanks.

[23:20:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I'm happy to file the bug if you want

[23:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, I think it's clear enough for those who read the parsing algorithm, just not for those who don't
