[08:03:00.0000] <karlushi>
was looking at http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup/form.html#form.attrs.accept-charset

[08:04:00.0000] <karlushi>
and it doesn't seem there is an explanation in which order you should process the space separated values list of encoding

[08:05:00.0000] <karlushi>
/me is going to the spec

[08:05:01.0000] <karlushi>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/forms.html#attr-form-accept-charset

[08:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
karlushi: http://whatwg.org/html#url-encoded-form-data

[08:07:01.0000] <Philip`>
Step 2 is where it defines the processing of accept-charset

[08:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
i.e. UAs can pick whichever they think is going to work best

[08:08:01.0000] <karlushi>
hmmm 

[08:08:02.0000] <karlushi>
I thought the order was meaningful

[08:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
It has no meaning defined by the spec, it seems

[08:09:01.0000] <Philip`>
It's just a list of charsets that the server will accept

[08:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
and there's no reason for the server to have preferences, since it'll decode them all equally into Unicode

[08:10:01.0000] <karlushi>
If specified, the value must be an ordered set of unique space-separated tokens

[08:10:02.0000] <karlushi>
-- quote from the spec

[08:10:03.0000] <Philip`>
The UA might choose to derive some meaning from the order

[08:10:04.0000] <annevk>
we should obsolete accept-charset

[08:10:05.0000] <karlushi>
ok

[08:11:00.0000] <annevk>
people ought to use UTF-8

[08:11:01.0000] <karlushi>
so if I understood well: accept-charset="ISO-8859-1 utf-8" == accept-charset="utf-8 iso-8859-1"

[08:11:02.0000] <Philip`>
annevk: People might want to migrate their site to UTF-8 gradually, by making their forms accept UTF-8 even if the outer page is stuck on Win1252

[08:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
in which case they need to use accept-charset

[08:13:00.0000] <karlushi>
/me is trying to figure out the issues/benefits of <form … accept-charset="ISO-8859-1 utf-8">

[08:13:01.0000] <annevk>
Philip`, we could make it like border= with only one allowed value

[08:13:02.0000] <annevk>
karlushi, why?

[08:13:03.0000] <annevk>
karlushi, use UTF-8, much superior

[08:13:04.0000] <Philip`>
karlushi: Not necessarily equal - a UA might choose to prefer ones that are earlier in the list, and the spec doesn't forbid or require that

[08:13:05.0000] <karlushi>

[18:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
should i suggest the toppings be sent as topping=a&topping=b&topping=c, or toppingA=on&toppingB=on&toppingC=on?

[18:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
the former means explaining the value="" attribute on type=checkbox

[18:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
the latter means explaining that it has a default

[18:19:00.0000] <miketaylr>
i think i prefer the first, but that's probably just an arbitrary personal preference

[18:19:01.0000] <ment>
uh... but topping=a&topping=b would get parsed by webserver as topping=b ...?

[18:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
ment: only if the webserver is buggy

[18:24:00.0000] <ment>
how it should be passed to application then? like an array?

[18:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's up to the application

[18:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
webservers that implement CGI just pass the data to the script unparsed

[18:27:00.0000] <ment>
i understand html 5 doesn't cover this, i'm just curious about the standard behaviour of scripting languages

[18:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
in perl, CGI.pm seems to offer it in a variety of forms, including an array form

[18:28:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
PHP has a special behavior to handle it.  name="topping[]" makes it collect the values into a $_POST['topping'] array.

[18:28:02.0000] <ment>
for example, let's say some binding parses those multiple key=val1&key=val2 as an array

[18:28:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Without the [] on the name, though, it just gives you the last one.

[18:29:00.0000] <ment>
then key=a is is string, key=a&key=b is an array

[18:29:01.0000] <ment>
TabAtkins: that seems reasonable

othermaciej: are your demos stable for use as bug report test cases?

[00:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: it was a pain to get the network stack to truly respect not sending as credentials

[00:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I was planning to tweak them a little to behave a little better in other browsers (by slightly defeating the original design intent)

[00:46:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: but I can refrain from checking in that change, or check in new versions under different URLs

[00:46:02.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, bugger

[00:47:00.0000] <annevk>
/me would love to nuke it

[00:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: I think part of the reason we added it in the first place is that we didn't want cross-site requests with credentials to be the default

[00:49:01.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: I guess it does seem a little silly to have three modes, but no-credentials with-Origin mode is mildly useful for semi-public data sources

[00:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: where you don't have to be a specific user but they would like to log what domains are accessing it and perhaps limit that

[00:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: nevermind, I'm not going to change these, too hard to make it perfect in all browsers

[00:51:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it looks like Opera and Firefox won't focus elements that are visibility: hidden either

[00:54:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: ok. I'll file a bug about the hover thing

[00:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I'm not 100% sure if it's even a bug per CSS that a relative positioned table doesn't count as a containing block for its absolute positioned descendants

[00:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: ok, after checking the CSS spec, I think it is: <http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/visudet.html#containing-block-details>

[00:57:00.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, in that case you might as well accept credentials too and just ignore them

[00:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: I don't even properly remember the full debate we had about this

[00:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: but I remember we argued about it a long time

[00:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I would be very hesitant to change it now, because anyone who has coded against the current spec has a potential security hole if we transparently change the default on sending credentials

[00:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: I think parts of the reasons for the original decision are:

[00:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
- if a server responds with Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true, it can't use Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * it has to echo back the specific origin

[00:59:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so servers that allow credentials can't use *, which would be inconvenient

[01:00:00.0000] <annevk>
but they can use null

[01:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
- you can't talk to a server that doesn't use Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true if you send credentials

[01:00:02.0000] <annevk>
which works for the globally unique identifier origin

[01:00:03.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: filed https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=546596

[01:01:00.0000] <annevk>
that's true

[01:01:01.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: if you had to use anon to talk to any server that doesn't allow credentials, that would break any existing use of cross-site XHR without the credentials flag, and it would make it impossible to have semi-public resources

[01:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: commented

[01:04:01.0000] <annevk>
it does not limit anything on the server side of things afaict

[01:04:02.0000] <annevk>
it might break some existing usage of the API, yes

[01:04:03.0000] <annevk>
but not everyone implements it yet so I'm not sure how much weight we should give that

[01:05:00.0000] <annevk>
preferably not much

[01:05:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the third mode has some value, for one thing it matches exactly what XDR does

[01:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it might not be a huge amount of value, but it doesn't seem so terrible that we should risk breaking compat to remove it

[01:11:00.0000] <annevk>
boo

[01:11:01.0000] <annevk>
oh well

[01:11:02.0000] <annevk>

[01:11:03.0000] <annevk>
that makes a lot of sense

[03:49:00.0000] <csarven>
So, catching up on Storage. Is there any way to implement something like globalStorage?

[03:50:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
cookies?

[03:50:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
window.name can be used to simulate sessionStorage

[03:51:00.0000] <csarven>
Well, cookies won't allow site A to access a cookie set by site B

[03:51:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
true

[03:52:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
does globalStorage allow that?

[03:52:01.0000] <csarven>
I was thinking of being able to store a non-sensitive data that can be accessed globally

[03:52:02.0000] <csarven>
AFAIK, yes

[03:52:03.0000] <csarven>
However, globalStorage is obsolete

[03:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
globalStorage was renamed localStorage and had its API changed a bit

[03:53:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
there's localStorage

[03:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
but it's basically the same thing

[03:55:00.0000] <csarven>
localStorage.setItem('foo', 'bar') from site A. localStorage.getItem('foo') from site B return null

[03:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah it's per-domain for security reasons

[03:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
(globalStorage was too, though you had to specify the domain and there was some level of sharing)

[03:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
you can simulate it using localStorage if you provide a cross-site API using postMessage()

[03:57:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
or CORS?

[03:57:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
or does cors not enable dom access?

[03:58:00.0000] <csarven>
CORS only allows the data for recognized servers

[03:59:00.0000] <csarven>
For open distributed systems, I don't think it will work

[04:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
anyway, time for me to sleep

[04:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
nn

[04:00:02.0000] <csarven>
I don't think postMessage() helps me

[04:01:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
cors can do allow: *, no?

[04:01:01.0000] <annevk>
zcorpan__, it doesn't

[04:01:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
annevk: ok

[04:01:03.0000] <csarven>
Simply wanted site A to set a value and let any other site use that value

[04:01:04.0000] <annevk>
CORS gives access to a single resource, giving access to the DOM would give access to all resources of that origin

[04:01:05.0000] <annevk>
would be quite a big difference

[04:02:00.0000] <annevk>
(plus a bunch of other issues)

[04:07:00.0000] <annevk>
csarven, you could define a postMessage() API that other sites can use, no?

[04:08:00.0000] <csarven>
That follows a centralised model no?

[04:09:00.0000] <annevk>
i suppose

[04:09:01.0000] <csarven>
That is, the other sites shouldn't have to be aware of the site that created the key/value.

[04:09:02.0000] <csarven>
Consider this:

[04:10:00.0000] <csarven>
Site A tries to set a key/value for person's username if there isn't already one in use. If there is one, it can reuse it

[04:12:00.0000] <csarven>
This is sort of like putting some data in your browser so wherever you go, you can carry it around with you. Fill forms etc

[04:13:00.0000] <csarven>
If site A wants to modify the existing key, it can throw a dialog box for the user to decide whether to update it or not. Similar to storing a new password value

[04:15:00.0000] <annevk>
I still don't see the problem

[04:17:00.0000] <csarven>
Do you mean to say that this is a non-issue and that it can be done or that you don't acknowledge this to be a valid problem

[04:18:00.0000] <annevk>
I mean to say that I don't see the problem

[04:19:00.0000] <annevk>
for instance, is there a site B?

[04:19:01.0000] <annevk>
the scenario is not very clear

[04:19:02.0000] <csarven>
heh

[04:20:00.0000] <csarven>
Site A looks for the key, if found, it will use it, otherwise it sets it. Site B looks for the key, if found, it will use it... Site C looks for the key..

[04:21:00.0000] <annevk>
where do they look for this key?

[04:21:01.0000] <csarven>
Wherever the UA is storing it

[04:21:02.0000] <annevk>
what would prevent A from doing something bad with it?

[04:21:03.0000] <csarven>
Site A, B, C .. need not be aware of each other

[04:21:04.0000] <csarven>
That's relative based on the data stored

[04:21:05.0000] <annevk>
I think you need site X that is the storage-broker

[04:22:00.0000] <annevk>
and otherwise, yeah, not possible

[04:22:01.0000] <csarven>
As I've said, if site A wants to update the key, UA can prompt the user.. like it does for passwords

[04:22:02.0000] <annevk>
o_O

[04:23:00.0000] <csarven>
Storage-broker is a centralised model. It doesn't scale well.

[04:24:00.0000] <annevk>
UA is also centralized

[04:24:01.0000] <annevk>
storage-broker would actually work across UAs

[04:24:02.0000] <annevk>
euh, no it wouldn't

[04:24:03.0000] <annevk>
nm

[04:25:00.0000] <csarven>
Even if it did, it would requires site 1...n to be aware of the storage-broker

[04:27:00.0000] <csarven>
So, do you see the problem now?

[04:27:01.0000] <annevk>
sure

[04:28:00.0000] <annevk>
but I don't really think this is something worth solving

[04:28:01.0000] <csarven>
Really?

[04:29:00.0000] <annevk>
really

[04:30:00.0000] <csarven>
Consider your UA having profile data can be used by sites for registration or authentication

[04:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
Would people want to share that data automatically with every web site that chooses to ask for it?

[04:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
Seems like it'd be either very restricted data, or else a significant privacy concern

[04:32:00.0000] <csarven>
You can put whatever you want to share in your profile data

[04:32:01.0000] <csarven>
The problem is no different than Geolocation

[04:32:02.0000] <annevk>
sounds like openid

[04:32:03.0000] <csarven>
Site asks for your location and the UA prompts the user if they want to share it or not

[04:32:04.0000] <annevk>
anyway, my mom would never understand this

[04:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
csarven: So the prompt is on reading, not just on writing?

[04:33:01.0000] <csarven>
It can be both

[04:34:00.0000] <csarven>
Writing is obviously opens up potential issues but I think that can be solved by UA's UI

[04:34:01.0000] <csarven>
For instance, the user marks their fullname, username fields to never be asked to be written by a site

[04:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'd expect users would get pretty annoyed with prompts popping up every time an ad iframe tries to read the email addresses from their global profile data, in order to spam them

[04:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
and even more annoyed if it didn't pop up a prompt first

[04:36:00.0000] <csarven>
How do users deal with storing passwords when they login?

[04:36:01.0000] <csarven>
Same problem

[04:36:02.0000] <annevk>
not at all

[04:36:03.0000] <Philip`>
Browsers do it automatically, and don't expose any password storage API to pages

[04:37:00.0000] <csarven>
My response was in respect to user's dealing with UA's prompt

[04:39:00.0000] <csarven>
or even SSL warnings

[04:39:01.0000] <csarven>
Users can manage how they want to deal with that information globally from their UA's settings

[04:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
Is Opera's approach (where you can enter some standard personal information in a settings page, and it fills in forms based on input names or something like that, maybe automatically or when you click a button) insufficient for this?

[04:41:01.0000] <csarven>
The point is to let users store data they want in their UA and have that accessible without any middle-man, storage-brokers, central systems..

[04:42:00.0000] <annevk>
not sure why websites have to get involved in such a feature

[04:44:00.0000] <csarven>
Philip`:  I would say in some ways, yes. What's different is that say you create an account on a federated system, that account username could be accessible by any site in that system (or anyone for that matter)

[04:47:00.0000] <csarven>
Web sites, UA and users wants to get involved in such a feature because it can automate a lot of mundane tasks

[04:48:00.0000] <csarven>
Even entering your email or OpenID URL for some identification

[04:48:01.0000] <csarven>
s/URL/URI

[04:49:00.0000] <csarven>
It helps data to flow in decentralized systems.

[04:49:01.0000] <csarven>
I'm not sure what else I need to say on top of this.. :)

[05:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:35:00.0000] <annevk>

[05:35:01.0000] <Philip`>

[05:35:02.0000] <Philip`>
so they're not going to use fake internal subset doctypes

[05:36:00.0000] <annevk>
mpilgrim, http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9051

[05:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.alistapart.com/articles/customdtd/ - "when you display the file in a browser, the ]> shows up on the screen. There’s no way around this bug, so this approach is right out."

[05:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
so even people following that article will use the safe approach of editing the .dtd file instead

[05:38:01.0000] <Philip`>

[06:57:00.0000] <Crash2108>
Will/does  <video> support streaming video?

[06:57:01.0000] <Crash2108>
And what about webcam and microphone access?

[06:57:02.0000] <Philip`>
As far as I'm aware, the spec supports streaming

[06:58:00.0000] <annevk>
webcam/microphone is post-HTML5

[06:58:01.0000] <Philip`>
so it's up to browser developers to implement whatever streaming protocols are useful

[06:58:02.0000] <Crash2108>
Flash will stick around for that.

[06:59:00.0000] <Crash2108>
What about multicasting?

[07:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
That seems like just a detail of the streaming protocol, that doesn't have any effect at the <video> level

[07:01:00.0000] <Crash2108>
It's in the IPv4-6 spec, but doesn't the application have to support it?

[07:01:01.0000] <Crash2108>
Or is it up to the server and network to support it?

[07:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
It has to be supported everywhere

[07:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
You can't use TCP, so you need some other transport protocol

[07:03:02.0000] <Philip`>
and then you can't use HTTP

[07:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
The network needs to support IP multicast, and the server and client need to support whatever new protocols you put on top of it

[07:04:01.0000] <Crash2108>
That's what I'm saying, shouldn't that be built in to the spec so that servers can relieve some pressure for IPTV?

[07:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
but from HTML's perspective it's just a <video> and a <source> with a non-HTTP URL

[07:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
It should be in some spec (and probably is already in lots), but HTML doesn't seem a relevant place for it

[07:05:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Crash2108: multicast on the Internet scale hasn't been a success so far with non-HTML solutions that support multicast

[07:05:02.0000] <Crash2108>
So it's being open for interpretation just like the actual video codecs.

[07:06:00.0000] <Crash2108>
Key words: so far.

[07:06:01.0000] <Philip`>
The first step is convincing every ISP in the world to enable IP multicasting :-)

[07:06:02.0000] <Crash2108>
IPv6 has better support and it's waiting to be tapped.

[07:06:03.0000] <Philip`>
(and the second step is probably apologising when their networks collapse)

[07:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
If/when people sort out the problems and get it implemented and deployed, it should work without any changes to HTML

[07:09:00.0000] <Crash2108>
ASsuming the browser supports it.

[07:09:01.0000] <Philip`>
Yes

[07:10:00.0000] <Crash2108>
So we're back in the 90s in that regard to just hope they all support similar features.

[07:10:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:11:00.0000] <Crash2108>

[15:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
As far as I can tell the only reason to advocate PING is that some of the people who think that links making POST requests is bad might be confused by having something that acts like POST but is spelled differently

[15:06:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[03:14:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: what's with meta charset?

[03:15:00.0000] <zcorpan>
/me wonders why the sublime player doesn't work in opera

[03:25:00.0000] <zcorpan>
/me files https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=546905

[03:29:00.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: the interaction with document's script-examinable charset, document.write and location.reload()

[03:30:00.0000] <hsivonen>
and scripts blocking the parsing of document.written content

[03:30:01.0000] <hsivonen>
in Gecko (old parser), meta charset in synchronously-parsed document.write doesn't cause renavigation 

[03:31:00.0000] <hsivonen>
but if an external script has blocked parsing and the document.written meta charset is parsed as an event loop task later, it can cause a charset renavigation

[03:31:01.0000] <zcorpan>
renavigation really sucks

[03:31:02.0000] <hsivonen>
to a stream that contains the concatenation of the document.write arguments

[03:31:03.0000] <hsivonen>
it sure does

[03:32:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I was told Gecko ignored meta charset in document.write, so I implemented that

[03:32:01.0000] <hsivonen>
but things are a bit more complicated

[03:32:02.0000] <zcorpan>
do you log in the error console when you do renavigation?

[03:32:03.0000] <hsivonen>
nope

[03:33:00.0000] <hsivonen>
renavigating a document.open()ed stream implicitly scares me

[03:33:01.0000] <hsivonen>
but changing things scares me too

[03:42:00.0000] <zcorpan>
/me also files http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=36120 and https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=35088

[05:30:00.0000] <hsivonen>
http://www.w3.org/QA/2010/02/working_group_publication_requ.html#c186978

[05:54:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: in the dom api, NaN means unknown and Infinite means infinite. but a browser can't tell the difference between a streaming resource and a normal resource when the server doesn't support byte range requests, i think

[05:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
Seems like a Content-Duration header ought to handle that case

[05:55:01.0000] <Philip`>
so that UAs do have some way to know

[05:56:00.0000] <Dashiva>
1*DIGIT | 'Infinity' | 'NaN'

[05:56:01.0000] <zcorpan>
yeah

[05:56:02.0000] <zcorpan>
1*DIGIT ["." 1*DIGIT]? | ...

[05:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
You don't need anything explicit for unknown, you can just not send the header

[05:58:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:58:01.0000] <Philip`>

[05:59:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[10:48:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me needs to stop trying to understand Dijkstra's algorithm and go home

[10:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
Dijkstra's algorithm is fun

[10:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
You just add into your set whatever vertex is closest to your current set, and then repeat until finished - it's not that complicated really :-)

[10:51:00.0000] <gsnedders>
So if I know the distance of every node from the initial, and I ahve a specific destination, how do I get the shortest path from it?

[10:52:00.0000] <gsnedders>
I guess I just follow the path of the shortest distance

[10:53:00.0000] <gsnedders>
You need to know which node from each node gives the shortest distance, though

[10:53:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Right?

[10:54:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me should just steal someone at work tomorrow with a CS degree who thinks they understand it?

[10:54:01.0000] <Philip`>
Every time you add a new node into the set, or reduce its cost, you store a link to its predecessor node

[10:54:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Yeah

[10:54:03.0000] <Philip`>
and when you reach the destination you trace backwards over those links

[10:54:04.0000] <gsnedders>
That's what I mean

[10:55:00.0000] <gsnedders>
At the first time you reach the destination?

[11:01:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Yes, I think

[11:01:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Is that right?

[11:01:02.0000] <Philip`>
You only ever 'reach' a node when it's the closest unvisited node to your current visited nodes

[11:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
so when you first reach the destination, all other unvisited nodes must be further away

[11:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
so a path through them cannot be better

[11:02:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Indeed

[11:02:03.0000] <gsnedders>
That's what I thought

[11:02:04.0000] <gsnedders>
Yay

[11:32:00.0000] <franksalim>
who knows the latest about ByteArray in ECMAScript?

[11:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: Do you understand the A* algorithm?

[11:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dijkstra's is just A* with the heuristic always returning 0.

[11:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Which, since 0 will always underestimate the actual distance, is guaranteed to find a shortest path, per normal A* rules.)

[11:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I can't find it now.  I want that picture.  :(

[11:55:00.0000] <miketaylr>

[11:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[11:58:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
(if you've not already seen it)

[12:18:00.0000] <Philip`>

[12:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:12:00.0000] <franksalim>

[13:18:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
Actually, other than backwards compat, is there a reason there should be a default button at all?

[13:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sidnicious: Is there a reason there *shouldn't* be a default button?  I use the fact that forms will submit with their default button all the time when I'm cruising the web.

[13:29:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
TabAtkins: Submit, yes, use a default button, no. Especially if default means first-in-tree-order, not the-one-that-the-developer-decides-is-default.

[13:29:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And if the developer doesn't know how to set a default/doesn't know you can/doesn't care/doesn't exist anymore?

[13:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I see the appeal of being *able* to specify a default button, but you shouldn't *rely* on such a specification when we already have a perfectly serviceable default behavior.

[13:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
Authors will be less surprised if everyone submits the form via the button - it stops them forgetting about the case where the user hits enter instead of clicking

[13:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and so e.g. it works as expected if they have <input type=submit disable> in the form)

[13:31:01.0000] <Sidnicious>
I like the behavior of forms without submit buttons: just submit the darn thing without pretending that a button was clicked.

[13:32:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
The current behavior just takes away information, makes it impossible to tell the difference without nasty JavaScript hacks.

[13:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
What difference?  Between the user hitting Enter, and them clicking the first-submit-input-in-tree-order?

[13:35:01.0000] <Sidnicious>
Correct.

[13:36:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Why do you care about that difference?  (I understand caring about *which* submit button was pressed in javascript, which you've brought up before.)

[13:38:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
Google has the "Google Search" button on the left, and the "I'm Feeling Lucky" button on the right of their search page, but what if the designer had wanted them the other way around?

[13:39:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
The Mac OS traditionally has the default button in a form on the right, with the alternate buttons filling in to the left.

[13:39:01.0000] <Sidnicious>
Linux, too.

[14:54:02.0000] <Traveler1>
Do you guys recommend to add a header tag around the hgroup?

[14:55:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: no worries, it happens all the time ;)

[14:55:01.0000] <sicking>
just kidding

[14:55:02.0000] <Traveler1>
<hgroup> <h1>title</h1> <h2>subtitle</h2> </hgroup>

[14:55:03.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: where at?

[14:55:04.0000] <Traveler1>
Should I add an extra header tag?

[14:55:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you don't need it, don't add it.

[14:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Most <hgroup>s aren't part of a <header>

[14:56:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
.

[14:56:02.0000] <Traveler1>
Hm

[14:56:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, <header> isn't needed most of the time.  It's just for when you are grouping a bunch of stuff into a "header".

[14:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Generally speaking, don't use extra tags unless you have some particular reason.  It's largely pointless.

[14:57:01.0000] <Traveler1>
Right.

[14:57:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
On the other hand, if you're going to end up putting in a <div id=header> or similar, might as well use <header> there.

[14:57:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Exactly.

[14:57:04.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: the websocket thing

[14:57:05.0000] <Traveler1>
No way, as AryehGregor said, no point.

[14:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm not saying definitely do it.  Just if you are planning on grouping things like that, then use <header> rather than a <div>.  <header> was introduced *precisely* to replace that sort of <div> usage.

[14:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So for instance, I use a <header> on aryeh.name because I want to have possibly a few headings at the top of the page, with a particular background and such, so I need an extra element.  So I made it <header> instead of <div id=header> or something.

[14:59:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hmm, looks like I can swap from using this single display table (to get a good two-column layout) to using display:table pretty painlessly.  It handles itself pretty well in IE7 when I patch it with float.

[15:00:00.0000] <Traveler1>
What about if I have two links on the header? Should I use a nav tag? Btw the links are just for viewing the page in english or another lang

[15:01:00.0000] <Traveler1>
nvm

[15:01:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If they are navigation for the site, use <nav>.  If not, don't.  ^_^

[15:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Man, why didn't I do this earlier?  The layout table is now officially banished from my company's site.  I just need to push a bit further and do the new sectioning elements rather than divs, and I'll be happy leaving this company.

[20:09:04.0000] <drclue>

[20:10:00.0000] <drclue>

[20:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
p { display: block; margin: 1.0em 0px; }

[20:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that is the line of CSS that gives the <p> element its default layout behavior in WebKit

[20:12:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it comes from the file html.css

[20:12:02.0000] <drclue>
The style of that P element is that it is a block with a margin, and is indeed style

[20:12:03.0000] <boblet>
foolip: I’ve got some more Live Microdata feedback…

[20:12:04.0000] <othermaciej>
drclue: that style is what controls its layout

[20:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you put that same style on a <div> or <span>, and it lays out the same

[20:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
the way <p> is different is semantics, not layout

[20:13:02.0000] <othermaciej>
<p> means the contents are a paragraph, but <div> or <span> would not indicate anything specific about the contents

[20:14:00.0000] <drclue>
I could with layout indicate that the order of appearance and placement in the tree of the P element involved is one thing while the style of tha rendering is another

[20:14:01.0000] <boblet>

[20:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[20:34:00.0000] <drclue>

[20:36:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I see you arguing previously that HTML's role is 'layout'.  Why do you say this?  At what point was HTML ever any sort of layout language, except by default (because CSS wasn't mature enough to do so yet)?

[20:41:00.0000] <drclue>
HTML is a structural beast as relates to it's nature , CSS is the paint or style you apply to that structure. At times the lines can blur a bit as one reaches into the realm of the other, but they really do have their basic natures. At times , even in spec they have over-reached, like for example tables. When the spec changed , I complied but it was wrong , which is why it has never really worked all that well. TABLES belong to HTML, just

[20:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Indeed, tables do belong to HTML, because "tabular data" is a unique semantic that doesn't exist elsewhere.  It's very useful to be able to indicate that a set of data is correlated along two different axes.

[20:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
On the other hand, table *layout* is part of a CSS module, and capable of being used on any element to provide the layout you want.  Grid-like constraint-based layout is useful outside of presenting tabular data.

[20:46:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(I use the table layout module, for example, to produce an attractive two-column layout on my company's site.)

[20:53:00.0000] <drclue>
Well , that two column layout IMHO should have been the MULTICOL tag introduced originally as the vendor specific offering of Netscape.

[20:53:01.0000] <drclue>
This was a structural layout item and made sense. No matter the size of the display device the general layout was consistent. Using tables or kin

[20:53:02.0000] <drclue>
sorta requires one to decide the size and dimensions of the display which is really wrong. If one takes their time and distributes the work load properly the desktop rendering should by and large work just as well in almost any other medium

[20:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nah, multicol is wrong.  For example, I want in some cases to be able to control the number of column based on the screen width - 1 column for small screens, 2 or 3 columns for wider screens.  This has *nothing* to do with the document itself; it's entirely a styling issue.

[20:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In fact, excellent example, the translation application for my company's software can list over 20 languages.  The name of a language isn't very wide, so it's ideal to present in multiple columns, but obviously you don't want to make the column too small so it starts wrapping the name.  That's just silly.

[20:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So I do a little "ul.lang-list{ column-width: 20em; }" or whatever, and it automatically adjusts.

[20:57:01.0000] <drclue>
OK , so you want to contrive several versions of your output or inject function into presentation. I myself would not do same. I might have a collapse option on the multicol  but other than that I would rather have the multicol element

[00:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan: it's easy to add them to the schema, it's just that currently all the obsolete attributes are in a legacy.rnc file that's not in the "valid" schema repository but is copied over by the build

[00:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
in consideration of the case of uses of the schema outside of v.nu

[00:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so the legacy.rnc file is just something that v.nu uses internally

[00:44:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
but the embed.attrs.other pattern is not in the legacy file

[00:44:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
it's part of the valid schema

[00:46:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and the particular nature of the embed.attrs.other pattern is such that there's no way to just append attribute names to in in the legacy file

[00:47:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the legacy file would need to basically completely refine it in whole

[00:47:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and it's a long list of attribute names

[00:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and maintaining it in two different places would be error-prone

[00:48:01.0000] <zcorpan>
i see

[00:48:02.0000] <zcorpan>
/me suggests doing whatever is simplest :)

[01:13:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[01:54:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:55:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:55:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:55:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:56:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:56:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:57:00.0000] <hsivonen>

hsivonen, zcorpan - well, after a little more poking around and thanks to finding wakaba_'s http://suika.fam.cx/~wakaba/wiki/sw/n/dataformatas page, I notice that the dataformatas, etc., attributes were never global in HTML4 anyway

[02:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the reserved PE was only referenced by span, div, input, select, textarea, button, table, object

[02:45:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so it seems the spec should list those explicitly instead of stating "...on any element"

[03:43:01.0000] <gsnedders>
That seems awfully slow

[03:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
(which is like six dot products per tile)

[03:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
(or an isPointInPath which isn't much faster)

[03:44:01.0000] <gsnedders>
It seems like there should be some constant time way of doing it

[03:44:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: The dot product? How does that work?

[03:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
Well sure if you literally just have a grid you can calculate which hexagon you are in with some formula

[03:45:01.0000] <jgraham>
But you said "easiest"

[03:45:02.0000] <Philip`>
For constant time, I guess you could calculate x mod hex-width, y mod hex-height, and then do a few line comparisons to work out which relative tile it's in

[03:46:00.0000] <gsnedders>
s/easiest/easiest but not gratutiously expensive/

[03:46:01.0000] <Philip`>
and then add that to floor(x / hex-width) etc

[03:46:02.0000] <Philip`>
or something along those lines

[03:46:03.0000] <gsnedders>
http://www.gamedev.net/reference/articles/article747.asp#MOUSE

[03:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: If the point is outside the hexagon, then there's a side of the hexagon which you could extend to infinity and the point would be on the outside of that line

[03:47:01.0000] <Philip`>
and you can detect whether a point is outside by doing a dot-product with the perpendicular and checking the sign, or something equivalent

[03:47:02.0000] <Philip`>
so you just do that for each side

[03:47:03.0000] <Philip`>
and if it's not outside any side, it must be inside the shape

[03:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Should work for any convex shape, I believe)

[03:49:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me will someday learn maths

[03:49:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: (the concept of being "outside a line" doesn't make much sense)

[03:50:00.0000] <jgraham>
(on its own)

[03:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: "On the opposite side of the line to the center of the shape which we are considering"

[03:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: Anyway, probably quickest to wrap the mouse coordinates to the smallest rectangular tiling region (which won't be the size I said, because I was stupid) and just do half a dozen line comparisons in there

[03:52:01.0000] <Philip`>
...like that gamedev.net thing except use maths instead of bitmaps to determine the region

[03:53:00.0000] <Philip`>
(By "half a dozen" I think I mean "five")

[09:56:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I noticed that the WHATWG example for HTML5 shows <nav><h2>Navigation</h2> ... </nav> without an <h1>

[09:56:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Why is that?

[09:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
The absolute values of the numbers are meaningless

[09:57:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Only relative values matter)

[09:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
So I guess the example is attempting to demonstrate that it's valid to do that

[09:58:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also, using lower numbers sometimes can be helpful for no-CSS display in legacy browsers.

[09:58:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So <h1> or <h2> would have been fine, it's completely arbitrary unless relative to another <h*>

[10:00:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I've read somewhere that <hgroup> is a specialised form of <header>, but that would not appear true.

[10:00:01.0000] <Dashiva>
<hgroup> is for grouping headers and subheaders

[10:00:02.0000] <Dashiva>
So they aren't interpreted as separate headings

[10:00:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nah, it's just a way to group multiple <hn> into a single heading, so it won't mess up the outline.

[10:01:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Right, that's what I thought.

[10:01:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
That's how we're using them.

[10:10:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Okay guys, let me share my "strategy" for HTML5 in our product.

[10:10:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I can pastie it, actually.

[10:11:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
http://pastie.org/833062

[10:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why bother with <html>, <head>, <body>?

[10:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
They're implicit.

[10:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You don't need the /> in the meta, <meta charset="UTF-8"> will work fine.

[10:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, why <header id="header">?  What's the id needed for?

[10:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Likewise <nav id="navigation">, etc.

[10:14:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Part of the point of those elements is so you don't need those id's.

[10:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You also have some div wrappers of unclear purpose -- do you need those for styling?

[10:15:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, yes the div wrappers are there for style guys to muck around with the content.

[10:16:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
the IDs are important because they target a particular singular instance versus a generic element which can exist elsewhere in the site.

[10:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
Calling them something like id="main-header" might help disambiguate them, and stop people asking why that header is header and other headers aren't header

[10:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or you could put a class or id on the body element and use that.

[10:17:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So you'd only need one class instead of lots of id's.

[10:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or, better yet, just stick with no id's or classes at all until you actually need them.  That's what I've done so far for my personal site, although admittedly it only has a few pages.

[10:18:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, I don't see how that would be easier AryehGregor, I'd still end up having .someBodyClassName > div > header or something to specifically target those elements, that's what IDs and classnames are for.

[10:18:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I've used "body > header" to target my top-level stuff.

[10:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Me too.

[10:18:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's what selectors are for.

[10:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Especially if you don't need IE support, then you barely need classes/ids at all.

[10:19:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
We'll need IE support.

[10:19:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Also, it's easier for a web designer to target an ID than moving through selectors.

[10:19:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, IE6 is the problem there.  Doesen't support child selectors.

[10:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So an #id helps there.

[10:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah.  Sigh.

[10:20:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, not to mention that it's easier to develop on.

[10:21:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
id is implicit that it is unique to the page, the only instance, therefore #header and #footer mean "The ONE header" and "The ONE footer"

[10:41:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Okay updated @ http://pastie.org/833113

FF3.5, Safari 4, and Opera 10 follow the redirect where IE8 and Chrome 4 ignore it. I figured I would raise this behavior here so folks are aware of it. [16:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
Incidentally, I believe that regexp won't work because " " matches "\s*[^"'>]"

[16:00:01.0000] <zcorpan>
oh forgot \s in there

[16:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think \s*+[^"'>] ought to work

[16:01:01.0000] <Philip`>
using Java's possessive quantifiers

[16:01:02.0000] <zcorpan>
i don't know what that means, but if it's equivalent then i guess it's good

[16:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
It means it'll match as much of \s as possible, and not back off

[16:02:01.0000] <zcorpan>
ah

[16:02:02.0000] <Philip`>
(so there will never be any whitespace left for the [...] to match)

And now Moz has implemented experimental support for it, so if I end up still tweaking it a bit, things will be fine when they do the unprefixed version too.

[15:34:01.0000] <btipling>
and in Chrome Audio elements are never garbage colleged, they just continue to eat up cpu even after you have no reference to them anymore

[15:34:02.0000] <btipling>
collected*

[15:54:00.0000] <btipling>

[15:54:01.0000] <btipling>

[05:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: I have a question about the Webkit default user-agent stylesheet: I notice that it doesn't set text-align on the th element, but if I open Web Inspector and show the inherited properties, it indicates that th has text-align: center inherited from.. somewhere

[05:39:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I don't understand where it's inheriting it from

[05:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: good point - lemme see if I can find out

[05:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: after looking for a while, I can't figure out how th elements get their centering

[05:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: my guess is that it does it in an odd way to avoid interfering with <th align=whatever>

[05:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: since a UA stylesheet rule would (I think) take priority over a presentational attribute, which is supposed to be treated at "presentational hint" priority

[05:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but, I can't see the code that does it at the moment

[05:55:00.0000] <annevk>
presumably th[align] would be implemented as a UA style sheet rule too

[05:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
this is supposed to be the precendence for presentational hints: http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/cascade.html#preshint

[05:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess the only thing special about them is they have specificity 0

[06:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I do not think th[align] in the UA style sheet would correctly implement the requirements for "presentational hints"

[06:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that would have specificity 0,0,1,1

[06:01:00.0000] <annevk>
it's a ua style sheet, they're not part of the CSS cascade

[06:01:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I see, origin takes priority over specificity

[06:01:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess the only technical problem with putting them in the UA stylesheet is that they would override the user stylesheet

[06:01:03.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway

[06:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I can't tell where the text-align: center comes from through code inspection

[06:02:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I could debug it but I don't feel up to it right now

[06:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: thanks for looking at it

[06:03:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I had just been wondering if there was something obvious I was missing, or misunderstanding

[06:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me is late to the party, and just now realized that Opera's implemented Transitions and 2D Transforms.

[06:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
table cells can inherit some properties from their table in a weird way but I don't think that's what is causing this

[06:05:01.0000] <othermaciej>
oh I found it

[06:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>
this is hella weird

[06:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
        // Table headers with a text-align of auto will change the text-align to center.                                             

[06:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
        if (e && e->hasTagName(thTag) && style->textAlign() == TAAUTO)

[06:06:02.0000] <othermaciej>
            style->setTextAlign(CENTER);

[06:06:03.0000] <othermaciej>
in CSSStyleSelector.cpp

[06:06:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I have no idea why it's done that way

[06:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess we want a table header to center even if you explicitly set text-align: auto?

[06:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
"auto" isn't even a standard text-align CSS value

[06:10:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's our implementation of the secret nameless initial value of text-algin

[06:25:00.0000] <jgraham>
* 

[06:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
†

[06:29:00.0000] <annevk>

[07:24:00.0000] <boblet>
hey all, what are context menus? Also, is the contextmenu attribute only for inputs?

[07:26:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
right-click menus, generally.

[07:28:00.0000] <boblet>
TabAtkins: aah, ok

[07:29:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also, no, @contextmenu is a global attribute.

[07:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's just an attribute that points at a <menu> somewhere in the document, which should be presented as a context menu in a UA-specific manner when the user triggers it in a UA-specific manner. (Which is just a popup menu when you right-click in typical UAs.)

[07:30:01.0000] <boblet>
they’d probably normally contain buttons huh

[07:30:02.0000] <boblet>
huh

[07:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Not necessarily.  They could contain <command> or whatnot too.

[07:31:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
\http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/interactive-elements.html#context-menus

[07:31:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Check that example.

[07:31:03.0000] <boblet>
TabAtkins: that’s the trouble, I did :)

[07:31:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Haha.

[07:31:05.0000] <boblet>
guess I don’t make enough web applications

[07:32:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nah, it's something that isn't used enough in typical webapps today.

[07:32:01.0000] <boblet>
ok, thanks for explaining

[07:32:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
But yeah, just assume that it's for producing custom right-click menus on specified elements.  It happens to have usability/accessibility benefits beyond that which come for free.

[07:33:00.0000] <boblet>
the UAs will present in relevant way part? or something more?

[07:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, they can present it in whatever way makes sense for them.

[07:34:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And trigger it based on whatever interaction makes sense for them.

[07:34:02.0000] <boblet>
cool

[07:35:00.0000] <boblet>
/me pines for the web of pages

[07:35:01.0000] <boblet>
I could understand that one

[07:35:02.0000] <boblet>
:)

[07:41:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Now you've got a web of applications, which happens to contain the web of pages as a strict subset.

[07:44:00.0000] <boblet>
TabAtkins: don’t forget the web of data. sheesh, where do I file a complaint that my knowledge is being made less relevant? ;)

[15:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
is there a spec for how HTTP CONNECT works anywhere?

[15:50:00.0000] <Lachy>

[15:50:01.0000] <Lachy>

[15:50:02.0000] <Hixie>

[15:55:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
if i connect to hixie.ch port 80 and send:

[15:55:02.0000] <Hixie>
CONNECT hixie.ch:80 HTTP/1.1 [CRLF][CRLF]

[15:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
i get back a 400 Bad Request

[15:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
but if i connect to hixie.ch port 80 and send:

[15:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
CONNECT hixie.ch:80 garbage [CRLF][CRLF]

[15:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
i get back a 405 Method not Allowed


2010-02-22
[16:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
i really can't see how to make CONNECT work as a handshake

[16:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
(not if we simultaneously try to not violate HTTP)

[16:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
how would a CONNECT handshake violate HTTP?

[16:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
is it forbidden to send a CONNECT request to an origin server?

[16:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
no

[16:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
the problem is the response

[16:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
it consists of an entire 2xx response before the pip is established

[16:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
pipe

[16:12:03.0000] <Hixie>
so basically we're opening a massive hole right at the head of the connection

[16:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you could do the Adam-style handshake after the connection is established

[16:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i guess we'd have to

[16:13:02.0000] <othermaciej>
unless there is some chance that the CONNECT request itself will completely own the server

[16:13:03.0000] <Hixie>
oh i missed your response to that question i asked the other day, btw, i was meeting with one of the hybi chairs

[16:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I do think the Adam-style handshake is more complicated than necessary for its own security

[16:14:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or at least, his original version

[16:14:02.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i don't see why we need to encrypt any useful data

[16:14:03.0000] <othermaciej>
there's no need for the server to generate its own entropy

[16:14:04.0000] <Hixie>
can't we just include a challenge of the form "here's 16 bytes, return them x'ored with each other"?

[16:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
s/'//

[16:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there's a couple of issues with that

[16:15:02.0000] <othermaciej>
1) doesn't increase the likelihood that the server will pay attention to the client's Origin

[16:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
2) no way to differentiate from future protocols using the same approach

[16:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
if the server doesn't pay attention to the origin, he'll include a hard-coded value, which is fine, no?

[16:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
3) required useful data ("this is WebSocket", "here's the Origin") would have to go in a separate response, increasing the number of round trips

[16:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't see how we can do anything that reduces the chances of a server just echoing the origin when they should check it

[16:17:02.0000] <othermaciej>
well let me put it this way

[16:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't follow #3

[16:17:04.0000] <othermaciej>
what do you expect to be in the handshake besides those 16 bytes, if anything?

[16:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Adam's goal was that the whole handshake looks like random bytes if you don't understand it, and thus is highly unlikely to have a specific bad effect on servers

[16:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah well given that the start of the handshake is a CONNECT, there's zero chance of that

[16:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
so i kinda gave up with that goal

[16:18:03.0000] <Hixie>
i guess if we want to do it we still can though

[16:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah I don't know how meaningful it is to do the Adam handshake after a CONNECT

[16:20:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I mean, probably somewhat meaningful just less so

[16:21:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there are a few ways I can think of to simplify server-side implementation of Adam's design without reducing the security:

[16:21:01.0000] <othermaciej>
1) Have the client use a one-time pad as its crypto (i.e. XOR with an equally long key)

[16:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
2) have the server respond with a hash of the client's key and the client's plaintext (perhaps reodering the parts)

[16:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it doesn't even have to be a cryptographically secure hash, could even be CRC, you just want a hash value that's too long to get the right value by chance

[16:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
though I suspect MD5 is more widely available in library form than most simpler hashes with a decent output size

[16:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that removes the server's needs to use a fancy algorithm to decrypt, to produce random bits, and to use a fancy algorithm to encrypt again

[16:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
we can get rid of the need for a library altogether just by having the server xor parts of the key together

[16:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. xor bytes 1,2,3,4 with bytes 5,6,7,8

[16:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
also making the key the right length is easy if you just interleave each byte of the key with the byte of data it's been xored with

[16:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. ABC becomes [k1][k1 xor A][k2][k2 xor B][k3][k3 xor C]

[16:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
and the server's nonce can then just be [k1 xor k2][k3 xor k4]...[k8 xor k16] or something

[16:34:00.0000] <NickYoung>
I hope this isn't supposed to be cryptographically secure..

[16:34:01.0000] <NickYoung>
the security guy in me is seeing the next WEP being created...

[16:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think making the server xor random bytes is probably more of a burden on the server than telling the server to use MD5

[16:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>
NickYoung: it's not supposed to be cryptographically secure

[16:35:02.0000] <NickYoung>
Oh good ;)

[16:35:03.0000] <NickYoung>
also, I disagree with your assertion.. XOR is a single cycle operation

[16:36:00.0000] <NickYoung>
even if you have 20 of them, it will be many thousands times faster than MD5

[16:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
NickYoung: by "burden" I mean difficulty of implementation, not CPU cost of doing the computation

[16:36:02.0000] <NickYoung>
seriously, bitwise -or is difficult to implement? =P

[16:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if you invent a funky custom algorithm then the server can't use a pre-existing library

[16:37:01.0000] <NickYoung>
from what I read, you're just XORing a few bytes...

[16:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, the tricky part is which bytes

[16:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you have to hand-code a loop to do it and have it step in the right increments

[16:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and the reason Hixie wants to do that is because calling a library function to do MD5 or CRC or whatever might be too hard

[16:39:00.0000] <NickYoung>
what's the point of this anyway, to verify you're speaking the correct protocol..?

[16:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
to verify that you are speaking the correct protocol and that the connection is allowed without  opening too much opportunity for cross-protocol attacks

[16:41:00.0000] <NickYoung>
and these 16bits are a nonce?

[16:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I think if your key is variable-length then you need to length-prefix or terminator-delimit the client handshake, so the server knows when it got all of it

[16:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: sure, the last four bytes would decode to CRLFCRLF or some such

[16:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it's meant to be 16 bytes, a 16-bit nonce would be pretty weak

[16:42:01.0000] <NickYoung>
ah, misread

[16:42:02.0000] <NickYoung>
wait

[16:42:03.0000] <NickYoung>
16 bytes?

[16:42:04.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: that would force a requirement to do the "decrypt" operation in streaming mode

[16:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
NickYoung: it's really a variable-length number of bytes, since the plaintext client handshake message is not fixed-length

[16:43:01.0000] <NickYoung>
ah.

[16:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: yes? the whole protocol is a "streaming-mode" protocol

[16:43:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: as opposed to "read known length or up to delimiter and then process"

[16:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
which is how HTTP headers and WebSocket messages are both handled

[16:44:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there is no need to process every single byte to even find the message boundaries

[16:45:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the point is, what you're proposing is not easier to implement than even Adam's original version, given a reasonable set of available libraries

[16:45:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it is in fact harder

[16:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and people could easily get it wrong in subtle ways, e.g. not expect the client handshake to be split in the middle, or to be split on an odd byte

[16:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't mind have a non-encrypted delimiter if you like

[16:46:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I would say it's far better to use well-known algorithms than some weird ad-hoc thing if your goal is to make it easy on custom server implementations

[16:46:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think the delimiter is the biggest problem with your proposal

[16:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
we could even just define the key characters for the last four bytes so that you can do the delimiter check in either mode

[16:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
"run around XORing random bytes together" is not a trivial operation

[16:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
i can't think of a single language i've ever used where it's been anything _but_ trivial

[16:47:03.0000] <othermaciej>
most people who interview with the Safari team would probably fail if presented that problem as an interview question (not that we hire them, but lots of these people think they know how to code)

[16:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't understand the problem here. read byte; if (needkey) key = byte else append(byte xor key); needkey = !needkey;

[16:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
it seems truly trivial

[16:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
am i missing something?

[16:51:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you're missing the loop, the code to detect the terminators, and the code to output the response

[16:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
right, you need those regardless of what we do here

[16:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
also you're not accounting for the fact that the read is asynchronous

[16:52:02.0000] <othermaciej>
s/output/compute/

[16:52:03.0000] <Hixie>

[16:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I do think that even though this doesn't have to be cryptographically secure, it would be wiser to use off-the-shelf algorithms, because the first rule of crypto club is "don't invent your own algorithms"

[17:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
the idea of the nonce coming back from the server is to have the server include something in the response that's verifiable (showing the server knows the protocol) and yet not predictable without controlling the client's handshake, right?

[17:06:02.0000] <othermaciej>
yes

[17:06:03.0000] <Hixie>
a one time pad isn't a new invention

[17:06:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I think a one-time pad for the client request is fine

[17:06:05.0000] <Hixie>
oh for the response, yeah

[17:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(given a suitable way to mark the boundary)

[17:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
ideally I think the response would use an algorithm that doesn't require the server to generate a random number, which is why I thought of hashing instead of encryption

[17:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[17:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
totally agreed on that

[17:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one more thing I thought of, you can't use a fixed set of bytes as a delimiter without forcing some kind of escapting

[17:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
oh, I guess the idea of 0x0 0xD is supposed to be that the plaintext request can't contain byte 0xD, but that's pretty subtle

[17:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I can't think of a good simple way to encode the length without violating the "it looks like random bytes" property

[17:53:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_oww>
Hey guys!

[17:54:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I heard some great questions about HTML5 today and I thought I would share them with the group and get your reactions.

[17:55:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Accessibility: What is the benefit to accessibility with HTML5? Do existing and popular screen-readers have an easier or harder time understanding HTML5 tags? How do they parse the content in IE when they run into an unknown tag?

[17:57:00.0000] <Hixie>
HTML5 improves matters for accessibility, though the various and sundry ways it does that are numerous and difficult to summarise

[17:58:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Hixie, can any of them be mentions or written?

[17:58:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Are they listed on the web?

[17:58:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Or is it theory.

[17:59:00.0000] <boblet>
JonathanNeal: one of the big accessibility improvements is moving a11y stuff from hidden locations (like attributes) to visible locations (like content), so they’re available to everyone, and also to give authors a reason to add them

[18:01:00.0000] <boblet>
an example of this is the great table summary vs caption wars

[18:01:01.0000] <boblet>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/tabular-data.html#attr-table-summary

[18:01:02.0000] <boblet>
another is the ongoing longdesc battle

[18:03:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
HTML5 Accessibility can be measured in battles.

[18:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
JonathanNeal: hidden="", the new <input type>s, removing features that were harming accessibility due to widespread misuse, removing all media-specific presentational features in favour of CSS, making many of the features more explicitly media-independent, etc

[18:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i replied to the issue-88 stuff

[18:06:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
 making many of the features more explicitly media-independent, you mean like the presentational to css stuff?

[18:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: thanks

[18:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
JonathanNeal: i mean like <hr> being redefined to have nothing to do with horizontal rules specifically

[18:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
or <b> and <i> being redefined to make sense in all media, not just visual media

[18:08:02.0000] <boblet>
JonathanNeal: eg em = emphasis to stress emphasis, kbd = keyboard to keyboard and other eg voice input (ie has explicit aural ref plus less UA-specific)

[18:10:00.0000] <boblet>
JonathanNeal: re accessibility battles, it’s a topic on which many people have strongly held and conflicting beliefs :|

[18:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the best features for accessibility are the new controls (both form controls and things that don't participate in form submission but resemble standard application widgets)

[18:11:01.0000] <othermaciej>
because now people won't need to use <div> soup to build those controls

[18:11:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
This is a fun discussion.

[18:15:00.0000] <boblet>
also once UAs (and authors) start using semantic structural elements (nav especially) it’ll make things way more accessible

[18:16:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Should I continue the dialog?

[18:16:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Google and the world of search:

[18:17:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Is there an SEO benefit to HTML5?  Is there one now, or will there be one?  Does Google favor HTML5 markup, over HTML4 markup, or XHTML markup? Does any search engine (such as Bing, Yahoo, etc)?

[18:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
no SEO benefit

[18:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
just make your content useful

[18:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
you'll have much more luck with making your content have high rank in google if you make it something people want, than if you spend the same time trying to do markup tricks

[18:20:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Fair enough, boblet or othermaciej feel free to jump in on that one if you think differently, otherwise I'll move on.

[18:20:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Final section, The Browser Effect:

[18:21:00.0000] <boblet>
although I think it’s fair to say that using good markup will help make the content accessible to people. i suspect there is some search engine benefit to using good markup over tag soup

[18:21:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
How will HTML5 impact browser performance? CSS3 selectors have a quantifiable impact on performance, but do HTML5 tags have any impact on rendering performance? What about in IE; what is the performance impact (in ms and possibly in MB) on having to create the elements via JS on every page load?

[18:22:00.0000] <boblet>
eg Google Lists(?) probably won’t include a list marked up using <p> with <br> in it’s list of related entries suggestions

[18:23:00.0000] <boblet>
I think POSH (plain old semantic HTML) is probably good SEO for free

[18:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't know anything about what search engine algorithms do

[18:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you would have to ask them

[18:25:00.0000] <boblet>
JonathanNeal: i don’t know of any performance impact, and typically something like 90% of the time is spent getting the file (vs processing), so any change on processing will probably be small

[18:25:01.0000] <othermaciej>
HTML5 will probably improve performance in the case where you can use a native HTML5 feature instead of rolling your own with DIV+CSS+JS

[18:26:00.0000] <boblet>
re: IE HTML5 shiv, the JS itself is tiny, and the performance overhead of creating new elements before being able to use them should be tiny compared to something like using jQuery. in current browsers I wouldn’t expect HTML5 (over HTML4 etc) to make a noticeable difference

[18:27:00.0000] <othermaciej>
also using the <video> element may be higher performance than plugin-based video solutions

[18:27:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it really shouldn't make much difference either way in most cases

[18:28:00.0000] <boblet>
JonathanNeal: if you’re worried about performance use YSlow and Smushit—your HTML 

[18:29:00.0000] <boblet>
—HTML differences are tiny compared to image minification and reducing requests

[18:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
appcache is an HTML5 feature that can significantly improve load performance (past the first time)

[18:31:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: the “submit review comment” help message should probably mention that you can receive a reply if you use the same email as bugzilla

[18:31:01.0000] <boblet>
also it munges non-ascii characters

[18:33:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
All of what you guys have said is great, but is there any measurable, documented proof?

[18:33:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Or is there a way you would recommend I make one, such as with yslow, etc?

[18:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
what are you looking for proof of?

[18:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
"how will HTML5 impact browser performace?" is a very open-ended question

[18:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if you formulate a specific hypothesis we can tell you ways to test

[18:35:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
"Do HTML5 tags have any impact on rendering performance?"

[18:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if the question is about using HTML5 at all, without using any new features, you could try the same page with HTML4.01 and HTML5 doctypes to see if there is any difference in load speed (there won't be)

[18:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if you want to see if enabling IE to use the new tags compatibly impacts load time in IE, you can test load times in IE of a page with and without

[18:36:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
How would you test those load times in IE?

[18:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if you want to see if appcache improves cached-case load speed, then that would be a more challenging experiment (to set up the app cache manifest properly etc) but still doable

[18:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you could use a stopwatch

[18:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or if you want to ignore network load time, instrument the page with a <script> to save the current time at the very top of the page (right inside <head> I guess) and then check in the "load" listener how much time elapsed

[18:37:02.0000] <othermaciej>
benchmarking is hard

[18:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
if you want data and not just educated guesses, it will take some work

[00:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: you know, it strikes me that if we just include some data in the encrypted part, then just repeating that information (unencrypted) is actually proof enough that the server is reading the handshake

[00:46:00.0000] <annevk>
Hixie, wasn't the concern with that simple echo thingies?

[00:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
well they'd have to decrypt it

[00:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
which is easy enough, but won't happen unless you really are a websocket server

[00:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: you would need to make sure that part of what they echo back is unpredictable

[00:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
right

[00:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
ideally you want at least one thing to be both unpredictable *and* not verbatim

[00:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
well it wouldn't be verbatim, since it'd be encrypted

[00:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but the data XOR'd with the one-time pad key is all predictable

[00:55:02.0000] <annevk>
what counts as unpredictable? timestamps?

[00:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the key itself is the only unpredictable part

[00:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: random data

[00:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i mean, client sends something like Unique-ID: 312524232362435234521, but in the encrypted part, and the server just has to say that back

[00:56:03.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: random data generated by the browser after JS code transfers control

[00:56:04.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: but the server's returned data is unencrypted

[00:56:05.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: you could do that - then the client is generating two different random numbers

[00:56:06.0000] <Hixie>
right

[00:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one to be the encryption key and one to be the nonce

[00:57:01.0000] <Hixie>
yup

[00:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
they can be generated from the same single truely random number, it's not like they have to be independent

[00:57:03.0000] <Hixie>
so it's not an entropy drain

[00:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the other property Adam was trying to guarantee is that both request and response look like random bytes without WebSocket processing but I don't know offhand why it's important

[00:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[00:58:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: they do have to be independent, XORing a value with itself won't be very random

[00:58:03.0000] <annevk>
btw http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/process-issues/2010Feb/0006.html (W3C Member-only)

[00:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: fair enough

[04:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: about 'should longdesc be considered "obsolete but conforming" or just conforming to a warning'

[04:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: yes?

[04:54:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
what does "just conforming to a warning" mean?

[04:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: it means that it would not be listed in the "obsolete but conforming" section or have that label applied to it, but the practical effect would be the same

[04:55:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
meaning that conformance checkers would still need to warn about it?

[04:55:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it seems like it is effectively creating yet another conformance level

[04:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
well, summary is in a gray zone right now where it's not totally clear which of those buckets it falls into

[04:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Cynthia's change proposal for summary would in fact label it as "obsolete but conforming"

[04:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
my thinking is we should do the same for longdesc

[04:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the effect on validators is pretty much nil, it's just a matter of presentation and spec organization

[04:59:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
perhaps one possible remedy for this is to not use the word "obsolete" in the name of that section, but categorize them as "Conforming features that have specific caveats"

[04:59:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
or something else that is more in the sense of "caveat" rather than "obsoleted"

[05:00:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the spec could mandate the specific warning messages that conformance checkers should emit for those cases

[05:01:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or at least what specific sense the messages should convey

[05:02:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., in general, the sense would be "There is evidence to suggest this element is widely misused, therefore, make sure to use it with care."

[05:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or if not "widely", at least "sometimes"

[05:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
Every feature of the language is sometimes misused

[05:03:02.0000] <Dashiva>
I don't think removing the word obsolete will do anything, it will just shift the battle to removing the new language

[05:03:03.0000] <Philip`>
and everything should be used with care

[05:04:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"Why does this fully conforming and not obsolete feature need a warning?"

[05:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe some need slightly more care than others, so perhaps we could have a care-o-meter that says longdesc rates 80% on the need-to-care index while summary is 70% and <a href> is only 20%

[05:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
Then we wouldn't have to keep drawing and shifting arbitrary lines between features that are good and features that are bad and features that are sort of in the middle so we'll allow them but complain a bit

[05:06:00.0000] <Dashiva>
And instead we get bikeshedding over what number to use for each feature

[05:07:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"Now only 19.95 care"

[05:07:01.0000] <Philip`>

[05:07:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:08:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:08:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:08:02.0000] <Philip`>

[05:09:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:09:01.0000] <Philip`>

[05:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:10:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:10:02.0000] <Philip`>

[05:10:03.0000] <Philip`>

[08:02:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:03:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[10:33:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
We've been running out HTML5 website through a gauntlet of tests.

[10:34:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Screenreaders, performance checkers.

[10:34:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Testing to see how much positive or negative the HTML5 impact has been.

[10:35:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
HTMl5 killed 0 accessibility tests on MAC and PC, including using the EYES and JAWS readers.

[10:36:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
In fact, HTML5 in combination with properly layed-out markup improved accessibility, and use of <nav> tag offered improved accessibility in the JAWS reader.

[10:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ooh, JonathanNeal, could you write up your findings?

[10:37:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
For IE6,7,8 we tested the shiv used to add in support for HTML5 elements in the DOM and CSS.

[10:37:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Especially regarding the results with actual screenreadeers.

[10:37:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, yea and we've been youtub'ing the results.

[10:37:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Awesome.

[10:38:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
You may wanna wait til we've written up our assessments of the results, right now it's scattered.

[10:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk

[10:38:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
We found the HTML5 shiv for IE had an impact of 0.025ms in IE6.

[10:38:03.0000] <miketaylr>
so awesome

[10:39:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
0.015ms in IE8.  We contrast these results with other tests, like document.getElementById, ElementsByTagName.

[10:39:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
We're measuring our existing site search results on Google, Bing, Yahoo, etc to see how the content was picked up.

[10:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[11:09:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, we don't have any formal testing procedure.  The procedure is largely 1) people commit stuff to trunk, 2) users of trunk (mostly developers) hopefully complain when things break, then eventually: 3) test.wikipedia.org is synced to trunk and sysadmins wait a little while to see if there are reports from voluntary testers, 4) all Wikimedia projects are synced to trunk, 5) sysadmins hang around in #wikimedia-tech for a while fieldi

[11:09:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
ng critical bug reports that weren't caught at an earlier stage.

[12:37:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
From an accessibility standpoint, Firefox's implementation is the best.  The visible controls are unique to the paused state of <video> in Chrome and Safari, whereas Firefox will hide the controls once a mouse has passed into and out of a <video>.  If a mouse has not passed into a <video> but keyboard interaction does, the controls remain visible - it's a visible feature triggered by a visible interaction.

[12:53:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[12:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[12:54:01.0000] <tantek>

[12:54:02.0000] <tantek>
also - note that in that case user need should win over author/developer need - per the design principles

[12:54:03.0000] <othermaciej>
aria-describedby defaults to visibility, which is nice

[12:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[12:57:01.0000] <tantek>
no - because alt is visible when you load a browser with images turned off (a common preference in browsers)

[12:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>
do the various <meta name> and <link rel> types without default visible effect count?

[12:57:03.0000] <tantek>
and some browsers show alt while images are loading (e.g. over slow connections)

[12:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok i'll post this to the list later if nobody has any more suggestions in the meantime

[12:58:01.0000] <tantek>
which just demonstrates another curbcut scenario - what was intended for accessibility helps those with slow networks

[12:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Change_Proposal_for_not_including_longdesc%3D""

[12:58:03.0000] <tantek>

[12:59:00.0000] <Hixie>

[12:59:01.0000] <tantek>
link rel is typically programmatic rather than content oriented - like script

[12:59:02.0000] <Dashiva>
"Not including" is probably going to be misunderstood to "not supporting"

[13:00:00.0000] <tantek>
you might argue that the "title" attribute on link is invisible content, but it is only advisory, and in the context of alternate style sheets - for user agents that support them (e.g. Mozilla back in the day), those titles are visible when choosing an alternative

[13:12:00.0000] <tantek>

[13:13:00.0000] <tantek>

[13:13:01.0000] <tantek>

[13:14:00.0000] <tantek>

[17:04:00.0000] <bfrantz>
a few days ago i had mentioned that there is disparity in how FF3.5 (+others) and IE8(+others) treat the entity body when encountering a 404. after some testing it turns out they all (opera, chrome, safari, ie, firefox) respect the entity body provided it is over 512bytes.  again, i'm unsure if html5 is the place to document or standardize on the "correct" behavior but thought I would provide the update for those interested.

[23:55:00.0000] <roc>
MikeSmith: we knew about the problem Hallvord talks about

[23:56:00.0000] <roc>
none of the proposed solutions are very good

[23:56:01.0000] <roc>
so we decided to tackle the problem head-on by exposing style.filter in Firefox and seeing how bad the compatibility problem is

[23:57:00.0000] <roc>
if the problem isn't bad, or we can persuade sites to fix their detection logic, then the Web wins. If the problem is really bad and unfixable, then we'll back off and nothing is really lost. Hallvord should be thanking us :-)

[23:57:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
interesting

[23:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
have you gotten much feedback or data yet on sites breaking?

[23:58:01.0000] <roc>
not yet

[23:58:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:58:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:58:04.0000] <roc>

[23:58:05.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:58:06.0000] <roc>

[23:59:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
