[02:43:00.0000] <annevk>
Hixie, I'm not sure whether XHR origin is always equal to Document origin

[02:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
when would it not be?

[02:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's not XHR origin that matters, it's script origin, surely

[02:45:00.0000] <annevk>
if that's true there's no need for an XHR origin

[02:45:01.0000] <annevk>
annoyingly I forgot the original scenario

[02:46:00.0000] <annevk>
maybe the origin always matched and it was just the base URL that was a different concept

[02:47:00.0000] <annevk>
the base URL coming from the Document of which the Window object had the XHR constructor object

[02:47:01.0000] <annevk>
hmm, so maybe I should kill XHR origin in favor of HTML5 script origin

[02:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
origin is new, right?

[02:48:00.0000] <annevk>
new?

[02:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
like, not implemented before you started adding stuff

[02:49:00.0000] <annevk>
the Origin header you mean?

[02:49:01.0000] <annevk>
/me is a bit confused

[02:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
me too

[02:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
i'm talking about whatever you pass the 'fetch' algorithm

[02:49:04.0000] <Hixie>
i think that's only for Origin header purposes

[02:49:05.0000] <Hixie>
so yeah, the header

[02:50:00.0000] <annevk>
right, that's new, but it would make sense if it matched what I defined to be "XMLHttpRequest origin"

[02:50:01.0000] <annevk>
I'm realizing the concept of "XMLHttpRequest origin" might not be needed; i.e. just XMLHttpRequest base URL is needed

[02:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
ah

[02:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not familiar enough with XHR to say one way or the other

[02:52:00.0000] <annevk>
my point was that if "XMLHttpRequest origin" is justified, the Origin header from HTML5 fetch needs to match what it says

[02:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
not necessarily

[02:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
a lot of the checks for script origin use the "effective origin" which is made using document.domain

[02:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
whereas the Origin: header is always made from the original origin

[02:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
which one does XHR use?

[02:53:04.0000] <Hixie>
can you XHR to the document.domain domain?

[02:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
i guess not, since you need a port and once you set document.domain you have no port

[02:55:00.0000] <annevk>
XHR does not care about document.domain

[02:55:01.0000] <annevk>
ah, but thanks for bringing that up

[02:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
even for the cross-document accesses?

[02:56:01.0000] <annevk>
so you have an iframe foo.example.org and a normal page bar.example.org

[02:56:02.0000] <annevk>
both set document.domain

[02:56:03.0000] <annevk>
to example.org

[02:56:04.0000] <annevk>
bar.example.org has the iframe

[02:56:05.0000] <Hixie>
so now foo can sent Origin: bar using bar's XHR?

[02:56:06.0000] <annevk>
bar.example.org then gets the XHR constructor out of foo.example.org

[02:56:07.0000] <annevk>
the request you make with that XHR is based on origin bar.example.org

[02:57:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok, good

[02:57:01.0000] <Hixie>
then you're using the entry script

[02:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
('s document's origin)

[02:57:03.0000] <annevk>
the script runs on foo.example.org, no?

[02:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
you said bar.example.org then gets the XHR constructor, so i presume the entry script is from bar

[02:58:01.0000] <annevk>
damn it, I missed up

[02:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
but what happens if you pass the object to foo?

[02:58:03.0000] <Hixie>
does the same object then change origin?

[02:58:04.0000] <annevk>
foo.example.org gets a constructor out of bar.example.org and uses it, the origin is bar.example.org

[02:58:05.0000] <Hixie>
as in, is it the caller that decides the Origin: header, or the object?

[02:58:06.0000] <Hixie>
oh

[02:58:07.0000] <Hixie>
that's not the entry script then

[02:58:08.0000] <annevk>
right

[02:58:09.0000] <Hixie>
quite different from how Origin: works in HTML5

[02:59:00.0000] <annevk>
the origin and base URL of XHR are determined by where its constructor comes from

[02:59:01.0000] <Dashiva>
What if you use the XMLHttpRequest object from a different window?

[02:59:02.0000] <annevk>
yes, same for base URL

[02:59:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Oh, that's what you meant

[03:00:00.0000] <annevk>
therefore I was saying that fetch should be modified somehow so that Origin matches the XHR origin

[03:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
Origin? or Referer?

[03:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
you pass in the value for Origin, so that's not a problem

[03:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
Referer however comes from the script currently

[03:02:00.0000] <annevk>

[09:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[10:51:01.0000] <rektide>

[10:52:00.0000] <rektide>

[10:52:01.0000] <rektide>

[10:55:00.0000] <annevk>
does a spec example work?

[11:06:00.0000] <zcorpan>
rektide: you need to call postMessage on the 'connect' event's port; the 'message' event doesn't have .ports

[11:08:00.0000] <zcorpan>
rektide: you could store a reference to the port by doing onconnect = function(e) { self.port = e.ports[0];

[11:13:00.0000] <zcorpan>
rektide: or maybe 'message' has ports

[11:14:00.0000] <zcorpan>
but it might be null

[11:18:00.0000] <zcorpan>
onconnect = function(event) {

[11:18:01.0000] <zcorpan>
  var port = event.ports[0]

[11:18:02.0000] <zcorpan>
  port.onmessage = function(event) {

[11:18:03.0000] <zcorpan>
    port.postMessage('pong')

[11:18:04.0000] <zcorpan>
  }

[11:18:05.0000] <zcorpan>
  port.postMessaage("connect")

[11:18:06.0000] <zcorpan>
};

[11:20:00.0000] <dimich>
Interesting that WebKit nightly actually reports the correct errors for rektide's URL

[11:20:01.0000] <dimich>
But Chrome does not. A bug.

[11:22:00.0000] <zcorpan>
opera says

[11:22:01.0000] <zcorpan>
Type mismatch (usually non-object value supplied where object required)

[11:22:02.0000] <zcorpan>
stacktrace:   In function .onconnect

[11:22:03.0000] <zcorpan>
    [source code not available]

[11:22:04.0000] <zcorpan>
  ...

[11:22:05.0000] <zcorpan>
URL: http://rektide.voodoowarez.com/2010/2/pong.js

[11:22:06.0000] <zcorpan>
Context: Web Worker exception

[11:22:07.0000] <zcorpan>
Time: Tue Feb 23 2010 20:27:55 GMT+0100

[11:43:00.0000] <zcorpan>
rektide: btw, you also need to call worker.port.start() if you're using addEventListener (as opposed to worker.port.onmessage, which calls start() implicitly)

[11:44:00.0000] <zcorpan>
rektide: otherwise the messages are on a queue waiting for the port to be enabled

[21:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
seems like the only intuitive way to implement "mouse over" equivalent on touchscreen devices is to also have a proximity sensor on the device that can detect when you are actually hovering over something with your finger 

[21:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
there is a big irony in the fact that the prevalent GUI conventions are modeled on physical desktop conventions that can't currently be implemented practically on devices that provide a greater degree of real physical interaction with the UI (through the touchscreen) rather than through the abstraction of a separate pointing device

[00:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
before the resource

[00:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
that would make it _so_ much harder to screw up the server-side implementation of this

[00:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
definitely seems like it would reduce the attack surface

[00:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
something like "WS012 /resource/ HTTP/1.1"

[00:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
where the three digits have to be converted to a number by parsing them as a decimal

[00:55:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: so what is preventing you from doing that?

[00:55:02.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: in all sincerity, I am pretty dubious of the prospects for or even usefulness of an incompatible replacement for cookies, but it's probably not *quite* as silly as an incompatible replacement for HTML

[00:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: seems like it would be a pain for HTTP servers to dispatch on, if they dispatch based on method

[00:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
and then some other number has to be divided by that number, so even if the implementor really screws it up, the number they get will be zero, and the division will crash the server rather than let it be attacked

[00:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: also, I am sure it would make the HTTP gods furious with hot anger

[00:56:03.0000] <Hixie>

[11:06:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
The <command> element is buggy in Firefox.  It is documented and validates only as self closing tag, but Firefox will not close the tag without a </COMMAND>.  So, you can pick your poison; you can not use the element all-together, you can markup the element as a self-closing tag and suffer the Firefoxequences, or you can add the closing tag and ignore validation all-together.

[11:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, can't you put it in another tag, so when Firefox hits the wrapper's close tag, it will close it?

[11:13:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, <command /> will not close, so the next <command /> will be a child of the previous.

[11:13:01.0000] <Philip`>
JonathanNeal: I expect he means <div><command></div>

[11:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
(or similar)

[11:14:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
The next element will be a child of <command, until it is closed by some other means.

[11:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
What does <div><command></div><div><command></div> do, or whatever?  Does that make sense here?

[11:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me isn't clear on how or why one would use <command> in practice, so isn't sure if that makes sense.

[11:15:01.0000] <Philip`>
Why does it matter how Firefox parses it, given that the functionality is not implemented?

[11:15:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
And right, does it matter how it gets parsed?

[11:15:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Say: <menu type="toolbar">

[11:15:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<command onclick="insertTag(buttons, 0);"  label="strong" icon="bold.gif"/>

[11:15:05.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<command onclick="insertTag(buttons, 1);"  label="em" icon="italic.gif"/>

[11:15:06.0000] <JonathanNeal>
</menu>

[11:16:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Ah crap, XChat didn't catch the line returns, sorry.

[11:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So why can't they just be nested in Firefox?

[11:16:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I mean, they're invisible anyway, aren't they?  Or are you styling them somehow?

[11:16:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
<div> or <span> wrappers should fix it, anyway.

[11:16:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, nested as in each command being a child of the previous?

[11:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah.

[11:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
What's making these visible at all?

[11:17:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, then the styling would get in the way.

[11:17:03.0000] <Philip`>
It seems a bad idea to use those elements at all, because the spec might change (given that there's no implementations yet, as far as I'm aware)

[11:17:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, I would very strongly advise that you avoid using anything with zero implementations.

[11:17:05.0000] <JonathanNeal>
That is a Catch 22.

[11:17:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, it's not.

[11:17:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
Implementations happen before features are used in authoring.

[11:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
By the time there's implementations, the parsers will have been fixed

[11:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Once there's at least one implementation, you can test in that implementation.

[11:18:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It is the developers who have dictated the implementations.

[11:18:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
That's how this whole mess started.

[11:18:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Huh?

[11:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If authors deploy features without implementations, then implementers may find that the sites break when the feature is actually implemented.

[11:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If your site is big enough, that will hold up their implementation.  If it's not, then your site will break.

[11:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
In any event, you gain nothing by using features that don't exist yet in *any* browser, so what's the point?  Use <input type=image> instead.

[11:20:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, you're referring to Gecko or Webkit implementing <command> ?  Okay, I just wanted to use a recommended element as a child of <menu>

[11:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why do you want to use <menu>?

[11:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
Nobody implements that either :-)

[11:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What Philip` said.

[11:25:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Accessibility and giving better meaning to page controls.

[11:25:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
let me provide an example

[11:25:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
http://sandbox.thewikies.com/liferay-rotating-banner/

[11:25:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
The source downlaods are outdated, but you'll see on that page I'm using <menu> and <command>

[11:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why not just use <nav> and <a>?

[11:28:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, is there some markup that would allow it to be a control but also prevent the screen-reader from listing the control, since it is visual only.

[11:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
JonathanNeal: I think you'd actually need to use <li><command></li> to make that correct, otherwise the content is interpreted as merely "flow content describing available commands" and not as actual commands

[11:29:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Using a screen reader or keyboard navigation, you can already move through all of the banners, so it didn't make sense for it to then list the controls, since the keyboard and screen-reader already provide those controls.

[11:29:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
The controls are for the visually unimpaired only.

[11:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I have no idea, but I'm pretty sure that using a completely unimplemented feature isn't the best way to do it.

[11:29:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
(Maybe the validator should raise a warning when someone does that?)

[12:42:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:42:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
"javascript markup seems like a secondary solution" eg including the controls via js.  I don't think that would help with screenreaders either.

[12:43:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:44:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:44:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[12:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[12:45:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'd bring that up on the list.

[12:47:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Wait, so it's good but bad?

[12:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
You want to use role=presentation.  But it's officially disallowed right now in HTML5 (only <img alt=""> can have it).

[12:48:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Oh, and I want presentational html.

[12:49:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Alternately...  Just use empty elements and/or images with no alt for the controls.  If the controls don't *contain* any content, they can't be read out.

[13:01:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[01:18:01.0000] <Hixie>

[01:44:02.0000] <gsnedders>

[01:47:04.0000] <gsnedders>

[01:48:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[02:12:03.0000] <Hixie>
"Except where otherwise specified, when the user agent creates and dispatches a message event in the algorithms described in the following sections, the lastEventId attribute must be the empty string, the origin attribute must be the empty string, the source attribute must be null, and the ports attribute must be null."

right

[02:25:02.0000] <remysharp>
I'm trying to clarify a point - does HTML5 (and various implementations of specs surrounding it) extend: a) the DOM, b) the BOM (browser object model) or c) both (I thought it was this, but not completely sure now I've gone over and over in my head)?

[02:26:00.0000] <nessy>
Hixie: I guess it's self-evident that neither metadata nor none would be appropriate, but it may make sense to state the obvious

[02:27:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: the spec says the attribute is ignored altogether, so it doesn't matter what value it's treated as

[02:27:02.0000] <nessy>
ah I see: so it's up to the browser anyway - ok, I get it

[02:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
remysharp: Depends what you mean by DOM and BOM, I guess

[02:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: well how preload="" is handled is entirely up to the browser anyway, so it's kinda hard to tell the difference :-)

[02:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: it's just a hint

[02:28:03.0000] <Philip`>
remysharp: I don't think HTML5 redefines the basic DOM things like getAttribute and createElement etc - it just defers to DOM 3 Core for that

[02:29:00.0000] <nessy>
fair enough :)

[02:29:01.0000] <remysharp>
Philip`: so things like the applicationCache, would you say that's BOM then?

[02:29:02.0000] <Philip`>
remysharp: but it redefines all the interfaces that HTML pages expose to scripts via objects in the DOM

[02:29:03.0000] <Philip`>
remysharp: I would never use the term "BOM" :-)

[02:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
remysharp: (except for byte order marks)

[02:30:01.0000] <annevk>
remysharp, BOM means byte-order-mark

[02:30:02.0000] <annevk>
remysharp, we refer to everything as DOM usually

[02:30:03.0000] <remysharp>
Philip`: okay cool. That makes sense. I've been staring at the question so long none of the letters made much sense anymore!

[02:30:04.0000] <annevk>
remysharp, including e.g. XMLHttpRequest, applicationCache, etc.

[02:30:05.0000] <remysharp>

[05:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
asmodai: I think there was some issue like you couldn't have the same keyword in two different enumerated attributes

[05:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
so it was align="center" and valign="middle"

[05:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
(due to weirdness of SGML DTDs)

[05:04:03.0000] <Philip`>
though I could be entirely making that up

[05:05:00.0000] <zcorpan>
i think that's accurate; sgml had a feature where you could omit the attribute name and just have the value

[05:05:01.0000] <zcorpan>
like <td center middle>

[05:05:02.0000] <Philip`>
Did that feature have to be explicitly enabled for each attribute in the DTD?

[05:05:03.0000] <zcorpan>
no, it's enabled for all enumerated attributes

[05:07:00.0000] <zcorpan>
(there's no concept of boolean attributes in sgml; they're just enumerated with one value)

Hmm, indeed

[09:49:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:50:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:50:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:08:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, I guess バリデータ is the more common way to write it, rather than バリデーター

[10:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I suppose I should have checked that before tweeting it

[10:09:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh well

[10:09:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
that common usage sounds wrong to me, though

[10:09:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
バリデーター makes it a long "a" sound at the end

[10:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
with is the usual way of transliterating a final "r", like in "er"

[10:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
which there is no real equivalent for in Japanese

[10:10:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
バリデータ makes the last part sound more like "data", like Dashiva points out

[10:11:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, a lot of common ways of transliterating stuff in Japanese a plain wrong

[10:11:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
like マイケル for Michael

[10:12:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it should be マイクル or even マイコ

[10:14:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me almost fails to notice the difference between the first two

[10:17:00.0000] <Dashiva>
MikeSmith: It makes more sense if you assume the people transliterating it only knew the written form and not the pronounciation

[10:17:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, I know

[10:17:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
but it's actually changing

[10:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see more and more people on twitter and such who are dispensing with the bookish canonical transliterations of names and words and instead just writing them closer to the way they really sound

[10:19:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I'm guessing tech-oriented Japanese have to be able to transliterate independently just to keep up with new terms

[10:20:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Or are there a semi-official "authorities" for that?

[10:21:00.0000] <asmodai>
Not really.

[10:21:01.0000] <asmodai>
There's the G5 collection and some katakana dictionaries, but most of it is quite informal.

[10:21:02.0000] <asmodai>
Nothing like Kojien, Meikyou or such dictionaries tend to really touch it, unless the term is so common.

[09:22:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: Strange implementation of your html5 shim.  Did that come from performance tests or something?

[09:24:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, you mean with the while loop?  It's just the fastest, smallest way to do it.

[09:24:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
In a while loop, you get the best performance by sticking the math before the variable, like --i

[09:24:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's not the smallest way to do it.  May be fastest, shrug.

[09:25:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I bet it's one of the smallest ways to do it, minus all the generous spaces and variable names I gave it.

[09:25:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
"abbr,article,etc".split(',');for(var i=0;i<e.length;i++){document.createElement(e[i])} is what I use.

[09:26:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sorry, clipped that wrong.  Assume a "var e=" beginning that line.

[09:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And I'm certain you can do it smaller by using Array functions.

[09:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Does JS have map()?  :)

[09:27:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Yes.

[09:28:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, by one space... var e='abbr article etc'.split(' ');i=e.length+1;while(--i){document.createElement(elems[i])}

[09:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Does this work?  "abbr,article,etc".split(',').map(document.createElement)

[09:28:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
But the while loop is much better for performance.

[09:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
The performance here is negligible anyway.

[09:28:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Premature optimization is the root of all evil.

[09:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me doubts .map() will work in IE, though

[09:29:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: Actually, you can probably shave off more if you correctly reference e in the createElement call.  ^_^

[09:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Kind of defeats the point.

[09:30:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, yes.

[09:30:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
var e="abbr,article,etc".split(',');for(var i=0;i<e.length;i++){document.createElement(e[i])} VS

[09:30:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
var e='abbr article etc'.split(' ');i=e.length+1;while(--i){document.createElement(e[i])}

[09:30:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Really, it was the storing of the createElement result that confused me.

[09:31:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, that was unnecessary, in a previous implementation I was nulling out that value after the loop (for memory purposes, but I think it's negliable.

[17:17:00.0000] <afa>
Chrome has rolled in a preliminary WebForms validity API that has broken my site

[17:17:01.0000] <afa>
i'm going to report it as a bug, but i want to make sure i'm correct before i do

[17:17:02.0000] <afa>
if a radio or checkbox group has an element checked, the whole control should be valid, shouldn't it

[17:18:00.0000] <afa>
where "whole control" means every input with the same name

[17:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
afa: you're using the "required" attribute?

[17:21:00.0000] <afa>
yeah

[17:21:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm checking what the spec says

[17:21:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if it's not an implementation bug then it's clearly a spec bug

[17:22:00.0000] <afa>
thanks

[17:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
afa: for checkboxes, the spec says it is based on just the element's checkedness

[17:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#checkbox-state

[17:23:02.0000] <othermaciej>
So I guess a "required" checkbox has to be checked, regardless of the group

[17:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
afa: for radiobuttons, it is supposed to be per group

[17:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#radio-button-state

[17:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
afa: according to that spec, if any radiobutton in the group has checkedness of true, validation should pass

[17:28:00.0000] <afa>
sorry for wandering off

[17:28:01.0000] <afa>
that link crashes opera (and my IRC session)

[17:28:02.0000] <afa>
so anything you said after that, i didnt get

[17:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>
afa: eek, sorry

[17:30:00.0000] <afa>
it's been a while since i worked on this app, so i want to make sure my memory is correct

[17:31:00.0000] <afa>
if you POST a checkbox, then multiple identical keys get sent for each checked checkbox with the same name, correct?

[17:31:01.0000] <afa>
so if c1s1q1 had values 0 and 1 checked,

[17:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
afa: short version, for checkbox, "required" requires each checkbox to be chacked, regardless of "name", for radio buttons, it's per group

[17:31:03.0000] <afa>
c1s1q1=0&c1s1q1=1 would be POSTed?

[17:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think that's right but I don't really know

[17:32:01.0000] <afa>
i know when i first brought this up, you said this may be a spec bug

[17:33:00.0000] <afa>
and i know that the unintuitive parts of HTML are often there for a reason (perhaps legacy cruft, perhaps others)

[17:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if it was true for radio buttons, yeah

[17:33:02.0000] <afa>
so i want to discuss this before i comment on the RFC

[17:33:03.0000] <othermaciej>
@required isn't legacy

[17:33:04.0000] <afa>
i know, but i know in other cases, there have been reasons for the unintuitive parts

[17:33:05.0000] <afa>
so i want to make sure this isnt the case :)

[17:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think for radio buttons it works as you expect, for checkboxes, what the spec says sounds reasonable to me

[17:35:00.0000] <afa>
the radio bug is a problem in chrome

[17:35:01.0000] <afa>
the checkbox is a conflict between my JS implementation and the docs

[17:35:02.0000] <afa>
i may comment on that part of the spec just to get feedback

[17:36:00.0000] <afa>
on its face, it's not wholly unreasonable

[17:36:01.0000] <afa>
but it seems to me that a group validation is more flexible and consistent

[17:36:02.0000] <afa>
so any multiple choice widget, whether mutually exclusive or not, has the same API

[17:36:03.0000] <afa>
if you want to require a box to be checked, put it in its own group

[06:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>
>it should explicitly say alt="" MUST NOT be blank unless it MAY be left blank

[06:09:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Isn't that implied? Or am I misunderstanding how the terms work

[06:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
Implied requirements are dangerous

[06:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
It seems generally better to be explicit

[06:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me doesn't like "x MAY y if z" because he's never quite sure if the intention was "x MUST NOT y if not z", or "x MUST NOT (not y) if z", or something else

[06:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
although in the case of <area> it already says it must be text that's somehow equivalent to the image area, so I don't see why it'd need to be stated again

[06:33:00.0000] <Dashiva>
For additional fun, write requirements on the form "x MAY not y"

[06:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
And "x MUST only y if z"

[06:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
and "x MUST y only if z"

[06:36:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Maybe all normative criteria should be written using some kind of formal logic notation

[06:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
RFC2119 is fine as long as you use the words in simple sentences ("if z, then y MUST x", "if not z, then y MUST NOT x", etc)

[06:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
and I think HTML5 generally does that quite consistently now

[06:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oddly, Opera kerns text with strokeText on Linux but not with fillText

[06:55:01.0000] <Philip`>
and with neither on Windows

[07:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
Is there a reliable way to make sure a @font-face is loaded before trying to draw with it?

[07:29:01.0000] <Philip`>
Firefox and Opera seem to block onload as long as the font is used in a (non-display:none) element within the page itself, so that's okay

[07:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
Chromium doesn't, so it randomly works only half the time

[07:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
and if I do something like draw with the font, then wait a bit to make sure it's really loaded and draw again, Chromium crashes

[07:30:02.0000] <Philip`>
so that's not so good

[07:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
and I'm not sure how else to do it

[07:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, seems to work better if I actually use characters from the font in the page

[07:57:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Detect the character width?

[08:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: That would only help detect whether the font has been loaded, and wouldn't cause it to become loaded

[08:02:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: position: absolute; visibility: hidden; top: 0; left: 0; I guess would cause it to load

[08:02:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Without interfering with anything

[08:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
That seems to work

[08:07:01.0000] <Philip`>
(I was doing opacity:0 which also seems to work)

[08:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
with a 0.5s delay before drawing to make sure it's really loaded

[08:08:01.0000] <Philip`>
because WebKit doesn't delay onload, it seems

[13:15:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:16:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:18:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: Maybe this is the kind of stuff Larry was talking about as overspecifying

[13:18:01.0000] <Philip`>
Non-existence of createImageData is maybe the biggest thing

[13:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: Maybe, but they're almost all things that could come up in practice

[13:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'd probably call it "sensible, unambiguous, testable level of specification" rather than "overspecification"

[13:24:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I agree personally, but minor bugs that don't get fixed even over time may suggest otherwise

[13:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: It may suggest that expecting implementations to have 100% conformance is unrealistic and not a good use of anybody's time (and so the Rec criteria are broken and harmful), but problems are much more likely to get fixed if they're clearly specified and tested than if they're not

[13:33:01.0000] <Philip`>
so I don't think it suggests that it's not good to specify all the behaviour


2010-02-28
[20:48:00.0000] <boblet>
can anyone speak to the increased rigor Microdata has over Microformats? /cc @foolip

[20:49:00.0000] <boblet>
I can describe examples, but don’t know if I can adequately summarise it

[20:53:00.0000] <boblet>
things like using itemscope & itemprop vs class, defining href/datetime to be content and not text inside element, more explicit separation from content than uF (itemprop vs abbr and class-title patterns)…

[21:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: the main "increased rigour" is the same as the difference between html and xml -- you can parse microdata, like you can parse xml, without knowing the vocabulary in use.

[22:33:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: ahah. good I checked

[13:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
roc, the Ubuntu Chromium package lets you install it either with or without non-free codecs.  I suspect that typically the non-free codecs would be installed, since they're needed to play lots of content users would be likely to have.

[13:23:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:28:00.0000] <roc>
now I get to rant about how MPEG-LA selective enforcement conspires with well-meaning free software advocates promoting "legal workarounds" to hopelessly confuse the situation and reduce the chance we'll get a truly free solution

[13:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Chromium is only in PPAs in current versions, and this page makes it seem like the chromium-codecs-ffmpeg* packages aren't yet available in Lucid: http://packages.ubuntu.com/lucid/chromium-browser

[13:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
